data: ' \n\x05\x05\x05C T\n\x16\x16\x01f0704\x1freute\nu f BC-BAHIA-COCOA-R'
data: 'EVIEW   02-26 0105'

data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'BAHIA COCOA REVIEW'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    SALVADOR, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Showers continued throughout the week in\nthe Bahia cocoa zone, alle'
data: 'viating the drought since early\nJanuary and improving prospects for'
data: ' the coming temporao,\nalthough normal humidity levels have not been'
data: ' restored,\nComissaria Smith said in its weekly review.\n    The dry'
data: ' period means the temporao will be late this year.\n    Arrivals for'
data: ' the week ended February 22 were 155,221 bags\nof 60 kilos making a '
data: 'cumulative total for the season of 5.93\nmln against 5.81 at the sam'
data: 'e stage last year. Again it seems\nthat cocoa delivered earlier on c'
data: 'onsignment was included in the\narrivals figures.\n    Comissaria Sm'
data: 'ith said there is still some doubt as to how\nmuch old crop cocoa is'
data: ' still available as harvesting has\npractically come to an end. With'
data: ' total Bahia crop estimates\naround 6.4 mln bags and sales standing '
data: 'at almost 6.2 mln there\nare a few hundred thousand bags still in th'
data: 'e hands of farmers,\nmiddlemen, exporters and processors.\n    There'
data: ' are doubts as to how much of this cocoa would be fit\nfor export as'
data: ' shippers are now experiencing dificulties in\nobtaining +Bahia supe'
data: 'rior+ certificates.\n    In view of the lower quality over recent we'
data: 'eks farmers have\nsold a good part of their cocoa held on consignmen'
data: 't.\n    Comissaria Smith said spot bean prices rose to 340 to 350\nc'
data: 'ruzados per arroba of 15 kilos.\n    Bean shippers were reluctant to'
data: ' offer nearby shipment and\nonly limited sales were booked for March'
data: ' shipment at 1,750 to\n1,780 dlrs per tonne to ports to be named.\n '
data: '   New crop sales were also light and all to open ports with\nJune/J'
data: 'uly going at 1,850 and 1,880 dlrs and at 35 and 45 dlrs\nunder New Y'
data: 'ork july, Aug/Sept at 1,870, 1,875 and 1,880 dlrs\nper tonne FOB.\n '
data: '   Routine sales of butter were made. March/April sold at\n4,340, 4,'
data: '345 and 4,350 dlrs.\n    April/May butter went at 2.27 times New Yor'
data: 'k May, June/July\nat 4,400 and 4,415 dlrs, Aug/Sept at 4,351 to 4,45'
data: '0 dlrs and at\n2.27 and 2.28 times New York Sept and Oct/Dec at 4,48'
data: '0 dlrs and\n2.27 times New York Dec, Comissaria Smith said.\n    Des'
data: 'tinations were the U.S., Covertible currency areas,\nUruguay and ope'
data: 'n ports.\n    Cake sales were registered at 785 to 995 dlrs for\nMar'
data: 'ch/April, 785 dlrs for May, 753 dlrs for Aug and 0.39 times\nNew Yor'
data: 'k Dec for Oct/Dec.\n    Buyers were the U.S., Argentina, Uruguay and'
data: ' convertible\ncurrency areas.\n    Liquor sales were limited with Ma'
data: 'rch/April selling at 2,325\nand 2,380 dlrs, June/July at 2,375 dlrs '
data: 'and at 1.25 times New\nYork July, Aug/Sept at 2,400 dlrs and at 1.25'
data: ' times New York\nSept and Oct/Dec at 1.25 times New York Dec, Comiss'
data: 'aria Smith\nsaid.\n    Total Bahia sales are currently estimated at '
data: '6.13 mln bags\nagainst the 1986/87 crop and 1.06 mln bags against th'
data: 'e 1987/88\ncrop.\n    Final figures for the period to February 28 ar'
data: 'e expected to\nbe published by the Brazilian Cocoa Trade Commission '
data: 'after\ncarnival which ends midday on February 27.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

data: 'sh Petroleum Co\nPlc <BP>, which also owns a 55 pct interest in Stan'

end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'TALKING POINT/BANKAMERICA <BAC> EQUITY OFFER'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    by Janie Gabbett, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    LOS ANGELES, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'BankAmerica Corp is not under\npressure to act quickly on its propos'
data: 'ed equity offering and\nwould do well to delay it because of the sto'
data: "ck's recent poor\nperformance, banking analysts said.\n    Some anal"
data: 'ysts said they have recommended BankAmerica delay\nits up to one-bil'
data: 'lion-dlr equity offering, which has yet to be\napproved by the Secur'
data: 'ities and Exchange Commission.\n    BankAmerica stock fell this week'
data: ', along with other banking\nissues, on the news that Brazil has susp'
data: 'ended interest payments\non a large portion of its foreign debt.\n  '
data: '  The stock traded around 12, down 1/8, this afternoon,\nafter falli'
data: 'ng to 11-1/2 earlier this week on the news.\n    Banking analysts sa'
data: 'id that with the immediate threat of the\nFirst Interstate Bancorp <'
data: 'I> takeover bid gone, BankAmerica is\nunder no pressure to sell the '
data: 'securities into a market that\nwill be nervous on bank stocks in the'
data: ' near term.\n    BankAmerica filed the offer on January 26. It was s'
data: 'een as\none of the major factors leading the First Interstate\nwithd'
data: 'rawing its takeover bid on February 9.\n    A BankAmerica spokesman '
data: 'said SEC approval is taking longer\nthan expected and market conditi'
data: 'ons must now be re-evaluated.\n    "The circumstances at the time wi'
data: 'll determine what we do,"\nsaid Arthur Miller, BankAmerica\'s Vice P'
data: 'resident for Financial\nCommunications, when asked if BankAmerica wo'
data: 'uld proceed with\nthe offer immediately after it receives SEC approv'
data: 'al.\n    "I\'d put it off as long as they conceivably could," said\n'
data: 'Lawrence Cohn, analyst with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and\nSmith'
data: '.\n    Cohn said the longer BankAmerica waits, the longer they\nhave'
data: ' to show the market an improved financial outlook.\n    Although Ban'
data: 'kAmerica has yet to specify the types of\nequities it would offer, m'
data: 'ost analysts believed a convertible\npreferred stock would encompass'
data: ' at least part of it.\n    Such an offering at a depressed stock pri'
data: 'ce would mean a\nlower conversion price and more dilution to BankAme'
data: 'rica stock\nholders, noted Daniel Williams, analyst with Sutro Group'
data: '.\n    Several analysts said that while they believe the Brazilian\n'
data: 'debt problem will continue to hang over the banking industry\nthroug'
data: 'h the quarter, the initial shock reaction is likely to\nease over th'
data: 'e coming weeks.\n    Nevertheless, BankAmerica, which holds about 2.'
data: '70 billion\ndlrs in Brazilian loans, stands to lose 15-20 mln dlrs i'
data: 'f the\ninterest rate is reduced on the debt, and as much as 200 mln\n'
data: 'dlrs if Brazil pays no interest for a year, said Joseph\nArsenio, an'
data: 'alyst with Birr, Wilson and Co.\n    He noted, however, that any pot'
data: 'ential losses would not show\nup in the current quarter.\n    With o'
data: 'ther major banks standing to lose even more than\nBankAmerica if Bra'
data: 'zil fails to service its debt, the analysts\nsaid they expect the de'
data: "bt will be restructured, similar to way\nMexico's debt was, minimizi"
data: 'ng losses to the creditor banks.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'
end tag: </reuters>

start tag: <body>
data: 'BankAmerica Corp is not under\npressure to act quickly on its propos'
data: 'ed equity offering and\nwould do well to delay it because of the sto'
data: "ck's recent poor\nperformance, banking analysts said.\n    Some anal"
data: 'ysts said they have recommended BankAmerica delay\nits up to one-bil'
data: 'lion-dlr equity offering, which has yet to be\napproved by the Secur'
data: 'ities and Exchange Commission.\n    BankAmerica stock fell this week'
data: ', along with other banking\nissues, on the news that Brazil has susp'
data: 'ended interest payments\non a large portion of its foreign debt.\n  '
data: '  The stock traded around 12, down 1/8, this afternoon,\nafter falli'
data: 'ng to 11-1/2 earlier this week on the news.\n    Banking analysts sa'
data: 'id that with the immediate threat of the\nFirst Interstate Bancorp <'
data: 'I> takeover bid gone, BankAmerica is\nunder no pressure to sell the '
data: 'securities into a market that\nwill be nervous on bank stocks in the'
data: ' near term.\n    BankAmerica filed the offer on January 26. It was s'
data: 'een as\none of the major factors leading the First Interstate\nwithd'
data: 'rawing its takeover bid on February 9.\n    A BankAmerica spokesman '
data: 'said SEC approval is taking longer\nthan expected and market conditi'
data: 'ons must now be re-evaluated.\n    "The circumstances at the time wi'
data: 'll determine what we do,"\nsaid Arthur Miller, BankAmerica\'s Vice P'
data: 'resident for Financial\nCommunications, when asked if BankAmerica wo'
data: 'uld proceed with\nthe offer immediately after it receives SEC approv'
data: 'al.\n    "I\'d put it off as long as they conceivably could," said\n'
data: 'Lawrence Cohn, analyst with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and\nSmith'
data: '.\n    Cohn said the longer BankAmerica waits, the longer they\nhave'
data: ' to show the market an improved financial outlook.\n    Although Ban'
data: 'kAmerica has yet to specify the types of\nequities it would offer, m'
data: 'ost analysts believed a convertible\npreferred stock would encompass'
data: ' at least part of it.\n    Such an offering at a depressed stock pri'
data: 'ce would mean a\nlower conversion price and more dilution to BankAme'
data: 'rica stock\nholders, noted Daniel Williams, analyst with Sutro Group'
data: '.\n    Several analysts said that while they believe the Brazilian\n'
data: 'debt problem will continue to hang over the banking industry\nthroug'
data: 'h the quarter, the initial shock reaction is likely to\nease over th'
data: 'e coming weeks.\n    Nevertheless, BankAmerica, which holds about 2.'
data: '70 billion\ndlrs in Brazilian loans, stands to lose 15-20 mln dlrs i'
data: 'f the\ninterest rate is reduced on the debt, and as much as 200 mln\n'
data: 'dlrs if Brazil pays no interest for a year, said Joseph\nArsenio, an'
data: 'alyst with Birr, Wilson and Co.\n    He noted, however, that any pot'
data: 'ential losses would not show\nup in the current quarter.\n    With o'
data: 'ther major banks standing to lose even more than\nBankAmerica if Bra'
data: 'zil fails to service its debt, the analysts\nsaid they expect the de'
data: "bt will be restructured, similar to way\nMexico's debt was, minimizi"
data: 'ng losses to the creditor banks.\n Reuter\n\x03'

data: 'T-(NEWS-A NALYSIS)  02-26 0092'
end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: "TOWER REPORT DIMINISHES REAGAN'S HOPES OF REBOUND"
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Michael Gelb, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The Tower Commission report, which\nsays President Reagan was ignora'
data: 'nt about much of the Iran arms\ndeal, just about ends his prospects '
data: 'of regaining political\ndominance in Washington, political analysts '
data: 'said.\n    "This is certification of incompetence," private politica'
data: 'l\nanalyst Stephen Hess told Reuters in commenting on the Tower\nrep'
data: 'ort made public today.\n    "It\'s as if he went before a profession'
data: 'al licensing board\nand was denied credentials."\n    In one of the '
data: 'most direct criticisms, board chairman John\nTower, a longtime Reaga'
data: 'n supporter and former Republican\nsenator from Texas, told a press '
data: 'conference, "The president\nclearly did not understand the nature of'
data: ' this operation."\n    The report, which lent credence to widespread'
data: ' opinion in\nWashington that Reagan is not in full command of the\ng'
data: 'overnment, was particularly damaging because it was prepared\nby a b'
data: "oard of the Republican president's own choosing.\n    The three-memb"
data: 'er panel made up of Tower, former National\nSecurity Adviser Brent S'
data: 'cowcroft and former Secretary of State\nEdmund Muskie, does not carr'
data: 'y the partisan taint of criticism\nfrom a Congress controlled by the'
data: ' Democratic party.\n    "We\'re falling by our own hand," said one R'
data: 'epublican\npolitical strategist. "What can we say except \'we\'re so'
data: 'rry, we\nwon\'t do it again\'?"\n    The strategist, who works for o'
data: "ne of his party's top 1988\npresidential contenders and asked not to"
data: ' be identified, said\nthe report was like "an anvil falling on us."\n'
data: '    Hess, with the Brookings Institution public policy study\ngroup,'
data: " said the report is the final blow to Reagan's hopes of\nregaining t"
data: 'he upper hand he once had in dealings with Congress,\nthe press and '
data: 'the Washington bureaucracy.\n    The report may also undermine the s'
data: 'tanding of Defense\nSecretary Caspar Weinberger and Secretary of Sta'
data: 'te George\nShultz, who the report suggests were more interested in k'
data: 'eeping\ntheir own skirts clean than supporting the president.\n    "'
data: 'They protected the record as to their own positions on this\nissue. '
data: 'They were not energetic in attempting to protect the\npresident from'
data: ' the consequences," it said.\n    White House chief of staff Donald '
data: 'Regan and former Central\nIntelligence Agency Director William Casey'
data: ' also received strong\ncriticism, but the blows were expected in the'
data: 'ir cases.\n    Regan, expected to resign or be fired shortly, was sa'
data: 'vaged\nfor allegedly failing both to help Reagan conduct the Iran\ni'
data: 'nitiative and to avoid "chaos" in the disclosure process.\n    Casey'
data: ', who underwent surgery for removal of a cancerous\nbrain tumor in D'
data: 'ecember, had already resigned for health\nreasons last month.\n    "'
data: 'This is a story about people who came up somewhat short of\nbeing he'
data: 'roes," Tower told reporters.\n    While Reagan retains considerable '
data: 'constitutional powers,\nincluding command of the armed forces and th'
data: 'e right to veto\nlegislation, analysts say it will be difficult for '
data: "him to\nretake control of the country's policy agenda -- particularl"
data: 'y\nwith Congress controlled by the Democrats.\n    The crucial remai'
data: 'ning question, they said, is whether the\nman in the street will for'
data: 'sake Reagan over the affair.\n    Although his job approval rating h'
data: 'as fallen as much as\ntwenty percentage points in some opinion polls'
data: ' since the arms\ndeal with Iran became public last November, his per'
data: 'sonal\npopularity is still relatively high.\n    A Los Angeles Times'
data: ' poll released earlier this week showed\nthat just 37 pct of those s'
data: 'urveyed thought Reagan was in\ncontrol of the government, but 55 pct'
data: ' still thought he was\ndoing a good job as president.\n    American '
data: 'Enterprise Institute analyst William Schneider, a\nDemocrat, says Re'
data: "agan's loss of support among Washington power\nbrokers could be offs"
data: 'et by continued backing of the public.\n    "In the past, he has bee'
data: 'n able to go around the power elite\nby appealing directly to the pu'
data: 'blic," Schneider said.\n    Reagan will again plead his case that wa'
data: 'y in a televised\naddress next week.\n    But one top Republican str'
data: 'ategist warned against expecting\na dramatic turnaround.\n    "The W'
data: 'hite House has to avoid building expectations that\ncannot be met," '
data: 'said the strategist, who requested anonymity.\n"They have to recogni'
data: 'ze there is no quick fix."\n    Analysts also point out that Reagan\''
data: 's personal popularity\nhas not always translated into public backing'
data: ' for his policies.\n    They note he was dramatically rebuffed in la'
data: "st November's\nelections when voters rejected his appeals and restor"
data: 'ed control\nof the Senate to the Democrats.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

data: "ent of Defense's de facto veto authority\nover the licensing process"

data: 'ore\nrational...licensing process will boost exports."\n    U.S. exp'
data: 'ort controls are intended to deny Eastern bloc\ncountries access to '
data: 'technology that could further their\nmilitary capabilities.\n    "By'
data: ' refocusing our control resources on higher levels of\ntechnology, t'

data: 'oting more exports," Cranston said.\n    "We cannot expect to contin'

data: 'BRAZIL ANTI-INFLATION PLAN LIMPS TO ANNIVERSARY'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb 26 - Brazil\'s "Cruzado" anti- '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'inflation\nplan, initially hailed at home and abroad as the saviour '
data: 'of the\neconomy, is limping towards its first anniversary amid soari'
data: 'ng\nprices, widespread shortages and a foreign payments crisis.\n   '
data: ' Announced last February 28 the plan froze prices, fixed the\nvalue '
data: 'of the new Cruzado currency and ended widespread\nindexation of the '
data: "economy in a bid to halt the country's 250\npct inflation rate.\n   "
data: ' But within a year the plan has all but collapsed.\n    "The situati'
data: 'on now is worse than it was. Although there was\ninflation, at least'
data: ' the economy worked," a leading bank\neconomist said.\n    The crumb'
data: 'ling of the plan has been accompanied by a\ndramatic reversal in the'
data: " foreign trade account. In 1984 and\n1985 Brazil's annual trade surp"
data: 'luses had been sufficient to\ncover the 12 billion dlrs needed to se'
data: 'rvice its 109 billion dlr\nforeign debt.\n    For the first nine mon'
data: 'ths of 1986 all seemed to be on\ntarget for a repeat, with monthly s'
data: 'urpluses averaging one\nbillion dlrs. But as exports were diverted a'
data: 'nd imports\nincreased to avoid further domestic shortages the trade '
data: 'surplus\nplunged to 211 mln dlrs in October and since then has avera'
data: 'ged\nunder 150 mln.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'U.S. DATA POINT TO CAPITAL SPENDING SLOWDOWN'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Kathleen Hays, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    NEW YORK, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'A surprise 7.5 pct drop in U.S. January\ndurable goods orders points'
data: ' to a slowdown in capital spending\nthat could presage lackluster re'
data: 'al growth in the U.S. economy\nin the first quarter of 1987, economi'
data: 'sts said.\n    With total orders, excluding the volatile defense sec'
data: 'tor,\nfalling a record 9.9 pct, economists agreed that the report\np'
data: 'ainted a bleak picture for the U.S. economy.\n    But they stressed '
data: 'that the 1987 tax reform laws may be a\nprimary factor behind the dr'
data: 'op in orders for business capital\ninvestment.\n    "It\'s a rather '
data: 'gloomy outlook for the economy, said David\nWyss of Data Resources I'
data: 'nc. "I\'m particularly impressed by the\n19.7 pct drop in non-defens'
data: 'e capital goods orders because it\nmay be a sign that businesses are'
data: ' reacting more adversely to\ntax reform than we thought."\n    The C'
data: 'ommerce Department pointed out that a record 14.8 pct\ndecline in ne'
data: 'w orders for machinery was led by declines in\noffice and computing '
data: 'equipment orders.\n    Economists said the drop in computer orders m'
data: 'ay have been a\nresponse to the lengthening of depreciation schedule'
data: 's and the\nend of the investment tax credit under the new tax laws.\n'
data: '    "It\'s more expensive to invest than it used to be, so\npeople j'
data: 'ust aren\'t doing it as much," Wyss said.\n     Increases in durable'
data: " goods orders at year's end reinforced\nthe view that businesses ant"
data: 'icipated the changing tax laws,\neconomists said.\n    November dura'
data: "ble goods orders rose 5.1 pct and December's\nincreased 1.5 pct, rev"
data: 'ised upwards from a previously reported\n0.9 pct.\n    But most ackn'
data: 'owledged that the huge January drop was caused\nby more than tax ref'
data: 'orm.\n    "The wash-out that took place in January was far greater\n'
data: 'than the actual gains that took place in November and\nDecember," sa'
data: 'id Bill Sullivan of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. "The\neconomy has a we'
data: 'akening bent to it early in the year."\n    "The report definitely p'
data: 'oints to very sluggish capital\nspending over the next couple of qua'
data: 'rters," said Donald Maude\nof Midland Montagu Capital Markets Inc.\n'
data: '    Maude pointed to a continuing decline in order backlogs as\nevid'
data: 'ence that the outlook for new orders is not improving. In\nNovember,'
data: ' order backlogs rose 0.6 pct, but in December they\nfell 0.6 pct and'
data: ' in January 0.7 pct, he said.\n    "It suggests orders in the pipeli'
data: 'ne are depleting, which\nmay quickly translate to a drop in producti'
data: 'on," Midland\nMontagu\'s Maude said.\n    Wyss cautioned that too mu'
data: "ch should not be made of\nJanuary's report, given that other reports"
data: ' have reflected\nstrength.\n    But he acknowledged that the decline'
data: ' occurred despite a 51\npct rise in defense orders, compared with a '
data: '57.7 pct decline in\nDecember.\n    He also noted that there was a 6'
data: '.9 pct drop in January\nshipments, compared with a 5.4 pct rise in D'
data: 'ecember.\n    "Given these numbers, there\'s no reason for the Fed t'
data: 'o\ntighten," Data Resources\' Wyss said.\n    "But there\'s no reaso'
data: 'n to ease unless we see more numbers\nlike this. The Fed will wait a'
data: 'nd see," he added.\n    Sullivan predicted the Fed will ease by East'
data: 'er. "People\naren\'t talking recession or Fed easing now, but the Fe'
data: 'd will\nhave to ease to ensure global growth."\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The chairmen and senior Republican\nmembers of the House and Senate '
data: 'tax writing committees proposed\nlegislation to curb estate tax dedu'
data: 'ction on sales of stock to\nan employee stock ownership plan.\n    T'
data: 'he proposal would raise federal revenues of 6.7 billion\ndlrs over t'
data: 'he fiscal year period 1987 to 1991.\n    If adopted by Congress it w'
data: 'ould effect all transactions\nafter Sept 26, 1987.\n    The plan was'
data: ' proposed by House Ways and Means Committee\nChairman Dan Rostenkows'
data: 'ki (D-Ill), Rep John Duncan (R-Tenn),\nSenate Finance Committee Chai'
data: 'rman Lloyd Bentsen (D-Tex) and Sen\nBob Packwood (R-Ore).\n    In a '
data: 'statement Rostenkowski said the estate tax deduction\nenacted last y'
data: 'ear as part of the tax reform bill was too broad\nand would have cos'
data: 't the governmet seven billion dlrs over four\nyears. The narrower de'
data: 'duction would cost the government less\nthan 300 mln dlrs for the sa'
data: 'me years.\n    He said it was designed to avoid sham transactions wh'
data: 'ich\nallowed estates to avoid taxes by transferring stock to ESOPs.\n'
data: '    Senate Finance Committee chairman Lloyd Bentsen said in a\nstate'
data: 'ment, "The Tax Reform Act contains a provision that allows\nmany wea'
data: 'lthy individuals to avoid the federal estate tax\nentirely when they'
data: ' die."\n    He added, "The provision was intended to encourage estat'
data: 'es\nto sell stock to employee stock ownership plans as a way of\npro'
data: 'moting worker ownership; however, the provision was not\nmeant to be'
data: ' broad enough to reduce federal revenues as much as\nis currently es'
data: 'timated."\n    He added, "The bill I have introduced today calls for'
data: ' the\nmodification of the provision in accordance with its intended\n'
data: 'purpose."\n Reuter\n\x03'

end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'QUEBECOR <PQB> HEAD SEES NEW VENTURES LIKELY'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Jane Arraf, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    MONTREAL, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "Quebecor Inc, one of Canada's largest\npublishing and printing compa"
data: 'nies, is likely to launch a new\ndaily newspaper in Montreal, probab'
data: 'ly this fall, president\nPierre Peladeau told Reuters in an intervie'
data: 'w.\n    The company, which last week won a bid to buy the Quebec\ngo'
data: "vernment's 55 pct interest in pulp and paper company <Donohue\nInc>,"
data: ' will also likely go ahead with plans to build a new paper\nmill in '
data: 'Matane, Quebec, Peladeau said.\n    "I would say we will move (ahead'
data: ' with the daily).... This\nis not definite but i think we will," he '
data: 'said, adding that he\nplans to announce a decision early next week.\n'
data: '    Quebecor, which had revenues of 446 mln Canadian dlrs last\nyear'
data: ' and profit of 16.2 mln dlrs, already publishes three daily\nnewspap'
data: 'ers, including the tabloid Le Journal de Montreal, the\nsecond-large'
data: 'st circulation paper in Canada.\n    A new daily would give Montreal'
data: ' its second English-\nlanguage paper and its sixth daily newspaper, '
data: 'making the city\nthe most crowded metropolitan newspaper market in N'
data: 'orth\nAmerica, analysts have said.\n    Peladeau said market studies'
data: ' have indicated a new English\nlanguage tabloid would have circulati'
data: 'on of 50,000 within six\nmonths. He said he is waiting to determine '
data: 'whether the new\nventure would have the support of major advertisers'
data: '.\n    Peladeau, who together with family members owns about 55\npct'
data: ' of Quebecor, said he has recieved offers from the heads of\ntwo maj'
data: 'or Canadian companies who are interested in the project\nbut has not'
data: ' decided whether he would take partners in the\nnewspaper venture.\n'
data: '    He said he would consider launching the newspaper with one\nof t'
data: 'he companies as a prelude to other joint ventures.\n    "It would be'
data: ' the possibility of doing something else in the\nshort term," Pelade'
data: 'au said.\n    Peladeau said the joint acquisition of Donohue with Ro'
data: "bert\nMaxwell's British Printing and Communications Corp plc <BPCL.L"
data: '>\ndoes not mean Quebecor will have to hold off on other projects.\n'
data: "    Peladeau and Maxwell's companies teamed up to buy the stake\nin "
data: 'Donohue, which resulted in Quebecor buying 51 pct of the\ngovvernmen'
data: "t's stake for about 165 mln Canadian dlrs and British\nprinting acqu"
data: 'iring the other 49 pct.\n    "In 1976 or 77 there was a tremendous s'
data: "hortage of\nnewsprint. There were days when we didn't have enough pa"
data: 'per to\nprint the paper," Peladeau said. "When I lived that, I said '
data: 'to\nmyself...next time we\'ll be ready."\n    Peladeau said most of '
data: "Donohue's current total newsprint\ncapacity however, is already comm"
data: 'itted to other buyers.\n    Quebecor uses about 100,000 metric tons '
data: "of newsprint a year\nand Maxwell's company, which publishes Britain'"
data: 's Daily Mirror\nnewspaper, uses about 200,000 tonnes.\n    Peladeau '
data: 'said even with a new 170 mln dlr paper machine, 49\npct owned by the'
data: " New York Times, (NYT.A), adding to Donohue's\n540,000 metric tonne "
data: 'capacity this fall, the companies will\nhave to install another pape'
data: 'r machine at Amos, Quebec, or build\nanother mill to meet their dema'
data: 'nds .\n    He said a new mill, which would produce either newsprint '
data: 'or\nother types of paper, would cost 400-500 mln dlrs and could be\n'
data: 'on stream in two years. He said a mill in Matane, a depressed\narea '
data: 'with high unemployment, would be heavily subsidized by the\ngovernme'
data: 'nt.\n    Peladeau said he is interested in further joint ventures\nw'
data: "ith Maxwell's company, either in the newspaper market in\nFrance or "
data: 'in the U.S., where the company owns two large\nprinting plants and i'
data: "s looking to expand its newspaper empire.\n    He said Maxwell's son"
data: 's, who are French citizens, would\nprovide an entree into the French'
data: ' market, where foreigners are\nprevented from buying newspapers. Pel'
data: 'adeau said he would\nconsider either buying into or starting daily n'
data: 'ewspapers in\nFrance or the U.S.\n    Quebecor is also in the proces'
data: 's of expanding its chain of\nabout 40 weekly newspapers, with the po'
data: 'ssible acquisition of\ntwo groups of weekly newspapers in the U.S., '
data: 'and is negotiating\nthe acquisition of two weekly newspaper chains i'
data: 'n Canada,\nPeladeau said.\n    He said the company may consider star'
data: 'ting daily newspapers\nin two small Quebec cities and buying radio s'
data: 'tations in the\nprovince.\n    Peladeau said Quebecor may also consi'
data: 'der trading in its\nlisting on the American stock exchange for a New'
data: ' York Stock\nExchange listing.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

data: 'dling, 1-1/16 inch\nupland cotton at 52.69 cts per lb, to be in effe'
data: 'ct through\nmidnight March 5.\n    The adjusted world price is at av'
data: 'erage U.S. producing\nlocations (near Lubbock, Texas) and will be fu'
data: 'rther adjusted\nfor other qualities and locations. The price will be'
data: ' used in\ndetermining First Handler Cotton Certificate payment rates'
data: '.\n    Based on data for the week ended February 26, the adjusted\nw'
data: 'orld price for upland cotton is determined as follows, in cts\nper l'
data: 'b --\n Northern European Price               66.32\n      Adjustment'

start tag: <title>
data: 'IRAN ANNOUNCES END OF MAJOR OFFENSIVE IN GULF WAR'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    LONDON, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Iran announced tonight that its major\noffensive against Iraq in the'
data: ' Gulf war had ended after dealing\nsavage blows against the Baghdad '
data: 'government.\n    The Iranian news agency IRNA, in a report received '
data: 'in\nLondon, said the operation code-named Karbala-5 launched into\nI'
data: 'raq on January 9 was now over.\n    It quoted a joint statewment by '
data: 'the Iranian Army and\nRevolutionary Guards Corps as saying that thei'
data: 'r forces had\n"dealt one of the severest blows on the Iraqi war mach'
data: 'ine in the\nhistory of the Iraq-imposed war."\n    The statement by '
data: 'the Iranian High Command appeared to\nherald the close of an assault'
data: ' on the port city of Basra in\nsouthern Iraq.\n    "The operation wa'
data: 's launched at a time when the Baghdad\ngovernment was spreading exte'
data: 'nsive propaganda on the resistance\npower of its army...," said the '
data: 'statement quoted by IRNA.\n    It claimed massive victories in the s'
data: 'even-week offensive\nand called on supporters of Baghdad to "come to'
data: ' their senses" and\ndiscontinue support for what it called the totte'
data: 'ring regime in\nIraq.\n    Iran said its forces had "liberated" 155 '
data: 'square kilometers of\nenemy-occupied territory during the 1987 offen'
data: 'sive and taken\nover islands, townships, rivers and part of a road l'
data: 'eading into\nBasra.\n    The Iranian forces "are in full control of '
data: 'these areas," the\nstatement said.\n    It said 81 Iraqi brigades an'
data: 'd battalions were totally\ndestroyed, along with 700 tanks and 1,500'
data: ' other vehicles. The\nvictory list also included 80 warplanes downed'
data: ', 250 anti-\naircraft guns and 400 pieces of military hardware destr'
data: 'oyed and\nthe seizure of 220 tanks and armoured personnel carriers.\n'
data: ' Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

data: 'U.S. BANK DISCOUNT BORROWINGS 310 MLN DLRS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    NEW YORK, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'U.S. bank discount window borrowings\nless extended credits averaged'
data: ' 310 mln dlrs in the week to\nWednesday February 25, the Federal Res'
data: 'erve said.\n    The Fed said that overall borrowings in the week fel'
data: 'l 131\nmln dlrs to 614 mln dlrs, with extended credits up 10 mln dlr'
data: 's\nat 304 mln dlrs. The week was the second half of a two-week\nstat'
data: 'ement period. Net borrowings in the prior week averaged 451\nmln dlr'
data: 's.\n    Commenting on the two-week statement period ended February\n'
data: '25, the Fed said that banks had average net free reserves of\n644 ml'
data: 'n dlrs a day, down from 1.34 billion two weeks earlier.\n    A Feder'
data: 'al Reserve spokesman told a press briefing that\nthere were no large'
data: " single day net misses in the Fed's reserve\nprojections in the week"
data: ' to Wednesday.\n    He said that natural float had been "acting a bi'
data: 't\nstrangely" for this time of year, noting that there had been\npoo'
data: 'r weather during the latest week.\n    The spokesman said that natur'
data: 'al float ranged from under 500\nmln dlrs on Friday, for which he cou'
data: 'ld give no reason, to\nnearly one billion dlrs on both Thursday and '
data: "Wednesday.\n    The Fed spokeman could give no reason for Thursday's"
data: " high\nfloat, but he said that about 750 mln dlrs of Wednesday's\nfl"
data: 'oat figure was due to holdover and transportation float at\ntwo wide'
data: 'ly separated Fed districts.\n    For the week as a whole, he said th'
data: 'at float related as of\nadjustments were "small," adding that they f'
data: 'ell to a negative\n750 mln dlrs on Tuesday due to a number of correc'
data: 'tions for\nunrelated cash letter errors in six districts around the\n'
data: 'country.\n    The spokesman said that on both Tuesday and Wednesday,'
data: ' two\ndifferent clearing banks had system problems and the securitie'
data: 's\nand Federal funds wires had to be held open until about 2000 or\n'
data: '2100 EST on both days.\n    However, he said that both problems were'
data: ' cleared up during\nboth afternoons and there was no evidence of any'
data: ' reserve\nimpact.\n    During the week ended Wednesday, 45 pct of ne'
data: 't discount\nwindow borrowings were made by the smallest banks, with '
data: '30 pct\nby the 14 large money center banks and 25 pct by large regio'
data: 'nal\ninstitutions.\n    On Wednesday, 55 pct of the borrowing was ac'
data: 'counted for by\nthe money center banks, with 30 pct by the large reg'
data: 'ionals and\n15 pct by the smallest banks.\n    The Fed spokesman sai'
data: 'd the banking system had excess\nreserves on Thursday, Monday and Tu'
data: 'esday and a deficit on\nFriday and Wedndsday. That produced a small '
data: 'daily average\ndeficit for the week as a whole.\n    For the two-wee'
data: 'k period, he said there were relatively high\nexcess reserves on a d'
data: 'aily avearge, almost all of which were at\nthe smallest banks.\n Reu'
data: 'ter\n\x03'

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'AMERICAN EXPRESS <AXP> SEEN IN POSSIBLE SPINNOFF'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Patti Domm, Reuter'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    New York, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'American Express Co remained silent on\nmarket rumors it would spino'
data: 'ff all or part of its Shearson\nLehman Brothers Inc, but some analys'
data: 'ts said the company may be\nconsidering such a move because it is un'
data: 'happy with the market\nvalue of its stock.\n    American Express sto'
data: 'ck got a lift from the rumor, as the\nmarket calculated a partially '
data: 'public Shearson may command a\ngood market value, thereby boosting t'
data: 'he total value of American\nExpress. The rumor also was accompanied '
data: 'by talk the financial\nservices firm would split its stock and boost'
data: ' its dividend.\n    American Express closed on the New York Stock Ex'
data: 'change at\n72-5/8, up 4-1/8 on heavy volume.\n    American Express w'
data: 'ould not comment on the rumors or its\nstock activity.\n    Analysts'
data: " said comments by the company at an analysts'\nmeeting Tuesday helpe"
data: 'd fuel the rumors as did an announcement\nyesterday of management ch'
data: 'anges.\n    At the meeting, company officials said American Express\n'
data: 'stock is undervalued and does not fully reflect the performance\nof '
data: 'Shearson, according to analysts.\n    Yesterday, Shearson said it wa'
data: 's elevating its chief\noperating officer, Jeffery Lane, to the added'
data: ' position of\npresident, which had been vacant. It also created four'
data: ' new\npositions for chairmen of its operating divisions.\n    Analys'
data: 'ts speculated a partial spinoff would make most\nsense, contrary to '
data: 'one variation on market rumors of a total\nspinoff.\n    Some analys'
data: 'ts, however, disagreed that any spinoff of\nShearson would be good s'
data: 'ince it is a strong profit center for\nAmerican Express, contributin'
data: 'g about 20 pct of earnings last\nyear.\n    "I think it is highly un'
data: 'likely that American Express is\ngoing to sell shearson," said Perri'
data: 'n Long of Lipper Analytical.\nHe questioned what would be a better i'
data: 'nvestment than "a very\nprofitable securities firm."\n    Several an'
data: 'alysts said American Express is not in need of\ncash, which might be'
data: ' the only reason to sell a part of a strong\nasset.\n    But others '
data: 'believe the company could very well of\nconsidered the option of spi'
data: 'nning out part of Shearson, and one\nrumor suggests selling about 20'
data: ' pct of it in the market.\n    Larry Eckenfelder of Prudential-Bache'
data: ' Securities said he\nbelieves American Express could have considered'
data: ' a partial\nspinoff in the past.\n    "Shearson being as profitable '
data: 'as it is would have fetched a\nbig premium in the market place. Shea'
data: "rson's book value is in\nthe 1.4 mln dlr range. Shearson in the mark"
data: 'et place would\nprobably be worth three to 3.5 bilion dlrs in terms '
data: 'of market\ncapitalization," said Eckenfelder.\n    Some analysts sai'
data: 'd American Express could use capital since\nit plans to expand globa'
data: 'lly.\n    "They have enormous internal growth plans that takes\ncapi'
data: 'tal. You want your stock to reflect realistic valuations to\nenhance'
data: ' your ability to make all kinds of endeavors down the\nroad," said E'
data: '.F. Hutton Group analyst Michael Lewis.\n    "They\'ve outlined the '
data: "fact that they're investing heavily\nin the future, which goes heavi"
data: 'ly into the international\narena," said Lewis. "...That does not pre'
data: 'clude acquisitions and\ndivestitures along the way," he said.\n    L'
data: 'ewis said if American Express reduced its exposure to the\nbrokerage'
data: ' business by selling part of shearson, its stock might\nbetter refle'
data: 'ct other assets, such as the travel related\nservices business.\n   '
data: ' "It could find its true water mark with a lesser exposure\nto broke'
data: 'rage. The value of the other components could command a\nhigher mult'
data: 'iple because they constitute a higher percentage of\nthe total opera'
data: 'ting earnings of the company," he said.\n     Lewis said Shearson co'
data: 'ntributed 316 mln in after-tax\noperating earnings, up from about 20'
data: '0 mln dlrs in 1985.\n   \n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

start tag: <dateline>

end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'U.S. M-1 money supply rose 2.1 billion\ndlrs to a seasonally adjuste'
data: 'd 736.7 billion dlrs in the\nFebruary 16 week, the Federal Reserve s'
data: "aid.\n    The previous week's M-1 level was revised to 734.6 billion"
data: '\ndlrs from 734.2 billion dlrs, while the four-week moving\naverage '
data: 'of M-1 rose to 735.0 billion dlrs from 733.5 billion.\n    Economist'
data: 's polled by Reuters said that M-1 should be\nanywhere from down four'
data: ' billion dlrs to up 2.3 billion dlrs.\nThe average forecast called f'
data: 'or a 300 mln dlr M-1 rise.\n Reuter\n\x03'

data: 'orresponding week a year\nago, the Association of American Railroads'
data: ' reported.\n    Grain mill product loadings in the week totalled 11,'
data: '382\ncars, down 1.8 pct from the previous week but 7.6 pct above the'

data: 'A study on grain certificates due out\nshortly from the Government A'
data: 'ccounting Office (GAO) could show\nthat certificates cost the govern'
data: 'ment 10 to 15 pct more than\ncash outlays, administration and indust'
data: 'ry sources said.\n    Analysis that the GAO has obtained from the Ag'
data: 'riculture\nDepartment and the Office of Management and Budget sugges'
data: 'ts\nthat certificates cost more than cash payments, a GAO official\n'
data: 'told Reuters.\n    GAO is preparing the certificate study at the spe'
data: 'cific\nrequest of Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.), former chairman of the\n'
data: 'senate agriculture committee.\n    The report, which will focus on t'
data: 'he cost of certificates\ncompared to cash, is scheduled to be releas'
data: 'ed in mid March.\n    The cost of certificates, said the GAO source,'
data: " depends on\nthe program's impact on the USDA loan program.\n    If "
data: 'GAO determines that certificates encourage more loan\nentries or cau'
data: 'se more loan forfeitures, then the net cost of\nthe program would go'
data: ' up. However, if it is determined that\ncertificates have caused the'
data: ' government grain stockpile to\ndecrease, the cost effect of certifi'
data: 'cates would be less.\n    GAO will not likely suggest whether the ce'
data: 'rtificates\nprogram should be slowed or expanded, the GAO official s'
data: 'aid.\n    But a negative report on certificates "will fuel the fire\n'
data: 'against certificates and weigh heavily on at least an increase\nin t'
data: 'he certificate program," an agricultural consultant said.\n    The O'
data: 'MB is said to be against any expansion of the program,\nwhile USDA r'
data: 'emains firmly committed to it.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

data: ' in three tranches that\ninclude floating rate and inverse floating '
data: 'rate CMOS.\n    The floating rate class amounts to 60 mln dlrs. It h'
data: 'as an\naverage life of 7.11 years and matures 2018. The CMOs have an'
data: '\ninitial coupon of 7.0375 pct, which will be reset 60 basis\npoints'
data: ' above LIBOR, said sole manager Thomson McKinnon.\n    The inverse f'
data: 'loater totals 4.8 mln dlrs. It has an average\nlife of 13.49 years a'
data: 'nd matures 2018. These CMOs were given an\ninitial coupon of 11-1/2 '
data: 'pct and priced at 104.40.\n    Subsequent rates on the inverse float'
data: 'er will equal 11-1/2\npct minus the product of three times (LIBOR mi'
data: 'nus 6-1/2 pct).\n    A Thomson officer explained that the coupon of '
data: 'the inverse\nfloating rate tranche would increase if LIBOR declined.'
data: ' "The\nyield floats opposite of LIBOR," he said.\n    The fixed-rate'

data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'OPEC MAY HAVE TO MEET TO FIRM PRICES - ANALYSTS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: "    BY TED D'AFFLISIO, Reuters"
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    NEW YORK, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'OPEC may be forced to meet before a\nscheduled June session to readd'
data: 'ress its production cutting\nagreement if the organization wants to '
data: 'halt the current slide\nin oil prices, oil industry analysts said.\n'
data: '    "The movement to higher oil prices was never to be as easy\nas O'
data: 'PEC thought. They may need an emergency meeting to sort out\nthe pro'
data: 'blems," said Daniel Yergin, director of Cambridge Energy\nResearch A'
data: 'ssociates, CERA.\n    Analysts and oil industry sources said the pro'
data: 'blem OPEC\nfaces is excess oil supply in world oil markets.\n    "OP'
data: "EC's problem is not a price problem but a production\nissue and must"
data: ' be addressed in that way," said Paul Mlotok, oil\nanalyst with Salo'
data: "mon Brothers Inc.\n    He said the market's earlier optimism about O"
data: 'PEC and its\nability to keep production under control have given way'
data: ' to a\npessimistic outlook that the organization must address soon i'
data: 'f\nit wishes to regain the initiative in oil prices.\n    But some o'
data: 'ther analysts were uncertain that even an\nemergency meeting would a'
data: 'ddress the problem of OPEC production\nabove the 15.8 mln bpd quota '
data: 'set last December.\n    "OPEC has to learn that in a buyers market y'
data: 'ou cannot have\ndeemed quotas, fixed prices and set differentials," '
data: 'said the\nregional manager for one of the major oil companies who sp'
data: 'oke\non condition that he not be named. "The market is now trying to'
data: '\nteach them that lesson again," he added.\n    David T. Mizrahi, ed'
data: 'itor of Mideast reports, expects OPEC\nto meet before June, although'
data: ' not immediately. However, he is\nnot optimistic that OPEC can addre'
data: 'ss its principal problems.\n    "They will not meet now as they try '
data: 'to take advantage of the\nwinter demand to sell their oil, but in la'
data: 'te March and April\nwhen demand slackens," Mizrahi said.\n    But Mi'
data: 'zrahi said that OPEC is unlikely to do anything more\nthan reiterate'
data: ' its agreement to keep output at 15.8 mln bpd."\n    Analysts said t'
data: "hat the next two months will be critical for\nOPEC's ability to hold"
data: ' together prices and output.\n    "OPEC must hold to its pact for th'
data: 'e next six to eight weeks\nsince buyers will come back into the mark'
data: 'et then," said Dillard\nSpriggs of Petroleum Analysis Ltd in New Yor'
data: "k.\n    But Bijan Moussavar-Rahmani of Harvard University's Energy\n"
data: 'and Environment Policy Center said that the demand for OPEC oil\nhas'
data: ' been rising through the first quarter and this may have\nprompted e'
data: 'xcesses in its production.\n    "Demand for their (OPEC) oil is clea'
data: 'rly above 15.8 mln bpd\nand is probably closer to 17 mln bpd or high'
data: 'er now so what we\nare seeing characterized as cheating is OPEC meet'
data: 'ing this\ndemand through current production," he told Reuters in a\n'
data: 'telephone interview.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    DALLAS, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Cenergy Corp reported fourth quarter net\nincome of 790,000 dlrs or '
data: 'seven cts per share on revenues of\n7.7 mln dlrs.\n    For the year '
data: 'it reported a net loss of 6.5 mln dlrs or 70\ncts per share as a res'
data: 'ult of writedowns in the book value of\nits oil and gas properties i'
data: 'n the first two quarters. Revenues\nwere 37 mln dlrs.\n    Following'
data: " the company's fiscal year ended March 31, 1985,\nit changed to a ca"
data: 'lender year end.\n    For the nine months ended Dec 31, 1985, it rep'
data: 'orted a loss\nof 63.4 mln dlrs or 6.54 dlrs per share on revenues of'
data: ' 47.6 mln\ndlrs, which it said was a result of noncash writedowns of'
data: ' oil\nand gas properties.\n    For the year ended March 31, 1985, Ce'
data: 'nergy reported net\nincome of 3,705,000 dlrs or 36 cts per share on '

data: 'the year fell to five\nmln barrels from 6.4 mln barrels of oil and t'

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: '<NOVA> WINS GOVERNMENT OKAY FOR HUSKY <HYO> DEAL'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    CALGARY, Alberta, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Nova, the Canadian company that\nowns 56 pct of Husky Oil Ltd, said '
data: 'it received government\napproval for a transaction under which <Unio'
data: 'n Faith Canada\nHolding Ltd> would buy a 43 pct stake in Husky.\n   '
data: ' Nova said the Minister of Regional and Industrial\nExpansion, Miche'
data: "l Cote, ruled that Union Faith's purchase of\nthe Husky stake would "
data: 'not result in Husky ceding control to a\nnon-Canadian company. It sa'
data: 'id this ruling was a key condition\nin completing the deal.\n    Uni'
data: 'on Faith is equally owned by <Hutchison Whampoa Ltd> and\n<Hong Kong'
data: ' Electric Holdings Ltd>.\n    Under the agreement with Union Faith, '
data: 'Husky will become a\nprivate company with Union Faith and Nova each '
data: 'holding 43 pct\nof its stock.\n    Nine pct of Husky would be owned '
data: 'by relatives of Li\nKa-Shing, chairman of Hutchison, and five pct by'

data: 'tral was in danger of failing.\n    Central had assets of 28.3 mln d'
data: 'lrs.\n    The FDIC said the deposits of the failed Farmers State\nBa'
data: 'nk, Hart, Tex., were assumed by Hale County State Bank,\nPlainview, '
data: 'Tex.\n    Farmers, with 9.6 mln dlrs in assets, was closed by Texas\n'
data: 'bank regulators.\n    The deposits of the failed First National Bank'
data: ' of Crosby,\nCrosby, Tex., with total assets of 8.2 mln dlrs, were a'
data: 'ssumed\nby Central Bancshares of the South Inc, Birmingham, Ala., af'
data: 'ter\nFirst National was closed by federal bank regulators, the FDIC\n'

start tag: <body>
data: 'Liquefied natural gas imports from\nAlgeria are unlikely to happen i'
data: 'n 1987 even though its\neconomically feasible, U.S. industry analyst'
data: 's sources said.\n    Youcef Yousfi, director-general of Sonatrach, t'
data: 'he Algerian\nstate petroleum agency, indicated in a television inter'
data: 'view in\nAlgiers that such imports would be made this year.\n    "Co'
data: 'ntract negotiations, filing with the U.S. government and\nthe time r'
data: 'equired to restart mothballed terminals will delay\nthe import until'
data: ' 1988/1989," Daniel Tulis, a natural gas\nanalyst with Shearson Lehm'
data: 'an Bros. said.\n    Sonatrach is currently negotiating with two of i'
data: 'ts former\ncustomers, Panhandle Eastern <PEL> and Distrigas, a subsi'
data: 'diary\nof Cabot Corp <CBT> to resume LNG export, company officials\n'
data: 'told Reuters. A third, El Paso Gas, a subsidiary of Burlington\nNort'
data: 'hern <BNI>, has expressed no interest.\n    Industry analysts said s'
data: 'ome imports of Algerian LNG were\nfeasible. "On a marginal cost basi'
data: 's, the companies that have\nmade capital investment to handle LNG im'
data: 'port can operate\nprofitably even in the current price environment,"'
data: '  Frank\nSpadine, an energy economist with Bankers Trust, said.\n   '
data: 'Analysts did not forsee a major impact from Algerian imports\non U.S'
data: '. prices which are currently soft but expected to trend\nhigher by t'
data: 'he end of 1987.\n    A decline in gas drilling and the time lag to b'
data: 'ring Gulf of\nMexico productions onstream will tighten gas supplies '
data: "and firm\nprices, Shearson's Tulis said.\n   In this context, Algeri"
data: 'an LNG import would be a source of\nsupplemental supply to U.S. dome'
data: 'stic production, he added.\n    Company sources currently in talks w'
data: 'ith Algeria agree,\nsaying that Algerian LNG would only serve to mee'
data: 't peak demand.\n    Company sources also said that any negotiations '
data: 'with\nAlgeria would emphasize looser arrangements which would relate'
data: '\nvolumes to market requirements and prices to U.S. spot market\nval'
data: 'ues.\n Reuter\n\x03'

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'U.S. FARM CREDIT RESCUE BILL SEEN BEFORE EASTER'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The chairman of the Senate Agriculture\nsubcommittee on credit said '
data: 'the panel will consider a farm\ncredit rescue package by Easter even'
data: ' if the system and its\nregulator do not ask for help by then.\n    '
data: '"We\'re going to have a bill to markup, I guarantee you,\nbefore the'
data: ' Easter recess," Sen. David Boren (D-Okla.) said.\n    Senate Majori'
data: 'ty leader Robert Byrd (D-W.Va.) wants\nrecommendations on farm credi'
data: 't presented by April 11, when\nCongress is scheduled to break for Ea'
data: 'ster, Boren said.\n    Boren urged the Farm Credit Administration (F'
data: "CA), the\nsystem's regulator, to quickly make a formal request for a"
data: 'id.\n    Under the 1985 Farm credit law passed by Congress, the FCA,'
data: '\nas regulator, is to certify when the system has exhausted all\nits'
data: ' capital and needs federal government help.\n    However, FCA chairm'
data: "an Frank Naylor said because much of the\nsystem's remaining capital"
data: ' is tied-up in legal action,\nhe could not technically certify a res'
data: 'cue is needed this year\nand perhaps not even in 1988. The other Rep'
data: 'ublican member of\nthe three-man FCA board, Marvin Duncan, agreed.\n'
data: '    But Boren urged that even if FCA cannot technically certify\naid'
data: ' is needed, it should request help informally.\n    "We all know we '
data: 'need a capital infusion," Boren said.\n    Boren and the FCA officia'
data: 'ls spoke at a hearing on the\nplight of the farm credit system. Also'
data: ' at the hearing, Brent\nBeesely, chief executive of the Farm Credit '
data: 'Council\nrepresenting the system, said that at the end of 1986 the\n'
data: 'system had only 1.5 billion dlrs in working capital remaining\nafter'
data: ' losses of 4.6 billion dlrs over the last two years.\n    While he d'
data: 'id not ask for government aid, Beesley indicated\nthe situation is s'
data: 'erious in some of the 12 system districts.\n    "A significant numbe'
data: 'r of banks and associations in the most\neconomically depressed area'
data: 's have and will continue to suffer\nextraordinary losses," Beesley s'
data: 'aid.\n    Jim Billington, Democratic member of the FCA board, said\n'
data: 'the troubles of the system have encouraged the flight of some\none b'
data: 'illion dlrs per month from the system as borrowers repay\nloans.\n  '
data: "  The system's total portfolio shrank to 54.6 billion dlrs by\nthe e"
data: 'nd of last year from 66.6 billion the previous year.\n    FCA board '
data: 'members said both borrowers and holders of bonds\nin the system need'
data: ' to be assured their money is safe. Naylor\nsuggested the need for a'
data: ' federal assurance to bondholders.\n    "The bondholders have no wor'
data: 'ry at this time," Billington\nsaid.\n    Naylor said several proposa'
data: 'ls for revamping the farm credit\nsystem are circulating. The propos'
data: 'als range from consolidation\nof the system into a centralized natio'
data: 'nal lender, to\nde-centralizing into semi-independent institutions.\n'
data: '    But He and the system spokesman Beesley were cautious about\npro'
data: 'posals for a secondary market on farm loans. Those\nproposals would '
data: 'package farm loans for resale to investors.\n    Naylor and Beesley '
data: 'said a secondary market set-up outside\nthe farm credit system would'
data: ' hurt the system. But Beesley said\na secondary market with the farm'
data: ' credit system as its agent\ncould be developed without Congressiona'
data: 'l legislation.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'
end tag: </reuters>

data: '  02-26 0091'
end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'REPORT COULD BE FINAL BLOW FOR REGAN'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Sue Baker, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "The Tower Commission's scathing   \ncomments on President Reagan's e"
data: 'mbattled chief of staff Donald\nRegan could signal the death knell t'
data: 'o his White House tenure,\nbut the impact of its strong criticism on'
data: ' two other top\nofficials was less clear.\n    Regan has come in for'
data: " tough criticism for his handling of\nReagan's worst political crisi"
data: 's since details of the covert\narms sales to Iran and diversion of p'
data: 'rofits to Nicaraguan\nrebels first emerged last November.\n    But c'
data: 'riticism of the roles of Secretary of State George\nShultz and Defen'
data: 'se Secretary Caspar Weinberger, who said they\nopposed the Iran arms'
data: ' initiative yet failed to end it, had been\nmuted until the release '
data: 'of the Tower Commission report.\n    "Their obligation was to give t'
data: 'he president their full\nsupport and continued advice with respect t'
data: 'o the program or, if\nthey could not in conscience do that, to so in'
data: 'form the\npresident," the report said after a three-month probe.\n  '
data: '  "Instead, they simply distanced themselves from the program.\nThey'
data: ' protected the record as to their own positions on this\nissue. They'
data: ' were not energetic in attempting to protect the\npresident from the'
data: ' consequences of his personal commitment to\nfreeing the hostages."\n'
data: '    The report saved some of its most scathing language for\nRegan, '
data: 'a gruff former Wall Street executive and close personal\nfriend of R'
data: 'eagan whose autocratic rule in the White House\nangered some top Rea'
data: "gan officials and, perhaps more\nimportantly, Reagan's wife Nancy.\n"
data: '    "More than almost any chief of staff of recent memory, he\nasser'
data: 'ted personal control over the White House staff and sought\nto exten'
data: 'd this control to the national security adviser," said\nthe report.\n'
data: "    Washington analysts said Regan's departure now appeared to\nbe o"
data: 'nly a matter of timing. Many expected the president to\nannounce it '
data: "when he addresses the nation on the Tower\nCommission's findings nex"
data: "t week.\n    With Regan's departure apparently imminent and Poindext"
data: 'er\nand other key figures in the scandal already out of office, the\n'
data: "report's tough criticism of Shultz and Weinberger could turn\nthe sp"
data: 'otlight on their future.\n    Senate Republican leader Robert Dole, '
data: 'a key Reagan ally,\ntold reporters the report disclosed "colossal bl'
data: 'unders" and said\npeople who had not served the president well shoul'
data: 'd step aside,\nbut he did not specify who should go.\n    "It would '
data: "seem to me that if you don't protect the\npresident, you don't serve"
data: ' the president well, then you should\nmove on," the Kansas Republica'
data: 'n, a likely presidential candidate\nnext year, said.\n    One Republ'
data: 'ican strategist said he believed Regan would not\nbe the only White '
data: 'House official to leave in the near future.\n   \n Reuter\n\x03'

data: 'IN-EXCE   02-26 0104'
end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'SWISS ECONOMY IN EXCELLENT CONDITION, OECD SAYS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    PARIS, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "Switzerland's economy, combining low\nunemployment, financial stabil"
data: 'ity and a large external payments\nsurplus, is in excellent conditio'
data: 'n and faces a satisfactory\nfuture, the Organisation for Economic Co'
data: 'operation and\nDevelopment, OECD, said.\n    This reflected the succ'
data: 'ess of stable and relatively tight\nfiscal and monetary policies fol'
data: 'lowed by the government, it\nsaid.\n    The OECD, in its annual repo'
data: 'rt on Switzerland, picked out\nsome signs of a slowdown in activity '
data: 'and a slight pick-up in\ninflation this year, but said these gave no'
data: ' cause for concern.\n    The study forecast a decline in Gross Domes'
data: 'tic Product\ngrowth to 1.75 pct this year from an estimated two pct '
data: 'in 1986\nand a small rise in consumer price inflation to 1.25 pct af'
data: "ter\nlast year's sharp fall to 0.75 pct from 3.6 pct in 1985.\n    B"
data: 'ut it said job creation should continue to absorb a modest\nincrease'
data: ' in the workforce, leaving the unemployment rate\nunchanged at aroun'
data: 'd one pct, the lowest in the 24-industrial\nnation OECD area.\n    A'
data: 'ssuming an average exchange rate of 1.71 Swiss francs to\nthe dollar'
data: ' this year, against 1.69 in the second half of 1986,\nthe report for'
data: 'ecast a 2.75 pct rise in exports and a 3.5 pct\nrise in imports this'
data: ' year after rises of 3.25 pct and 6.5 pct\nrespectively in 1986.\n  '
data: '  The faster growth of imports compared with exports this\nyear and '
data: 'last, reflecting buoyant private consumption, meant\nthat the contri'
data: 'bution of the foreign payments balance to GDP\nwould shrink in both '
data: 'years.\n    But "given Switzerland\'s large external surplus, there\n'
data: 'should be no concern if domestic demand grows faster than\nGDP...Whi'
data: 'ch, if only in a small way, would contribute to\nimproving internati'
data: 'onal balances," the OECD said.\n    Real private consumption appeare'
data: 'd to have been unusually\nbuoyant last year, with a 3.25 pct growth '
data: 'rate, after several\nyears of relative weakness, it noted.\n    In 1'
data: '987 private consumption was expected to slow somewhat\nto a 2.25 pct'
data: ' growth rate, but should still outstrip overall\nGDP, it added.\n   '
data: ' The outlook for investment in plant and machinery remained\nbright '
data: 'into 1987, and with capacity use at near record levels\nlast year th'
data: 'ere was scope for rationalisation and modernisation\nin both the ind'
data: 'ustry and service sectors, it said.\n    As a consequence, growth in'
data: ' machinery and equipment\ninvestment is likely to decelerate only sl'
data: 'ightly this year\nafter vigorous growth in 1986.\n    But the report'
data: ' raised a questionmark over the prospects for\ntourism and the banki'
data: 'ng industry, two major service sector\nearners of foreign exchange.\n'
data: '    The long-term appreciation of the Swiss Franc, and the\naccelera'
data: 'ting deregulation of foreign banking markets, could\nlead to a loss '
data: 'of international market share for both, it said.\n    Particularly f'
data: 'or the banks, "recent developments in\ninternational financial marke'
data: 'ts give rise to the question\nwhether the Swiss financial system, wh'
data: 'ich has shown substantial\nflexibility in the past, is adapting itse'
data: 'lf at the speed\nrequired ... To preserve its competitive position,"'
data: ' it said.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

end tag: </reuters>

start tag: <title>
data: 'U.S. WHEAT BONUS TO SOVIET CALLED DORMANT'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The U.S. Agriculture Department is not\nactively considering offerin'
data: 'g subsidized wheat to the Soviet\nUnion under the export enhancement'
data: ' program (EEP), senior USDA\nofficials said.\n    However, grain tra'
data: 'de analysts said the proposal has not\nbeen ruled out and that an of'
data: 'fer might be made, though not in\nthe very near future.\n    "The gr'
data: 'ain companies are trying to get this fired up again,"\nan aide to Ag'
data: 'riculture Secretary Richard Lyng said. "But there\njust isn\'t much '
data: 'talk about it, informally or formally."\n    Most analysts interview'
data: 'ed by Reuters were more confident\nthan USDA officials that bonus wh'
data: 'eat would be offered to the\nSoviets, even though U.S. officials did'
data: ' not make such an offer\nwhen they held grain talks with Soviet coun'
data: 'terparts earlier\nthis week.\n    But administration and private sou'
data: 'rces agreed that if the\nReagan administration did decide to offer s'
data: 'ubsidized wheat to\nMoscow, it could take several months.\n    "I ju'
data: "st don't see any proposal like that sailing through any\ninteragency"
data: ' process," the aide to Lyng said.\n    "An export enhancement offer '
data: 'is not consummated overnight,"\nsaid one former USDA official, who n'
data: 'oted that the\nadministration took three months to decide in favor o'
data: 'f selling\nChina wheat under the subsidy program.\n    An official r'
data: 'epresenting a large grain trade company said\ndeliberations within U'
data: 'SDA might be nudged along by members of\nCongress, a number of whom '
data: 'urged USDA this week to make a wheat\nsubsidy offer to the Soviets.\n'
data: "    But Lyng's aide said that during a day-long visit to\nCapitol Hi"
data: 'll yesterday, House members did not press the\nsecretary on the subs'
data: "idy question a single time.\n    The administration's interagency tr"
data: 'ade policy review group,\ncomprised of subcabinet-level officials, h'
data: 'as not been asked to\nclear a request to offer Moscow wheat under th'
data: "e EEP, officials\nat the U.S. Trade Representative's Office said.\n "
data: '   In their talks this week, the two sides discussed the\nadministra'
data: "tion's previous EEP offer but did not talk about any\nnew initiative"
data: '. One USDA official who took part in the\nconsultations this week de'
data: 'scribed them as an exchange of "calm,\nbasic, factual economics."\n '
data: '   Another USDA official said there was "not even an informal\nsugge'
data: 'stion or hint" that the Soviets would live up to their\npledge to bu'
data: 'y four mln tonnes of wheat this year if they were\ngranted more favo'
data: 'rable terms.\n    USDA and private sources agreed that consideration'
data: ' of an\nEEP initiative by interagency review groups likely would be\n'
data: 'delayed because of disarray within the White House stemming\nfrom th'
data: 'e Iran arms affair.\n Reuter\n\x03'

end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The U.S. Treasury said it was willing\nto participate with several o'
data: 'ther industrial countries in\nproviding a 500 mln-dlr short-term bri'
data: 'dge loan to Argentina.\n    The Treasury announcecement did not name'
data: ' the other\ncountries nor the amount of financing the United States '
data: 'was\nwilling to supply.\n    Argentina announced a wage and price fr'
data: 'eeze on Wednesday\nnight and is negotiating with New York bankers fo'
data: 'r about 2.15\nbillion dlrs in new loans and other financing.\n    "O'
data: 'ur willingness to participate in this multilateral\nshort-term finan'
data: "cing indicates our support for Argentina's\neconomic program to achi"
data: 'eve sustainable growth and a viable\nbalance of payments position," '
data: 'the Treassury statement said.\n    In announcing a four-month wage a'
data: 'nd price freeze, Argentine\nofficials said the country needed "a mor'
data: 'e serene climate" to\ncarry out structural changes in the economy.\n'
data: '    But Argentina did not suspend interest payments on its\nforeign '
data: 'debts, as neighboring Brazil did last week.\n    The Treasury said t'
data: 'he U.S. share of bridge financing for\nArgentina would come from its'
data: ' Exchange Stabilization Fund.\n    The one-page statement noted the '
data: "International Monetary\nFund expressed confidence in Argentina's eco"
data: 'nomic policies and\nprospects by approving a new stand-by financing '
data: 'arrangement for\nit on February 18.\n    "Argentina is expected to q'
data: 'ualify for IMF\nbalance-of-payments financing which would enable Arg'
data: 'entina to\nrepay a multilateral bridge loan and support the implemen'
data: 'tation\nof its economic program," the statement said.\n    The lates'
data: 't Argentine action marked the second time in less\nthan two years it'
data: 's government has used a wage and price freeze\nto restrain inflation'
data: '.\n    The debt talks in New York are being headed by Argentine\nFin'
data: 'ance Minister Mario Brodersohn and are expected to last for\nseveral'
data: ' days.\n    Along with new financing, Argentina reportedly wants low'
data: 'er\ninterest rates on an existing total 53 billion dlrs in foreign\n'
data: "debt and elimination of foreign banks' control over how some of\nthe"
data: ' money is loaned in Argentina.\n Reuter\n\x03'

data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'FALLING SOYBEAN CRUSH RATIOS CUT OUTPUT'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    by John Morrison, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    CHICAGO, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The sharp decline in soybean crush ratios\nseen in the last few week'
data: 's, accelerating in recent days, has\npushed margins below the cost o'
data: 'f production at most soybean\nprocessing plants and prompted many to'
data: ' cut output of soybean\nmeal and oil.\n    The weekly U.S. soybean c'
data: 'rush rate was reported by the\nNational Soybean Processors Associati'
data: 'on this afternoon at 21.78\nmln bushels, down from the 22 mln bushel'
data: ' plus rate seen over\nthe past two months when crush margins surged '
data: 'to the best\nlevels seen in over a year.\n    Active soymeal export '
data: 'loadings at the Gulf had pushed\nsoybean futures and premiums higher'
data: ', prompting a pick-up in the\nweekly crush number.\n    However, muc'
data: 'h of that export demand seems to have been met,\nwith most foreign m'
data: 'eal users now waiting for the expected surge\nin shipments of new cr'
data: 'op South American soymeal over the next\nfew months.\n    U.S. proce'
data: 'ssors are now finding domestic livestock feed\ndemand is very light '
data: 'for this time of year due to the milder\nthan normal winter, so they'
data: ' steadily dropped offering prices in\nan attempt to find buying inte'
data: 'rest, soyproduct dealers said.\n    Soybean meal futures have also s'
data: 'teadily declined in recent\nweeks, setting a new contract low of 139'
data: '.70 dlrs per ton in the\nnearby March contract today.\n    "Many spe'
data: 'culators down here bought March soymeal and sold\nMay, looking for n'
data: 'o deliveries (on first notice day tomorrow,\nwhich would cause March'
data: ' to gain on deferreds)," one CBT crush\ntrader said.\n    "But they\''
data: 've been bailing out this week because the March\nhas been acting lik'
data: 'e there will be a lot delivered, if not\ntomorrow, then later in the'
data: ' month," he added.\n    As a result of the weakness in soymeal, the '
data: 'March crush\nratio (The value of soyproducts less the cost of the so'
data: 'ybeans)\nfell from the mid 30s earlier this month to 22.6 cents per\n'
data: 'bushel today, dropping over five cents in just the last two\ndays.\n'
data: '    The May crush ended today just over 17 cents, so no\nprocessors '
data: 'will want to lock in a ratio at that unprofitable\nlevel, the trader'
data: ' said. Hopefully, they will now start to cut\nback production to get'
data: ' supplies in line with demand, he added.\n    With futures down, pro'
data: 'cessors are finding they must bid\npremiums for cash soybeans, furth'
data: 'er reducing crush margins.\n    A central Illinois processor is only'
data: ' making about 30 cents\nfor every bushel of soybeans crushed at curr'
data: 'ent prices, down\nsharply from levels just seen just a few weeks ago'
data: ' and below\nthe average cost of production, cash dealers said.\n    '
data: 'Most soybean processing plants are still in operation, with\nlittle '
data: 'talk of taking temporary down-time, so far. But\nprocessors will sta'
data: 'rt halting production in the next few weeks\nit they continue to fac'
data: 'e unprofitable margins, they added.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'FED DATA SUGGEST STABLE U.S. MONETARY POLICY'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    by Jeremy Solomons, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    NEW YORK, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Latest Federal Reserve data suggest that\nthe central bank voted to '
data: 'maintain the existing degree of\npressure on banking reserves at its'
data: ' regular policy-making\nmeeting two weeks ago, money market economis'
data: 'ts said.\n    "The numbers were a little disappointing, but I think '
data: 'we\ncan take Mr Volcker at his word when he said that nothing had\nc'
data: 'hanged," said Bob Bannon of Security Pacific National Bank.\n    Fed'
data: ' Chairman Paul Volcker told a Congressional committee\nlast Thursday'
data: ' that the Fed\'s policy "has been unchanged up to\ntoday."\n    Alth'
data: "ough Volcker's statement last Thursday allayed most\nfears that the "
data: 'Fed had marginally tightened its grip on\nreserves to help an ailing'
data: ' dollar, many economists still wanted\nconfirmation of a steady poli'
data: "cy in today's data, which covered\nthe two-week bank statement perio"
data: 'd ended yesterday.\n    This need for additional reassurance was mad'
data: "e all the more\nacute by the Fed's decision yesterday to drain reser"
data: 'ves from\nthe banking system by arranging overnight matched sale-pur'
data: 'chase\nagreements for the first time since April of last year,\necon'
data: "omists added.\n    Today's data showed that the draining action was "
data: 'for a\nfairly large 3.9 billion dlrs, economists said.\n    "The one'
data: ' thing that caught my eye were the relatively\nsizeable matched sale'
data: 's on Wednesday," said Dana Johnson of\nFirst National Bank of Chicag'
data: 'o. "But there was a clearly\njustified need for them. There was noth'
data: 'ing ominous."\n    "The Fed couldn\'t have waited until the start of'
data: ' the new\nstatement period today. If it had, it would have missed it'
data: 's\n(reserve) projections," added Security Pacific\'s Bannon.\n    A '
data: 'Fed spokesman told reporters that there were no large\nsingle-day ne'
data: 't miss in reserve projections in the latest week.\n    Economists si'
data: 'milarly shrugged off slightly higher-than-\nexpected adjusted bank b'
data: "orrowings from the Fed's discount\nwindow, which averaged 310 mln dl"
data: "rs a day in the latest week,\ncompared with many economists' forecas"
data: 'ts of about 200 mln.\n    For the two-week bank statement period as '
data: 'a whole, the\ndaily borrowing average more than doubled to 381 mln d'
data: 'lrs from\n160 in the prior period.\n    "There were wire problems at'
data: ' two large banks on Tuesday and\nWednesday, so I am not too bothered'
data: ' about the borrowings," said\nScott Winningham of J.S. Winningham an'
data: 'd Co. The Wednesday\naverage rose to 946 mln dlrs from 148 mln a wee'
data: 'k earlier.\n    Lending further support to the stable policy view wa'
data: 's a\nrelatively steady federal funds rate of about six pct in the\nl'
data: 'atest week and persistently high levels of excess reserves in\nthe b'
data: 'anking system, economists said.\n    "For the time being, the Fed is'
data: ' following a neutral path,\nwith fed funds at about six to 6-1/8 pct'
data: '," said Darwin Beck of\nFirst Boston Corp. "I expect it to continue '
data: 'in that vein."\n    "Excess reserves fell but they are still over a '
data: 'billion\ndlrs," added First Chicago\'s Johnson. Banks\' excess reser'
data: 'ves\naveraged 1.03 billion dlrs a day in the latest statement\nperio'
data: 'd, down from 1.50 billion in the previous one.\n    After the Fed de'
data: 'clined to assign a 1987 target growth range\nto the wayward M-1 mone'
data: 'y supply measure last week, little\nattention was paid to a steeper-'
data: 'than-anticipated 2.1 billion\ndlr jump in the week ended February 16'
data: '.\n    Looking ahead, economists said the Fed will have to tread a\n'
data: "fine line between the dollar's progress in the international\ncurren"
data: 'cy markets and the development of the domestic economy.\n    "The ma'
data: 'rket has perhaps exaggerated the dollar\'s effect on\nFed policy," s'
data: 'aid First Chicago\'s Johnson. "Of course, it will\ntake the dollar i'
data: 'nto account in future policy decisions but if\nthe economy is weak, '
data: 'it won\'t pull back from easing."\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The New York Stock Exchange said it will\nbegin a review of regulati'
data: 'on in the securities industry to\ndetermine what changes may be need'
data: 'ed to maintain the integrity\nof the market and protect investors in'
data: ' coming years.\n    The Exchange said the study is needed because of'
data: ' the rapid\nchanges taking place in the securities industry. Among t'
data: 'he\nfactors it cited were the increase in trading volume, the\nproli'
data: 'feration of new trading instruments and the rise of\ncomputerized tr'
data: 'ading techniques.\n    The Exchange did not mention, however, the in'
data: 'sider trading\nscandal that has caught several top Wall Street execu'
data: 'tives.\n    The NYSE said its study will be chaired by Richard R.\nS'
data: 'hinn, executive vice chairman of the Exchange and former\nchairman a'
data: 'nd chief executive officer of <Metropolitan Life\nInsurance Co.>\n  '
data: '  Other members of the study committee include Charles F.\nBarbar, f'
data: 'ormer chairman of Arsarco Inc <AR>, Roger Birk,\nchairman emeritus o'
data: 'f Merrill Lynch and Co <MER> and Irwin\nGuttag, chairman of the NYSE'
data: " special surveillance committee.\n    The committee's report should "
data: 'be completed by the end of\nthe year, the Exchange said.\n Reuter\n\x03'

start tag: <title>
data: 'JAPAN TO TRY TO OPEN MARKET TO U.S. CAR PARTS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Japan has pledged to try to increase\nits purchase of U.S. car parts'
data: ' and also to exchange data to\nmonitor the purchases, the Commerce D'
data: 'epartment said.\n    U.S. negotiators opened talks last August with '
data: 'Japanese\nofficials to try to force open the Japanese market to\nAme'
data: 'rican-made parts in an effort to redress an estimated five\nbillion '
data: 'dlr deficit in car parts trade.\n    Japan had agreed to try to incr'
data: 'ease purchases of U.S.-made\nparts by Japanese car makers and to beg'
data: 'in long term contracts\nfor parts purchases, a Commerce department o'
data: 'fficial said.\n    He added that the agreement also said Japan agree'
data: 'd to try\nto devise a way to collect purchasing information in order'
data: ' to\nmonitor progress in stepping up Japanese orders.\n    The Comme'
data: 'rce Department said in a statement last year that\n"statistics suppo'
data: 'rt the perception in the United States that\nAmerican auto parts sup'
data: "pliers are not welcome in the inner\ncircles of Japan's auto compani"
data: 'es and their traditional\nsuppliers."\n    It estimated that while J'
data: "apan's car firms sold almost five\nbillion dlrs worth of parts in th"
data: 'e United States in 1985, U.S.\nfirms sold only one per cent of Japan'
data: "'s 55 billion dlr market.\n reuter\n\x03"
