data: '   02-26 0098'
end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'FRANCE FACES PRESSUE TO CHANGE POLICIES'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Brian Childs, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    PARIS, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "France's right wing government is facing\ngrowing pressure to modify"
data: ' its economic policies after revising\ndown its 1987 growth targets '
data: 'and revising up its inflation\nforecasts for this year.\n    Moving '
data: 'reluctantly into line with most private sector\nforecasts the govern'
data: 'ment yesterday raised its 1987 inflation\nestimate a half percentage'
data: ' point to 2.5 per cent and cut its\neconomic growth estimate to betw'
data: 'een two and 2.8 per cent from a\n2.8 per cent target written into th'
data: 'e annual budget last\nseptember.\n    Finance Minister Edouard Balla'
data: 'dur said the revised figures\nwould not push the government off its '
data: 'chosen mix of price\nderegulation, budget-cutting rigour and pay res'
data: 'traint.\n    But Trade Union leaders served immediate notice they wo'
data: 'uld\npush to protect the purchasing power of their members, raising\n'
data: 'the spectre of a vicious spiral of wage and price rises.\n    And ba'
data: 'nk economists contacted by Reuters said they believed\nPrime Ministe'
data: 'r Jacques Chirac could be forced by slow growth\nand rising unemploy'
data: 'ment to reflate the economy later this year,\nperhaps in the autumn,'
data: ' to boost his prospects in Presidential\nelections due by April 1988'
data: '.\n    "The outlook is more worrying than it was a few weeks ago,"\n'
data: 'said Societe Generale economist Alain Marais. "We have the\nimpressi'
data: 'on it may be difficult to get even two per cent growth\nthis year."\n'
data: '    "The big question is whether the government\'s policy of wage\nm'
data: 'oderation will be maintained," he added.\n    The government has set'
data: ' public sector wage rises at aboout\n1.7 per cent this year, with a '
data: 'three per cent ceiling for rises\njustified by increased productivit'
data: 'y.\n    But the head of the socialist CFDT union federation, Edmond\n'
data: 'Maire, meeting with Chirac today, renewed union demands already\nrej'
data: 'ected by the government for indexation clauses to be built\ninto fut'
data: 'ure pay contracts to safeguard workers against higher\nprices.\n    '
data: 'Calling the government\'s policies "unbalanced and unjust," he\nalso'
data: ' demanded investment incentives to boost employment. He\nannounced a'
data: 'fter his meeting that Chirac had told him the\ngovernment would spen'
data: 'd two billion francs on a series of\nmeasures to boost employment an'
data: 'd training\n    Andre Bergeron, a widely respected leader of the mod'
data: 'erate\nForce Ouvriere labour group, put similar demands to Chirac\ne'
data: 'arlier in the week while the Communist-led CGT, the largest of\nFran'
data: "ce's unions, declared the defence of its members earnings\nits top p"
data: 'riority.\n    But with unemployment nearing 11 per cent last month, '
data: 'and\nstill rising, government supporters and some economic analysts\n'
data: 'said they were confident Chirac could resist union pay demands.\n   '
data: ' "Salary indexation was ended by the previous Socialist\ngovernment '
data: 'and I dont think this administration is going to\nreverse that," com'
data: 'mented Michel Develle, economist at\nrecently-privatised Banque Pari'
data: 'bas.\n    Damaging transport and electricity strikes over Christmas\n'
data: 'and the New Year, partly blamed by the government for higher\ninflat'
data: 'ion, had undermined the unions power and popularity, he\nsaid.\n    '
data: 'Develle said Paribas expected inflation to rise even more\nthan the '
data: 'governments revised forecast, perhaps to 2.6 or 2.7\nper cent this y'
data: 'ear against last years 2.1 per cent.\n    "But that would still be a'
data: 'n exceptional achievement\nconsidering that for the first time since'
data: ' the Second World War\nall french prices have been freed," he commen'
data: 'ted.\n    Finance Ministry officials said that the governments\nabol'
data: 'ition of price and rent controls last year was responsible\nfor near'
data: 'ly a quarter of a 0.9 per cent surge in January living\ncosts.\n    '
data: 'But they claimed it was a once-off phenomenon that should\nhave no k'
data: 'nock-on impact on the rest of the year.\n    Both Marais and Develle'
data: ' said they agreed with that, so long\nas the government kept wages u'
data: 'nder control.\n    Prices could rise 1.5 per cent in the first three'
data: ' months of\n1987 and two per cent in the first half year, fractional'
data: 'ly more\nthan forecast this week by the National Statistics Institut'
data: 'e,\nINSEE,  Marais said. But the second half year should be better,\n'
data: 'he added.\n    Ironically, one side effect of higher inflation could'
data: ' be to\nhelp the government achieve its aim of cutting the state bud'
data: 'get\ndeficit, several analysts said.\n    So long as public sector w'
data: 'ages are held down, higher Value\nAdded Tax receipts resulting from '
data: 'rising prices should offset a\nloss in revenues that otherwise would'
data: ' result from slower than\nexpected growth, they said.\n   \n Reuter\n'
data: '\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "Japan's unadjusted consumer price index\n(base 1985) fell 0.4 pct to"
data: " 99.7 in January from the previous\nmonth, the government's Manageme"
data: 'nt and Coodination Agency said.\n    The fall compares with a declin'
data: 'e of 0.2 pct in December.\n    The January index compared with a yea'
data: 'r earlier was down 1.1\npct, the first drop larger than 1.0 pct sinc'
data: 'e it fell 1.3 pct\nin September 1958.\n    Food costs rose in Januar'
data: 'y from December but prices fell\nfor clothing, footwear and utilitie'
data: 's, causing the overall\ndecline for the month.\n    Housing, medical'
data: ' and educations costs increased in January\ncompared with a year ear'
data: 'lier but the cost of utilities,\ngasoline and vegetables fell.\n    '
data: 'The unadjusted consumer price index for the Tokyo area\n(base 1985) '
data: 'was down 0.1 pct in mid-February from a month\nearlier at 100.2, ref'
data: 'lecting lower prices for food, clothing\nand footwear. Compared with'
data: ' a year earlier, the index was down\n0.7 pct due to lower vegetable,'
data: ' fuel oil and utility costs.\n REUTER\n\x03'

end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla, Feb 26 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'An unmanned Delta rocket\ncarrying a 57 mln dlr weather observation '
data: 'satellite blasted off\nhere today in the first U.S. Space launch of '
data: 'the year.\n    The 116-foot rocket lifted off at 1805 local time (23'
data: '05\nGMT) and placed in orbit a 1,850 pound Geostationary\nOperationa'
data: 'l Environmental Satellite (GOES) to replace an\nidentical one that w'
data: 'as destroyed last May when a Delta rocket\nexploded after liftoff.\n'
data: '    Weather forecasters have had only a single satellite to\ncover t'
data: 'he entire U.S. Since another GOES failed in orbit in\nAugust 1984.\n'
data: '    "We\'ll have both our weather eyes open again," said Thomas\nPyk'
data: 'e, a spokesman for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric\nAdministrat'
data: 'ion, which owns and operates the satellite.\n    The smooth launchin'
data: 'g came after two delays in as many days.\nThe first was caused by a '
data: 'fuel leak and the second by powerful\ncrosswinds.\n    The Delta was'
data: ' the first of six rockets scheduled for launch\nby the National Aero'
data: 'nautics and Space Administration this year.\nThe launch marked the t'
data: 'hird straight success for the space\nprogram which was battered by a'
data: ' series of failures in 1986,\nincluding the loss of the Challenger s'
data: 'huttle.\n REUTER\n\x03'

data: 'IGHT--   02-26 0110'
end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'ECONOMIC SPOTLIGHT - JAPAN EYEING FOREIGN STOCKS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Jeff Stearns, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    TOKYO, Feb 27 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Japanese life insurers, trust banks and\ncorporations, largely respo'
data: 'nsible for vitalising the U.S. Bond\nmarket in recent years, are now'
data: ' eyeing stockmarkets in the\nU.S., Britain, France and Hong Kong, fu'
data: 'nd managers said.\n    After concentrating on U.S. Treasury bonds fo'
data: 'r years,\nJapanese institutions now see a risk in relying too much o'
data: "n\nsimilar types of investments, they said.\n    Japan's net buying "
data: 'in overseas stockmarkets this year may\ndouble or triple to 15-20 bi'
data: 'llion dlrs from seven billion in\n1986, Shigeki Matsumoto of Nikko S'
data: "ecurities Co Ltd, said.\n    Matsumoto, who manages Nikko's investme"
data: 'nt research and\nstrategy, said there is evidence Japanese investors'
data: ' began\npoking around in foreign stockmarkets around July last year,'
data: '\nbut few made firm commitments until December when net purchases\ns'
data: 'uddenly grew to 1.5 billion dlrs from around 500 mln in each\nof the'
data: ' previous five months.\n    Net buying in 1985 totalled only 995 mln'
data: ' dlrs, he added.\n    This sudden penchent for overseas stocks is li'
data: 'kely to draw\nthe widest smiles from Wall Street because about 70 to'
data: ' 80 pct\nof funds will be invested in the U.S. Markets, Matsumoto sa'
data: 'id.\n    "The trend has been to head toward the U.S. Market, first\n'
data: 'because of its size and next because it has been successful\nover th'
data: 'e last couple of years," said Eugene Atkinson, managing\ndirector of'
data: " Goldman Sachs International Corp.\n    Wall Street's massive turnov"
data: 'er offers good liquidity,\nenabling institutions to easily move larg'
data: 'e volumes of money in\nand out of shares with the minimum of risk, h'
data: 'e added.\n    However, few see holdings in U.S. Treasuries dwindling'
data: '.\nThey will remain a Japanese mainstay, fund managers said.\n    In'
data: 'stitutions, particularly life insurance companies which\nconcentrate'
data: ' on income rather than capital gains to cover\npayouts to policy hol'
data: 'ders, are unlikely to sell their U.S.\nTreasuries, but will put in l'
data: 'ess money, said Shinichi Kobuse,\nmanager of Yamaichi Securities Co '
data: "Ltd's international fixed\nincome activities.\n    There has been so"
data: 'me selling of U.S. Bonds by short-term\ninvestors, but the selling i'
data: 's unlikely to amount to a\nsignificant chunk of Japanese bond holdin'
data: 'gs because the\nliquidity of the U.S. Bond market remains attractive'
data: ', he added.\n    Kobuse said investment managers are bullish on the '
data: 'U.S.\nEquity markets despite predictions by economists the U.S.\nEco'
data: 'nomy will remain sluggish over the next couple of months.\n    Inter'
data: 'est in Wall Street has been spurred by recent reports\nof significan'
data: 't growth in earnings by major U.S. Corporations,\nhe added.\n    Yut'
data: 'aka Hashimoto general manager of Nippon Life Insurance\nCo told an e'
data: 'conomic conference that insurance companies, which\nare responsible '
data: 'for 26 pct of Japanese funds in foreign\nsecurities, hold a lopsided'
data: ' proportion of U.S. Treasuries and\nintend to diversify into other i'
data: 'nstruments and currencies.\n    Insurance companies have put the dom'
data: 'inant portion of their\nfunds into the U.S., But will now invest in '
data: 'Britain, West\nGermany, France and other countries, Hashimoto said.\n'
data: '    Lower interest rates worldwide make the returns on stocks\nrelat'
data: 'ively high in comparison with bonds and in light of the\nstrength in'
data: ' the yen, the growth in stock values is expected to\noffset currency'
data: ' risks, he added.\n    One trust bank official said his bank aims fo'
data: 'r a 10 pct\nannual return on overseas investments but the recent dec'
data: 'line in\nU.S. 30-year bond yields has caused a rethink in pension fu'
data: 'nd\ninvestment stategies.\n    The bank is looking more at U.S. Equi'
data: 'ties and European\nbonds, he said.\n    Japanese investments in Brit'
data: 'ish equities have already\nturned active and the pace is likely to i'
data: 'ncrease, said Andrew\nSheaf, general manager of international equity'
data: ' activities at\nCounty Securities Japan.\n    "Last week was the bus'
data: 'iest week we had," he said.\n    Investments are being spurred by th'
data: 'e growth in profits of\nBritish companies and the recent deregulatio'
data: 'n of government\ncontrolled firms, fund managers said.\n    Deregula'
data: 'tion in France is also attracting Japanese\ninterest, but stock inve'
data: 'stments there will be inhibited by\nworries about the French franc, '
data: 'they said.\n    Investments in Hong Kong will be mostly short-term a'
data: "nd\nspeculative due to uncertainty about the colony's long-term\npol"
data: 'itical stability, they added.\n    Japanese investors are cautious a'
data: 'bout West Germany,\nparticularly as German firms, like their Japanes'
data: 'e counterparts,\nare concerned about the recent dollar fall.\n    Au'
data: 'stralia also poses some risks due to currency values,\nthey added.\n'
data: ' REUTER\n\x03'

start tag: <title>
data: 'JAPAN EXPECTED TO CUT BASE RATE FOR STATE BODIES'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    TOKYO, Feb 27 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Japan is expected to cut the base lending\nrate for state financial '
data: 'institutions to 5.5 pct from 6.2 as\npart of the recent pact by majo'
data: 'r industrial nations in Paris,\nFinance Ministry sources said.\n    '
data: 'They said the cut is based on a revision of the Trust Fund\nBureau L'
data: 'aw, which should be approved by parliament on March 3,\nabolishing t'
data: 'he 6.05 pct minimum interest rate on deposits with\nthe bureau.\n   '
data: ' The bureau channels funds to government financial\ninstitutions for'
data: ' public works and other official uses, they\nsaid.\n    The base len'
data: 'ding rate for state bodies such as the Japan\nDevelopment Bank, Peop'
data: "le's Finance Corp and the finance\ncorporations of local public ente"
data: 'rprises usually moves in\ntandem with long-term prime rates, the sou'
data: 'rces said.\n    However, it was impossible for them to follow the la'
data: 'st cut,\nto 5.8 pct from 6.2 pct on January 28, because the Trust Fu'
data: 'nd\nBureau rate was legally set at 6.05 pct.\n    The ministry will '
data: 'abolish the minimum rate and introduce a\nmarket-related one to reso'
data: 'lve the problem and stimulate the\ndomestic economy, they said.\n   '
data: ' On Tuesday, the ministry allowed long-term bankers to cut\ntheir pr'
data: 'ime to a record low of 5.5 pct, effective February 28.\nThe move sug'
data: 'gested it had reached agreement with depositors\nusing the bureau, t'
data: 'he postal savings system of the Posts and\nTelecommunications Minist'
data: 'ry and the Japan welfare annuity of\nthe Ministry of Health and Welf'
data: 'are, the sources said.\n    These ministries are trying to determine'
data: " which market rates\nshould be considered when setting the bureau's "
data: 'deposit rate,\nthe ministry sources said.\n    Coupon rates on new 1'
data: '0-year government bonds, minus 0.1\npercentage points, is the likeli'
data: 'est choice, they added.\n REUTER\n\x03'

data: '    CANBERRA, Feb 27 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Domestic demand is now expected to make\nno contribution to Australi'
data: 'an economic growth in fiscal\n1986/87, ending June 30, while net exp'
data: 'orts will account for all\nof the overall increase, Treasurer Paul K'
data: 'eating said here.\n    However, he did not say in his speech to the '
data: 'Economic\nPlanning Advisory Council (EPAC) if the forecast 2.25 pct '
data: 'rise\nin gross domestic product (gdp) had been revised.\n    But Kea'
data: 'ting said domestic demand could fall slightly this\nfinancial year a'
data: 'nd net export growth will provide the total\nsource of gdp growth.\n'
data: '    The August budget had forecast domestic demand would\ncontribute'
data: ' 0.75 percentage points to non-farm gdp growth of 2.5\npct while net'
data: ' exports would account for 1.75 points.\n    Keating said the overal'
data: 'l impact of the changed economic\nparameters is welcome as it appear'
data: 's to have contributed to a\nslightly more rapid correction in the cu'
data: 'rrent account deficit\nthan first anticipated.\n    "The government '
data: 'initially forecast a current account deficit\nfor 1986/87 of 14.75 b'
data: 'illion -- our present expectation is that\nthe result will be somewh'
data: 'at lower, around 14 billion," he said.\n    Partial indicators relea'
data: 'sed since the last meeting of EPAC\nin December indicate that the 19'
data: '86/87 budget strategy is\nbroadly on track, Keating said.\n    "They'
data: ' indicate that domestic demand has been a little more\nsluggish than'
data: ' was expected at budget time," he said.\n    "On the other hand, net'
data: ' exports seem to be expanding by more\nthan expected at budget time,'
data: ' and this is underpinning growth\nin domestic production and employm'
data: 'ent."\n    Keating said it now seems likely that the 1986/87 inflati'
data: 'on\nrate will exceed the budget forecast of eight pct.\n    "Neverth'
data: 'eless, there is likely to be a marked slowing in\ninflation over com'
data: 'ing quarters as depreciation and budgetary\neffects wane," he said.\n'
data: '    Keating said the government expects economic growth to pick\nup '
data: 'moderately in 1987/88 due to a further significant rise in\nnet expo'
data: 'rts and a very moderate but positive contribution from\nprivate dome'
data: 'stic demand.\n    He said domestic demand growth will be due to a\ns'
data: 'trengthening in real household disposable income.\n    The moderate '
data: 'rise in economic growth next financial year\nshould be sufficient to'
data: ' sustain employment growth at a level\nbroadly equivalent to that of'
data: ' the current fiscal year.\n    "The current account deficit will con'
data: 'tinue to show\nimprovement in 1987/88," Keating said.\n    "As the i'
data: 'mpact of the exchange rate depreciations of recent\nyears recede fur'
data: 'ther, and given continued effective wage\nrestraint, inflation shoul'
data: 'd moderate markedly in 1987/88," he\nsaid.\n REUTER\n\x03'

data: 'of indebtedness as an alternative\nto cash, the authoritative Busine'

data: 'rters yesterday the\nalternative proposal is designed to avoid an im'
data: 'passe when debt\nrescheduling talks reopen in New York on Tuesday.\n'
data: '    He did not give details but said, "It is a very useful\nalternat'
data: 'ive and in the end will permit the banks to say that\nthey achieved '
data: 'their pricing target and will likewise permit the\nPhilippines to sa'
data: 'y exactly the same thing."\n    Quoting negotiation documents to be '
data: 'presented to the\ncountry"s 12-bank advisory committee, Business Day'
data: ' said the debt\ncertificates will carry maturities of five or six ye'
data: 'ars.\n    It said the certificates will be classified as zero-coupon'
data: '\nbonds or promissory notes with no interest but priced at a\nconsid'
data: 'erable discount from their redemption price.\n    It said the debt b'
data: 'onds will entitle holder banks to a\nguaranteed return on both inter'
data: 'est and principal since no\npayment of any kind is made until the bo'
data: 'nd matures.\n    It said a bank can sell the bonds on the secondary '
data: 'bond\nmarket for either dlrs or pesos depending on its requirement.\n'
data: '    The documents said peso proceeds can be invested in\nselected in'
data: 'dustries under the Philippines" debt/equity program.\n    Ongpin sai'
data: 'd Manila is sticking to its demand of a spread of\n5/8 percentage po'
data: 'ints over London Interbank Offered Rates\n(LIBOR) for restructuring '
data: '3.6 billion dlrs of debt repayments.\n    "(The proposal) will give '
data: 'the banks a choice of 5/8ths or\nthe alternative," Ongpin said. "Our'
data: ' representatives have gone to\nWashington to the (International Mone'
data: 'tary) Fund, the (World)\nBank, the Fed (Federal Reserve Board) and t'
data: 'he (U.S.) Treasury\nto brief them in advance on this alternative and'
data: ' it has\ngenerally been positively received."\n    "We don"t believe'
data: ' that there is going to be a problem on the\naccounting side," Ongpi'
data: 'n said. "We have run this alternative\nproposal to the accounting fi'
data: 'rms. Neither have the government\nregulators indicated that there wi'
data: 'll be a problem."\n REUTER\n\x03'

data: 'dled the presidency and one-third\nbelieve he should resign, a new p'
data: 'oll said.\n    The poll conducted by Newsweek magazine said 53 pct o'
data: 'f the\nrespondents gave Reagan a negative performance rating, nearly'
data: '\ndouble his disapproval rating before the Iran/Contra scandal.\n   '
data: ' The magazine said, however, that Reagan remained personally\npopula'
data: 'r. By better than a three-to-one ratio, a majority of\nthose polled '

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'PRODUCER SPLIT HEATS UP COFFEE QUOTA TALKS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Lisa Vaughan, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    LONDON, March 1 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Talks on the possibility of reintroducing\nglobal coffee export quot'
data: 'as have been extended into today, with\nsparks flying yesterday when'
data: ' a dissident group of exporters was\nnot included in a key negotiati'
data: 'ng forum.\n    The special meeting of the International Coffee\nOrga'
data: 'nization (ICO) council was called to find a way to stop a\nprolonged'
data: ' slide in coffee prices.\n    However, delegates said no solution to'
data: ' the question of how\nto implement quotas was yet in sight.\n    Wor'
data: 'ld coffee export quotas -- the major device used to\nregulate coffee'
data: ' prices under the International Coffee Agreement\n-- were suspended '
data: 'a year ago when prices soared in reaction to\na drought which cut Br'
data: 'azil"s output by nearly two thirds.\n    Brazil is the world"s large'
data: 'st coffee producer and exporter.\n    Producers and consumers now ar'
data: 'e facing off over the\nquestion of how quotas should be calculated u'
data: 'nder any future\nquota distribution scheme, delegates said.\n    Tem'
data: 'pers flared late Saturday when a minority group of eight\nproducing '
data: 'countries was not represented in a contact group of\nfive producer a'
data: 'nd five consumer delegates plus alternates which\nwas set up to faci'
data: 'litate debate.\n    The big producers "want to have the ball only in'
data: ' their court\nand it isn"t fair," minority producer spokesman Luis E'
data: 'scalante of\nCosta Rica said.\n    The majority producer group has p'
data: 'roposed resuming quotas\nApril 1, using the previous ad hoc method o'
data: 'f carving up quota\nshares, with a promise to try to negotiate basic'
data: ' quotas before\nSeptember 30, delegates said.\n    Their plan would '
data: 'perpetuate the status quo, allowing Brazil\nto retain almost all of '
data: 'its current 30 pct share of the export\nmarket, Colombia 17 pct, Ivo'
data: 'ry Coast seven pct and Indonesia\nsix pct, with the rest divided amo'
data: 'ng smaller exporters.\n    But consuming countries and the dissident'
data: ' producer group\nhave tabled separate proposals requiring quotas be '
data: 'determined\nby availability, using a formula incorporating exportabl'
data: 'e\nproduction and stocks statistics.\n    Their proposals would give'
data: ' Brazil a smaller quota share and\nColombia and Indonesia a larger s'
data: 'hare, and bring a new quota\ndistribution scheme into effect now rat'
data: 'her than later.\n    Brazil has so far been unwilling to accept any '
data: 'proposal\nthat would reduce its quota share, delegates said.\n    De'
data: 'legates would not speculate on prospects for agreement on\na quota p'
data: 'ackage. "Anything is possible at this phase," even\nadjournment of t'
data: 'he meeting until March or April, one said.\n    If the ICO does agre'
data: 'e on quotas, the price of coffee on the\nsupermarket shelf is not li'
data: 'kely to change sinnificantly as a\nresult, industry sources said.\n '
data: '   Retail coffee prices over the past year have remained about\nstea'
data: 'dy even though coffee market prices have tumbled, so an\nupswing pro'
data: 'bably will not be passed onto the consumer either,\nthey said.\n REU'
data: 'TER\n\x03'

data: 'INDONESIAN AGRICULTURE GROWTH EXPECTED TO SLOW'

start tag: <dateline>
data: '    JAKARTA, March 1 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Indonesia"s agriculture sector will grow\nby just 1.0 pct in calenda'
data: 'r 1987, against an estimated 2.4 pct\nin 1986 as the production of s'
data: 'ome commodities stagnates or\ndeclines, the U.S. Embassy said in a r'
data: 'eport.\n    Production of Indonesia"s staple food, rice, is forecast'
data: ' to\nfall to around 26.3 mln tonnes from an embassy estimate of\n26.'
data: '58 mln tonnes in 1986, according to the annual report on\nIndonesia"'
data: 's agricultural performance.\n    The government officially estimates'
data: ' 1986 rice production at\n26.7 mln tonnes, with a forecast 27.3 mln '
data: 'tonnes output in\n1987.\n    The report says wheat imports are likel'
data: 'y to fall to 1.5 mln\ntonnes in calendar 1987 from 1.69 mln tonnes i'
data: 'n 1986 because of\na drawdown on stocks.\n    "Growth prospects for '
data: 'agriculture in 1987 do not look\npromising as rice production is for'
data: 'ecast to decline and the\nproduction of sugarcane, rubber and copra '
data: 'show little or no\ngain," the report says.\n    "The modest overall '
data: 'increase which is expected will be due\nto significant gains in prod'
data: 'uction of corn soybeans, palm oil\nand palm kernels."\n    Constrain'
data: 'ts to significant overall increases in\nagricultural output include '
data: 'a shortage of disease resistant\nseeds, limited fertile land, insect'
data: ' pests and a reluctance by\nfarmers to shift from rice production to'
data: ' other crops, the\nreport underlines.\n    The fall in rice producti'
data: 'on is caused by an outbreak of\npests known as "wereng" or brown pla'
data: 'nt hoppers in 1986 which\nlargely offset gains in yields.\n    The o'
data: 'utbreak has forced the government to ban the use of 57\ninsecticides'
data: ' on rice because it was believed the wereng are now\nresistant to th'
data: 'ese varieties, and to use lower-yielding, more\nresistant rice types'
data: '.\n    The government is depending on increased production of\nexpor'
data: 't commodities such as coffee, tea, rubber, plywood and\npalm oil to '
data: 'offset revenue losses brought on by falling crude\noil prices.\n    '
data: 'Palm oil production is expected to increase by over 7.0 pct\nin 1987'
data: ' to 1.45 mln tonnes from 1.35 mln, with exports rising\nto an estima'
data: 'ted 720,000 tonnes from 695,000 tonnes in 1986, the\nreport says.\n '
data: '   But while production of soybeans in 1987/88 (Oct-Sept) will\nrise'
data: ' to 1.075 mln tonnes from 980,000 in 1986/87, imports will\nalso ris'
data: 'e to supply a new soybean crushing plant.\n    The report says that '
data: 'imports of wheat, soybeans, soybean\nmeal and cotton are not likely '
data: 'to decline as a result of last\nSeptember"s 31 pct devaluation of th'
data: 'e rupiah because of a rise\nin domestic demand.\n    The report said'
data: ' that Indonesia"s overall economic\nperformance in calendar 1986 was'
data: ' about zero or even a slight\nnegative growth rate, the lowest rate '
data: 'of growth since the\nmid-1960s. It compares with 1.9 pct growth in 1'
data: '985 and 6.7 pct\nin 1984.\n    The dramatic fall in oil prices last '
data: 'year was responsible\nfor the slump.\n REUTER\n\x03'

end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Kuwait"s Oil Minister, in remarks\npublished today, said there were '
data: 'no plans for an emergency OPEC\nmeeting to review oil policies after'
data: ' recent weakness in world\noil prices.\n    Sheikh Ali al-Khalifa al'
data: '-Sabah was quoted by the local\ndaily al-Qabas as saying: "None of t'
data: 'he OPEC members has asked\nfor such a meeting."\n    He denied Kuwai'
data: 't was pumping above its quota of 948,000\nbarrels of crude daily (bp'
data: 'd) set under self-imposed production\nlimits of the 13-nation organi'
data: 'sation.\n    Traders and analysts in international oil markets estim'
data: 'ate\nOPEC is producing up to one mln bpd above a ceiling of 15.8 mln'
data: '\nbpd agreed in Geneva last December.\n    They named Kuwait and the'
data: ' United Arab Emirates, along with\nthe much smaller producer Ecuador'
data: ', among those producing above\nquota. Kuwait, they said, was pumping'
data: ' 1.2 mln bpd.\n    "This rumour is baseless. It is based on reports '
data: 'which said\nKuwait has the ability to exceed its share. They suppose'
data: ' that\nbecause Kuwait has the ability, it will do so," the minister\n'
data: 'said.\n    Sheikh Ali has said before that Kuwait had the ability to'
data: '\nproduce up to 4.0 mln bpd.\n    "If we can sell more than our quot'
data: 'a at official prices,\nwhile some countries are suffering difficulti'
data: 'es marketing their\nshare, it means we in Kuwait are unusually cleve'
data: 'r," he said.\n    He was referring apparently to the Gulf state of q'
data: 'atar,\nwhich industry sources said was selling less than 180,000 bpd'
data: '\nof its 285,000 bpd quota, because buyers were resisting\nofficial '
data: 'prices restored by OPEC last month pegged to a marker\nof 18 dlrs pe'
data: 'r barrel.\n    Prices in New York last week dropped to their lowest '
data: 'levels\nthis year and almost three dollars below a three-month high '
data: 'of\n19 dollars a barrel.\n    Sheikh Ali also delivered "a challenge'
data: ' to any international\noil company that declared Kuwait sold below o'
data: 'fficial prices."\n    Because it was charging its official price, of'
data: ' 16.67 dlrs a\nbarrel, it had lost custom, he said but did not elabo'
data: 'rate.\n    However, Kuwait had guaranteed markets for its oil becaus'
data: 'e\nof its local and international refining facilities and its own\nd'
data: 'istribution network abroad, he added.\n    He reaffirmed that the pl'
data: 'anned meeting March 7 of OPEC"s\ndifferentials committee has been po'
data: 'stponed until the start of\nApril at the request of certain of the b'
data: 'ody"s members.\n    Ecuador"s deputy energy minister Fernando Santos'
data: ' Alvite said\nlast Wednesday his debt-burdened country wanted OPEC t'

data: 'o difficulties faced by Qatar, he said: "We\nexpected such pressure.'
data: ' It will continue through March and\nApril." But he expected the sit'
data: 'uation would later improve.\n REUTER\n\x03'

data: '-AT-CRO   03-01 0107'
end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'INDONESIA SEEN AT CROSSROADS OVER ECONOMIC CHANGE'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Jeremy Clift, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    JAKARTA, March 1 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Indonesia appears to be nearing a\npolitical crossroads over measure'
data: 's to deregulate its protected\neconomy, the U.S. Embassy says in a n'
data: 'ew report.\n    To counter falling oil revenues, the government has\n'
data: 'launched a series of measures over the past nine months to\nboost ex'
data: 'ports outside the oil sector and attract new\ninvestment.\n    Indon'
data: 'esia, the only Asian member of OPEC and a leading\nprimary commodity'
data: ' producer, has been severely hit by last year"s\nfall in world oil p'
data: 'rices, which forced it to devalue its\ncurrency by 31 pct in Septemb'
data: 'er.\n    But the U.S. Embassy report says President Suharto"s\ngover'
data: 'nment appears to be divided over what direction to lead\nthe economy'
data: '.\n    "(It) appears to be nearing a crossroads with regard to\ndere'
data: 'gulation, both as it pertains to investments and imports,"\nthe repo'
data: 'rt says. It primarily assesses Indonesia"s agricultural\nsector, but'
data: ' also reviews the country"s general economic\nperformance.\n    It s'
data: 'ays that while many government officials and advisers\nare recommend'
data: 'ing further relaxation, "there are equally strong\npressures being e'
data: 'xerted to halt all such moves."\n    "This group strongly favours an'
data: ' import substitution economy,"\nthe report says.\n    Indonesia"s ec'
data: 'onomic changes have been welcomed by the World\nBank and internation'
data: 'al bankers as steps in the right direction,\nthough they say crucial'
data: ' areas of the economy like plastics and\nsteel remain highly protect'
data: 'ed, and virtual monopolies.\n    Three sets of measures have been an'
data: 'nounced since last May,\nwhich broadened areas for foreign investmen'
data: 't, reduced trade\nrestrictions and liberalised imports.\n    The rep'
data: 'ort says Indonesia"s economic growth in calendar 1986\nwas probably '
data: 'about zero, and the economy may even have\ncontracted a bit. "This i'
data: 's the lowest rate of growth since the\nmid-1960s," the report notes.'
data: '\n    Indonesia, the largest country in South-East Asia with a\npopu'
data: 'lation of 168 million, is facing general elections in\nApril.\n    B'
data: 'ut the report hold out little hope for swift improvement\nin the eco'
data: 'nomic outlook. "For 1987 early indications point to a\nslightly posi'
data: 'tive growth rate not exceeding one pct. Economic\nactivity continues'
data: ' to suffer due to the sharp fall in export\nearnings from the petrol'
data: 'eum industry."\n    "Growth in the non-oil sector is low because of '
data: 'weak\ndomestic demand coupled with excessive plant capacity, real\nd'
data: 'eclines in construction and trade, and a reduced level of\ngrowth in'
data: ' agriculture," the report states.\n    Bankers say continuation of p'
data: 'resent economic reforms is\ncrucial for the government to get the in'
data: 'ternational lending its\nneeds.\n    A new World Bank loan of 300 ml'

data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    NEW DELHI, March 1 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Opposition politicians, businessmen\nand newspapers criticised India'
data: '"s newly unveiled 1987/88 budget\nand large projected deficit of aro'
data: 'und 57 billion rupees.\n    They said the budget failed to provide i'
data: 'ncentives for\neconomic growth and merely tinkered with tax reform.\n'
data: '    But few politicians were prepared to criticise a sharp rise\nin '
data: 'defence expenditure in the Hindu-majority nation where\nplaying on f'
data: 'ear of aggression by Moslem Pakistan has proved a\nvote winner. The '
data: 'Indian Express, the country"s biggest selling\npaper, said: "The def'
data: 'ence cow has never been holier."\n    The Sunday Mail newspaper bran'
data: 'ded the budget "shamelessly\npolitical." It said in a front page com'
data: 'mentary the "budget is bad\nfor growth, bad for prices, bad for the '
data: 'stock market and\nneutral in respect of everything else."\n    Busin'
data: 'essmen polled by Reuters said the budget had done\nlittle for them.\n'
data: '    Gandhi announced small increases in poverty alleviation and\nedu'
data: 'cation outlays but he ordered a hold-down on current\nexpenditure in'
data: ' an attempt to rein in the budget deficit. He\ntold ministries to cu'
data: 'rb spending and promised a review of\nmoney-losing public sector ind'
data: 'ustries.\n    Gandhi lowered import tariffs on some computer parts b'
data: 'ut\notherwise did little to extended the economic liberalisation\npo'
data: 'licy launched two years ago.\n    Reaction in Bombay, India"s busine'
data: 'ss capital, was generally\nunfavourable.\n    Businessmen and econom'
data: 'ists said the budget had no proposals\nfor closing the 1987/88 budge'
data: 't deficit. It also failed to boost\nindustrial investment and produc'
data: 'tivity needed to lift real\neconomic growth above the five pct a yea'
data: 'r envisaged by the\n1985-90 development plan.\n    Nalin Vissanji, P'
data: 'resident of the Indian Merchants Chambers\nof Commerce said the budg'
data: 'et gave no incentives to the capital\nmarket and had not fulfilled a'
data: ' government pledge to remove\nsurtax on corporate income.\n    Share'
data: 's on The Bombay Stock Exchange, India"s biggest, fell\nin a post-bud'
data: 'get session yesterday but brokers welcomed Gandhi"s\nproposal to set'
data: ' up a regulatory board for the securities\nindustry.\n    The exchan'
data: 'ge was shaken last year by several scandals and\ntrading was suspend'
data: 'ed several times.\n    Brokers said trading volume may increase with'
data: ' the change in\ncapital gains tax on stock sales.\n    Stockholders '
data: 'can now sell shares after one year instead of\nthree years without i'
data: 'ncurring capital gains tax.\n    Stock Exchange President Ramdas Dal'
data: 'al said yesterday the\nfall in share prices after the budget came as'

data: 'onds will entitle holder banks to a\nguaranteed return on both inter'
data: 'est and principal since no\npayment of any kind is made until the bo'
data: 'nd matures.\n    It said a bank can sell the bonds on the secondary '
data: 'bond\nmarket for either dlrs or pesos depending on its requirement.\n'
data: '    The documents said peso proceeds can be invested in\nselected in'

data: 'd Manila is sticking to its demand of a spread of\n5/8 percentage po'

data: '3.6 billion dlrs of debt repayments.\n    "(The proposal) will give '
data: 'the banks a choice of 5/8ths or\nthe alternative," Ongpin said. "Our'
data: ' representatives have gone to\nWashington to the (International Mone'
data: 'tary) Fund, the (World)\nBank, the Fed (Federal Reserve Board) and t'
data: 'he (U.S.) Treasury\nto brief them in advance on this alternative and'
data: ' it has\ngenerally been positively received."\n    "We don\'t believ'

data: 'in said. "We have run this alternative\nproposal to the accounting f'

data: 'QATAR UNVEILS BUDGET FOR FISCAL 1987/88'

data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    DOHA, March 1 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "The Gulf oil state of Qatar, recovering\nslightly from last year's d"
data: 'ecline in world oil prices,\nannounced its first budget since early '
data: '1985 and projected a\ndeficit of 5.472 billion riyals.\n    The defi'
data: 'cit compared with a shortfall of 7.3 billion riyals\nin the last pub'
data: 'lished budget for 1985/86.\n    In a statement outlining the budget '
data: 'for the fiscal year\n1987/88 beginning today, Finance and Petroleum '
data: 'Minister Sheikh\nAbdul-Aziz bin Khalifa al-Thani said the government'
data: ' expected to\nspend 12.217 billion riyals in the period.\n    Projec'
data: 'ted expenditure in the 1985/86 budget had been 15.6\nbillion riyals.'
data: '\n    Sheikh Abdul-Aziz said government revenue would be about\n6.74'
data: '5 billion riyals, down by about 30 pct on the 1985/86\nprojected rev'
data: 'enue of 9.7 billion.\n    The government failed to publish a 1986/87'
data: ' budget due to\nuncertainty surrounding oil revenues.\n    Sheikh Ab'
data: 'dul-Aziz said that during that year the government\ndecided to limit'
data: ' recurrent expenditure each month to\none-twelfth of the previous fi'
data: "scal year's allocations minus 15\npct.\n    He urged heads of govern"
data: 'ment departments and public\ninstitutions to help the government rat'
data: 'ionalise expenditure. He\ndid not say how the 1987/88 budget shortfa'
data: 'll would be covered.\n    Sheikh Abdul-Aziz said plans to limit expe'
data: 'nditure in\n1986/87 had been taken in order to relieve the burden pl'
data: "aced on\nthe country's foreign reserves.\n    He added in 1987/88 so"
data: 'me 2.766 billion riyals had been\nallocated for major projects inclu'
data: 'ding housing and public\nbuildings, social services, health, educati'
data: 'on, transport and\ncommunications, electricity and water, industry a'
data: 'nd\nagriculture.\n    No figure was revealed for expenditure on defe'
data: 'nce and\nsecurity. There was also no projection for oil revenue.\n  '
data: '  Qatar, an OPEC member, has an output ceiling of 285,000\nbarrels p'
data: 'er day.\n    Sheikh Abdul-Aziz said: "Our expectations of positive s'
data: "igns\nregarding (oil) price trends, foremost among them OPEC's\ndete"
data: 'rmination to shoulder its responsibilites and protect its\nwealth, h'
data: "ave helped us make reasonable estimates for the coming\nyear's reven"

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'GULF BOND, STOCK MARKETS LAG BEHIND, GIB SAYS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    BAHRAIN, March 1 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Gulf money markets have grown reasonably\nwell during the past decad'
data: 'e, but bond and stock markets remain\nto a large extent fragmented a'
data: 'nd lag behind, <Gulf\nInternational Bank BSC> (GIB) said.\n    The b'
data: "ank's economist Henry Azzam said in a review of Gulf\ncapital market"
data: 's that investors have to relinquish traditional\ninvestment vehicles'
data: ' such as real estate, foreign currency bank\naccounts and precious m'
data: 'etals.\n    "Greater financial sophistication is needed coupled with'
data: '\nmore diversified capital market instruments and a change in the\nd'
data: 'isclosure requirements on company accounts," he said.\n    The GIB s'
data: 'tudy reviewed capital markets under three\ncategories -- money marke'
data: 'ts, stock and bond markets.\n    Azzam said Gulf states had been mak'
data: 'ing greater use of\nshort-term money market instruments and banks in'
data: ' the region had\nfloated various euronotes and underwriting faciliti'
data: 'es.\n    "Nevertheless, bond and stock markets remain, to a large\ne'
data: 'xtent, fragmented and lagging behind," he said.\n    Most debt in th'
data: 'e region is still raised by syndicated loans\nand bank facilities an'
data: 'd very few companies had made use of\nstock or bond issues. Only Kuw'
data: 'ait has an official stock\nexchange, while other Gulf nations have y'
data: 'et to establish\nexchanges.\n    But with dwindling financial surplu'
data: 'ses in the Gulf,\ngovernments are actively pursuing ways to develop '
data: 'capital\nmarkets and set up domestic stock exchanges, Azzam said.\n '
data: '   He said recession stemming from sliding oil prices had\n"clearly '
data: 'had a negative impact on the development of capital\nmarkets in the '
data: 'region."\n    In addition, family firms are reluctant to go public,\n'
data: 'financial awareness among investors is still lacking and\ninvestment'
data: ' analysis and corporate reporting standards lack\ndepth. A sharp fal'
data: 'l in share prices in the early 1980s prompted\ninvestors to hold on '
data: 'to shares hoping for an eventual recovery.\n    Azzam said the absen'
data: "ce of proper commercial law in some\nGulf countries and authorities'"
data: ' apparent reluctance to adopt\nfinancial innovations had also hamper'
data: 'ed capital markets.\n    He called for clearly defined laws governin'
data: 'g incorporation\nof joint stock companies and the flotation of debt '
data: 'instruments.\n    Azzam said capital market instruments should be ma'
data: 'de\navailable to all citizens and institutions of Gulf Cooperation\n'
data: 'Council (GCC) states -- Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar, Oman, Saudi\nArabia '
data: 'and the United Arab Emirates (UAE). Some moves had been\ntaken in th'
data: 'is direction, with Bahrain allowing GCC nationals to\nown up to 25 p'
data: 'ct of locally incorporated companies.\n    Azzam said Gulf money mar'
data: 'kets had received greater depth\nfrom the introduction of treasury b'
data: 'ill offerings in Bahrain and\nthe expansion of securities repurchase'
data: ' regulations in Saudi\nArabia.\n    But he added there is "no bond m'
data: 'arket to speak of" in Saudi\nArabia, Qatar, Oman or the UAE, with th'
data: 'e last Saudi riyal\ndenominated bond issued in 1978.\n    While Bahr'
data: 'ain plans an official stock exchange and trading\nin Saudi Arabia ha'
data: 's picked up, establishment of formal\nexchanges in Qatar, Oman and t'
data: 'he UAE does not appear imminent,\nAzzam said.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

data: 'SAUDI ARABIA REITERATES COMMITMENT TO OPEC PACT'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    BAHRAIN, March 1 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "Saudi Arabian Oil Minister Hisham Nazer\nreiterated the kingdom's co"
data: "mmitment to last December's OPEC\naccord to boost world oil prices a"
data: 'nd stabilise the market, the\nofficial Saudi Press Agency SPA said.\n'
data: '    Asked by the agency about the recent fall in free market\noil pr'
data: 'ices, Nazer said Saudi Arabia "is fully adhering by the\n... Accord '
data: 'and it will never sell its oil at prices below the\npronounced price'
data: 's under any circumstance."\n    Nazer, quoted by SPA, said recent pr'
data: 'essure on free market\nprices "may be because of the end of the (nor'
data: 'thern hemisphere)\nwinter season and the glut in the market."\n    S'
data: 'audi Arabia was a main architect of the December accord,\nunder whic'
data: 'h OPEC agreed to lower its total output ceiling by\n7.25 pct to 15.8'
data: ' mln barrels per day (bpd) and return to fixed\nprices of around 18 '
data: 'dlrs a barrel.\n    The agreement followed a year of turmoil on oil '
data: 'markets,\nwhich saw prices slump briefly to under 10 dlrs a barrel i'
data: 'n\nmid-1986 from about 30 dlrs in late 1985. Free market prices\nare'
data: ' currently just over 16 dlrs.\n    Nazer was quoted by the SPA as sa'
data: "ying Saudi Arabia's\nadherence to the accord was shown clearly in th"
data: 'e oil market.\n    He said contacts among members of OPEC showed the'
data: 'y all\nwanted to stick to the accord.\n    In Jamaica, OPEC Presiden'
data: 't Rilwanu Lukman, who is also\nNigerian Oil Minister, said the group'
data: ' planned to stick with the\npricing agreement.\n    "We are aware of'
data: ' the negative forces trying to manipulate\nthe operations of the mar'
data: 'ket, but we are satisfied that the\nfundamentals exist for stable ma'
data: 'rket conditions," he said.\n    Kuwait\'s Oil Minister, Sheikh Ali a'
data: "l-Khalifa al-Sabah, said\nin remarks published in the emirate's dail"
data: 'y Al-Qabas there were\nno plans for an emergency OPEC meeting to rev'
data: 'iew prices.\n    Traders and analysts in international oil markets e'
data: 'stimate\nOPEC is producing up to one mln bpd above the 15.8 mln ceil'
data: 'ing.\n    They named Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, along with'
data: '\nthe much smaller producer Ecuador, among those producing above\nqu'
data: 'ota. Sheikh Ali denied that Kuwait was over-producing.\n REUTER\n\x03'

data: 'FEBRUARY U.S. PURCHASING MANAGER INDEX FALLS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    NEW YORK, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The U.S. Economy continued to expand in\nFebruary but at a slower pa'
data: 'ce than in January, which saw a\nspurt of activity, the National Ass'
data: 'ociation of Purchasing\nManagement (NAPM) said in a report.\n    The'
data: " Association's composite survey index dropped to 51.9\npct in Februa"
data: 'ry from 55.8 pct in January, the NAPM said. It was\nthe seventh cons'
data: 'ecutive month in which this leading indicator\nwas over 50 pct.\n   '
data: ' A reading above 50 pct generally indicates that the economy\nis in '
data: 'an expanding phase. One below 50 pct implies a declining\neconomy.\n'
data: '    The  NAPM report, based on a survey of purchasing managers\nat 2'
data: '50 U.S. Industrial companies, also found that the growth\nrate in ne'
data: 'w orders and production slowed in February.\n    But production rema'
data: 'ined vigorous, with more than three\ntimes as many members reporting'
data: ' it better rather than worse.\n    Vendor deliveries improved slight'
data: 'ly last month, but members\nreported that steel supplies were tight '
data: 'as USX Corp gradually\nresumed production.\n    The same number of m'
data: 'embers reported inventories were higher\nas reported them lower. The'
data: ' NAPM said that had not happened\nsince August 1984.\n    For a sixt'
data: 'h straight month, more purchasers reported paying\nhigher rather tha'
data: 'n lower prices, this time by a ratio of nine\nto one.\n    Robert Br'
data: 'etz, chairman of the NAPM\'s business survey\ncommittee, said: "The '
data: 'economy continued to expand in February,\nbut at a more subdued rate'
data: ' than in January. The slowing of new\norders should not be significa'
data: 'nt enough to dampen prospects for\na respectable first quarter."\n  '
data: '  The composite index is a seasonally adjusted figure, based\non fiv'
data: 'e components of the NAPM business survey - new orders,\nproduction, '
data: 'vendor deliveries, inventories and employment.\n REUTER\n\x03'

data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    BRUSSELS, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'European Community (EC) agriculture\nministers meet later today to c'
data: 'onsider a package of deep cuts\nin prices and subsidies after a week'
data: ' marked by strong protests\nby European farmers, Community officials'
data: " said.\n    The common target for the farmers' wrath is the EC's\nBr"
data: 'ussels Commission, which for the fourth year running has\ncalled for'
data: ' radical changes in the price support system.\n    EC Agriculture Co'
data: 'mmissioner Frans Andriessen says huge food\nsurpluses, which have al'
data: 'ienated international trade partners\nand pushed the Community to th'
data: 'e edge of bankruptcy, demand such\naction.\n    With Community wareh'
data: 'ouses stocked with some 16 mln tonnes\nof unwanted cereals, over one'
data: ' mln tonnes of butter and huge\nstocks of wine and olive oil, Andrie'
data: 'ssen says bluntly the days\nof open-ended price guarantees must end.'
data: '\n    EC agriculture ministers try to fix the guaranteed prices\npai'
data: 'd to Community farmers before an April 1 deadline for the\nnew marke'
data: 'ting year, an increasingly difficult task as EC\nmembers cut funds a'
data: 'nd demand greater budget discipline.\n    Andriessen has proposed a '
data: 'freeze for most prices, coupled\nwith reductions in other support me'
data: 'chanisms, which could lead\nto price cuts of as much as eight pct fo'
data: "r some products.\n    A producer's right to sell into EC warehouses "
data: 'at a fixed\nguaranteed price when he finds no real market outlet is '
data: 'to be\nscaled back so it applies only in exceptional cases.\n    The'
data: ' latest proposals are designed to keep expenditure on\nagriculture v'
data: 'irtually stable. EC farm policies now swallow\ntwo-thirds of an annu'
data: 'al budget of about 36 billion European\ncurrency units (Ecu) and are'
data: ' mainly responsible for an expected\nshortfall this year of about fi'
data: 've billion Ecus.\n    The most contentious aspects of the package ar'
data: 'e a new oils\nand fats tax and a change in the "green" exchange rate'
data: ' system,\nwhich translates EC farm prices into national currencies.\n'
data: '    The tax, of up to 330 Ecus per tonne, would be levied on\nimport'
data: 'ed and domestically produced oilseeds, but could trigger\na fresh tr'
data: 'ade dispute with the United States, which provides\nthe EC with the '
data: 'bulk of its soybeans.\n    It would increase the cost of margarines '
data: 'and low-fat\nproducts in an attempt to increase both olive oil and b'
data: 'utter\nconsumption.\n    West Germany has flatly rejected green rate'
data: ' changes, which\nwould cause a fall in prices for producers as count'
data: 'ries with\nweak and strong currencies were brought more into line.\n'
data: ' REUTER\n\x03'

data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: "QANTAS TO BUY FOUR 747-400'S FOR ONE BILLION DLRS"
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    SYDNEY, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: '<Qantas Airways Ltd> has placed a firm\norder with Boeing Co <BA> fo'
data: 'r four 747-400 aircraft at a cost\nof 250 mln Australian dlrs each, '
data: 'chairman Jim Leslie said.\n    The first is due for delivery in Apri'
data: 'l 1989 with the others\narriving in May, June and September of that '
data: 'year, he said in a\nstatement.\n    The 400 series is the latest mod'
data: 'el of the Boeing 747\nfamily, he said.\n    The purchase will take g'
data: "overnment-owned Qantas's 747 fleet\nto 28, he said.\n    Leslie said"
data: ' Qantas is talking to three engine makers who\nare all offering engi'
data: 'nes for the Boeing 747-400 and it will\nannounce a decision on engin'
data: 'e purchases later this year.\n    He said they are United Technologi'
data: 'es Corp <UTX> unit <Pratt^M\nand Whitney>, General Electric Co <GE> '
data: "and Britain's <Rolls-Royce^M\n Ltd>.\n    He said the 747-400, which"
data: ' incorporates new technology such\nas extended wings with six-feet h'
data: 'igh winglets and enhanced\nelectronics, should have its first flight'
data: ' next February. The\n400 series has a designed range of 12,500 kms, '
data: "2,140 kms\nfurther than the current Qantas 747-300's, he said.\n    "
data: 'The aircraft will be financed by foreign borrowings and\nforeign exc'
data: 'hange earnings, and Qantas believes they will pay\nfor themselves in'
data: ' four to five years, Leslie said.\n    The 747-400 has a take-off we'
data: 'ight of 870,000 pounds, up\nfrom 833,000 for the 300 series, and off'
data: 'ers an eight pct fuel\nsaving, he said.\n    The higher range and pa'
data: 'yload means they will first be used\non the route to Britain and Eur'
data: 'ope via Asia.\n    They will also be used on non-stop flights betwee'
data: 'n Sydney\nand Los Angeles.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

start tag: <title>
data: 'STRONG EARTHQUAKE HITS NEW ZEALAND'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WELLINGTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'An earthquake measuring 6.5 on the\nRichter scale caused widespread '
data: 'damage in northern New Zealand\nand a civil defence emergency was de'
data: 'clared in some areas,\nofficials and seismologists said.\n    There '
data: 'were no immediate reports of casualties. The quake\njolted the Bay o'
data: 'f Plenty and Waikato areas.\n    The town of Whakatane was said by o'
data: 'fficials to be virtually\nisolated.\n    A civil defence emergency w'
data: 'as declared in Whakatane which\nhas about 16,000 people. Officials s'
data: 'aid many roads and bridges\nin the area had been damaged.\n    No de'
data: 'aths were reported but one man was admitted to\nhospital in serious '
data: 'condition after his car was buried in a mud\nslip.\n    Seismologist'
data: 's said Whakatane was hit by three earthquakes,\nthe strongest measur'
data: 'ing 6.5 on the Richter scale. They were\nfollowed by a series of aft'
data: 'ershocks.\n    The quakes were felt across the Bay of Plenty and Wai'
data: 'kato\nregions in the northeast of the North Island.\n    Smaller tre'
data: 'mors had been felt in the Bay of Plenty for more\nthan a week.\n    '
data: 'Police said many districts lost power supplies and\ntelephone links.'
data: '\n    Energy Ministry officials ordered the release of water\nbehind'
data: ' the Matahina hydro-electric dam, 32 kilometres above\nWhakatane on '
data: 'the Rangitaiki river. The quake cracked the\nroadway and concrete ab'
data: 'utment along the top of Matahina, the\nlargest earth dam in the Nort'
data: 'h Island.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

start tag: <title>
data: 'PHILIPPINES HEADS CONFIDENTLY INTO DEBT TALKS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Chaitanya Kalbag, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    MANILA, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Philippine Finance Secretary Jaime Ongpin\nstarts negotiations with '
data: "the country's 12-bank advisory\ncommittee in New York tomorrow, buoy"
data: 'ed by an economy on the\nmend and political stability one year after'
data: ' President Corazon\nAquino took power, central bank officials said.\n'
data: '    The country now has foreign debt totalling 27.8 billion\ndlrs an'
data: 'd faces debt repayments of 3.6 billion dlrs due between\nJanuary 198'
data: '7 and December 1992. Manila also hopes to tack on\nanother 5.8 billi'
data: 'on dlrs, rescheduled in a 1985 accord, to any\nnew agreement, the of'
data: "ficials said.\n    Chile's 15-1/2 year rescheduling accord at one pe"
data: 'rcentage\npoint over London Interbank Offered Rates (LIBOR) and\nVen'
data: "ezuala's 21 billion dlr package at 7/8 point over LIBOR\nportend wel"
data: "l for the Philippines, despite Brazil's repayment\nsuspension last w"
data: 'eek, the officials said.\n    Manila, which has not made any princip'
data: 'al repayments since\n1983, wants terms better than the 20-year repay'
data: 'ments at 13/16\npercentage point over LIBOR offered in October to Me'
data: 'xico in a\n77 billion dlr rescue.\n    Ongpin wants 5/8 point over t'
data: 'he benchmark rate, which is\ncurrently hovering around 6-1/2 pct.\n '
data: '   The banks are said to be firm on the 1-1/8 points offered\nwhen t'
data: 'he last round of negotiations collapsed on November 7.\n    Ongpin s'
data: 'aid every 1/16 point over LIBOR meant an additional\n5.1 mln dlrs in'
data: ' annual interest payments.\n    One banker said banks were wary of r'
data: 'epeating a Mexico-type\naccord, which some 70 small creditor banks a'
data: 're still refusing\nto endorse five months after it was signed.\n    '
data: "In Manila's case, about 40 pct of the 15 billion dlrs\noutstanding t"
data: 'o commercial banks is owed to the 12 large banks\non the advisory co'
data: 'mmittee, while about 180 smaller banks have\naverage exposures of 20'
data: ' mln dlrs each.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

data: 'eutral zone output but not\nsales from floating storage, which are g'

start tag: <title>
data: 'GERMAN EUROBOND MARKET EXPECTS BREATHING SPACE'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Alice Ratcliffe, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    FRANKFURT, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'After an onslaught of new paper, fewer\nmark eurobonds issues are ex'
data: 'pected this week, bankers said.\n    Most managers said they were pl'
data: "anning a low issue volume\nfor the Bundesbank's two-week bond calend"
data: 'ar beginning today.\n    "We want to have a week\'s pause," one mana'
data: 'ger said.\n    Last week borrowings totalled 1.775 billion marks,\ni'
data: 'ncluding a 300 mln mark private placement for Deutsche Bank.\nIssues'
data: ' for all of February rose to nearly five billion marks,\nfrom 3.6 bi'
data: 'llion in January.\n    The heavy volume also meant most borrowers ex'
data: 'cept the very\nbest addresses were having to accept higher coupons.\n'
data: '    "I think the D-mark market is still good, but only if you\ncan g'
data: 'ive a good coupon," another manager said.\n    But even some governm'
data: 'ent borrowers were not getting the\nbest reception for bonds which w'
data: 'ould have been taken up more\nreadily under other conditions.\n    O'
data: 'f the three mark eurobonds launched on Tuesday alone,\nbonds for Den'
data: ' Danske Bank and Iceland were trading outside fees\non Friday, altho'
data: "ugh prices had recovered from initial lows.\n    Den Danske's 5-3/4 "
data: '1992 bond was quoted at midday on Friday\nat 97.35/65 compared with '
data: "its par price, and Iceland's 6-1/2\npct 1997 bond traded at 97.25/75"
data: ' against a 100-1/4 issue price.\n    A 300 mln mark 6-1/8 pct 1997 i'
data: 'ssue for Nippon Telegraph\nand Telephone was also depressed, but tra'
data: 'ded Friday within fees\nat 98.15, 98.50 from its par price.\n    Som'
data: 'e shorter maturities did better. In contrast to the\n10-year NTT and'
data: ' Iceland issues, a five-year six pct bond for\nHoogovens, traded at '
data: '98.40/75 from its 99-1/2 price, thanks\nmainly to its shorter maturi'
data: 'ty, dealers said.\n    The large amount of paper brought to the mark'
data: 'et in the last\ntwo months has also led many syndicate managers to c'
data: "omplain\nabout the Bundesbank's present fixed calendar system, which"
data: '\nthey say is too inflexible.\n    Currently all mark denominated eu'
data: 'robonds have to be\nregistered with the Bundesbank in the week prece'
data: 'ding the\ntwo-week issue period. A bank may decline to issue a bond '
data: 'on\nthe requested day in the calendar, but then has to wait for the\n'
data: 'next calendar period to schedule the bond again.\n    Some managers '
data: 'said they would prefer to abolish the system.\n    The Bundesbank sh'
data: 'ortened the reporting period to two weeks\nfrom four weeks last July'
data: '. But few expect the calendar to be\ncompletely abolished. "I don\'t'
data: ' think the Bundesbank would give\nthat up," one banking analyst said'
data: '.\n    "I wouldn\'t have anything against getting rid of the system,'
data: '"\nthe analyst said, adding banks were capable of regulating the\nvo'
data: 'lume of new issues themselves.\n    The Bundesbank plays a passive r'
data: 'ole in setting the calendar\nwithout trying to regulate the issues, '
data: 'but it needs the\nregistration to gauge the volume of mark bonds goi'
data: 'ng through\nthe euromarket, he said.\n    For this reason, few manag'
data: 'ers here foresee the Bundesbank\nsacrificing its present calendar sy'
data: 'stem.\n    Bond activity in West German bond trading and syndication'
data: '\ndepartments is also expected to be quieter than normal owing to\nt'
data: 'he carnival holiday.\n    Carnival will close banks in Duesseldorf a'
data: 'll day on Monday.\nIn Frankfurt, banks will close on Tuesday in the '
data: 'afternoon.\n REUTER\n\x03'

end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Iraq has secured agreement to defer\noutstanding payments on a 500 m'
data: 'ln dlr syndicated euroloan\nfollowing five months of negotiations wi'
data: 'th creditor banks.\n    Banking sources said the rescheduling is par'
data: "t of Iraq's\ncontinuing effort to defer payments of foreign debt as "
data: 'its\neconomy comes under strain from the  Gulf War and soft world\no'
data: 'il prices.\n    Iraq informed the 37 banks in the loan syndicate las'
data: 't\nSeptember it could not meet the remaining four principal\nrepayme'
data: 'nts totalling 285 mln dlrs, and missed the first of\nthese for 71.25'
data: ' mln due on September 29.\n    The 500 mln dlr credit, under the lea'
data: 'd management of\nParis-based Union de Banques Arabes et Francaises ('
data: 'UBAF), has a\nfive-year maturity and a margin of one percentage poin'
data: 't over\nLondon Interbank Offered Rates (LIBOR).\n    Banking sources'
data: ' said the agreement now worked out goes some\nway to meeting credito'
data: 'r bank demands that at least part of the\nfirst missing instalment o'
data: 'f 71.25 mln dlrs be paid and not\ndeferred.\n    One quarter or 17.8'
data: ' mln dlrs will be paid on signature of\nthe accord, expected in late'
data: ' March, with the remainder in three\nmore instalments to be made eve'
data: 'ry six months.\n    The remaining three principal instalments - orig'
data: 'inally due\nin March 1987, September 1987 and March 1988 - will each'
data: ' be\ndeferred for two years from the due date, banking sources said.'
data: '\n    The margin for the loan remains unchanged and no penalty\ninte'
data: 'rest is being imposed, the sources added.\n    Bank reaction to Iraq'
data: "'s rescheduling request has been one\nof resignation, with many bank"
data: "ers seeing little alternative for\nBaghdad's economic planners. Iraq"
data: ' is estimated to have foreign\ndebt of about 50 billion dlrs, althou'
data: 'gh about half is thought\nto be in the form of loans from its Gulf A'
data: 'rab allies,\nparticularly Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.\n    The 500 mln '
data: 'dlr credit is in the name of the state-owned\nRafidain Bank. The onl'
data: 'y other major eurocredit, a 500 mln dlr\ndeal under the agency of Gu'
data: 'lf International Bank, was signed in\nOctober, 1985 and is still in '
data: "a two year grace period.\n    The bulk of Iraq's commercial debt - e"
data: 'xcluding loans by its\nallies in the Gulf War - is in the form of tr'
data: 'ade financing.\n    But Rafidain bank stopped paying debt due on let'
data: 'ters of\ncredit last March and a series of negotiations with banks a'
data: 'nd\nwestern government export credit agencies has been underway.\nSo'
data: 'me banks have agreed to a three-year deferrment of\nobligations due '
data: 'on letters of credit.\n REUTER\n\x03'

data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    LONDON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Talks on coffee export quotas at the\nInternational Coffee Organizat'
data: 'ion (ICO) special council session\nwill resume at noon gmt today, fo'
data: 'llowing a last minute decision\ntaken early this morning to extend t'
data: 'he meeting 24 hours, ICO\nofficials said.\n    An 18 member contact '
data: 'group will meet at midday to examine\nnew ideas, and the full counci'
data: 'l is to convene at 1900gmt, they\nsaid.\n    The extension resulted '
data: 'from a last ditch effort by Colombia\nto salvage the talks, which by'

data: ' on quotas, delegates said.\n REUTER\n\x03'

end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'JAPAN PLANS MORE FLEXIBLE CORPORATE BOND ISSUES'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Yoshiko Mori, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    TOKYO, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Japanese securities houses will issue new\ncorporate bonds more quic'
data: 'kly, accept issue requests throughout\nthe month instead of at month'
data: '-end and introduce a competitive\nunderwriting method from April 1, '
data: 'to bring Japanese firms back\nto the Tokyo bond market, securities m'
data: 'anagers said.\n    Domestic issues have slowed to a trickle as more '
data: 'and more\ncompanies turn to more flexible overseas markets for cash,'
data: ' but\nthe proposed moves are expected to pave the way for a review o'
data: 'f\npublic bond issues, they said.\n    "Relaxation of issue rules wo'
data: 'uld be better applied not only\nto straight corporate bonds, but als'
data: 'o convertible bonds and\nwarrant bonds, to call back issuers effecti'
data: 'vely from overseas\nmarkets," a Nikko Securities house bond manager '
data: 'said.\n    Securities houses will launch an issue about 10 days afte'
data: 'r\na corporate declaration of intent instead of 25 days as now,\nthe'
data: ' securities managers said.\n    Underwriters are expected to abolish'
data: ' the lump-sum issuance\nsystem, in which all corporate bonds are iss'
data: 'ued at month-end,\nand accept issue requests during the month, they '
data: 'said.\n    Securities houses also plan to introduce free competition'
data: '\namong underwriters when negotiating with issuers over terms in\nor'
data: 'der to better reflect the market, securities managers said.\n    Mar'
data: 'ket participants expect the new issue methods to be\napplied beginni'
data: 'ng in April, with the projected issue by <Nippon\nTelegraph and Tele'
data: 'phone Corp>.\n    The so-called proposal method abolishes the practi'
data: 'ce of\ntaking lead-managership and enables more market-oriented\ndec'
data: 'isions on terms, securities sources said.\n    The four major Japane'
data: 'se securities houses now take turns\nunderwriting corporate bonds.\n'
data: '    Setting issue terms using financial criteria prepared by\nsecuri'
data: 'ties houses and in reference to coupon rates on latest\npublic bonds'
data: ' is now almost automatic, they said.\n    The new moves are based on'
data: ' wide-ranging proposals made in\nlate December by advisers to Financ'
data: 'e Minister Kiichi Miyazawa.\nThey were aimed at revitalising the dom'
data: 'estic corporate bond\nmarket, securities house managers said.\n    T'
data: 'he finance ministry, commissioned banks and securities\nhouses agree'
data: 'd in January to lower the eligibility ceiling for\ncompanies wanting'
data: ' to issue non-collateral straight and\nconvertible bonds from March '
data: '1, securities managers said.\n    The cut will more than double the '
data: 'number of corporations\nable to make non-collateral issues from arou'
data: 'nd 70 for straight\nbonds and 180 for convertibles now, securities m'
data: 'anagers said.\n    The Bond Market Committee of the Securities Excha'
data: 'nge\nCouncil also recommended introduction of a shelf registration\n'
data: 'system, more use of corporate ratings systems and\nsimplification of'
data: ' disclosure rules to help speed up the issuing\nprocess, securities '
data: 'sources said.\n    It also called for a major review of the commissi'
data: 'oned bank\nsystem, which increases the cost of issuing domestic bond'
data: 's, and\nfor deregulation of private placements, they said.\n    Some'
data: ' of these proposals are likely to take some time to put\ninto effect'
data: ', the sources said. A shelf registration system\nwould need a revisi'
data: 'on of Japanese commercial law, expected in\n1988, the sources said.\n'
data: ' REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The start of trading on the new\nSingapore Government Securities Mar'
data: 'ket has been postponed until\nlate March or early April because legi'
data: 'slative amendments still\nneed parliamentary approval, banking sourc'
data: 'es said.\n    The new bill market, intended to establish a base for '
data: 'a\nwider capital market and to encourage private bond issues in\nSin'
data: 'gapore, was supposed to be launched today.\n    William K.K. Wong, m'
data: 'anaging director of Indosuez Asia\n(Singapore) Ltd, said there is no'

data: 'trade, he said.\n    Lawrence Yeo, director of Citicorp Investment B'
data: "ank\n(Singapore) Ltd, said the market's success depends on domestic\n"
data: 'participation.\n    The five primary dealers and the three registere'
data: 'd dealers\nwill all be local companies.\n    The primary dealers are'
data: ' <Commercial Discount Co Ltd>,\n<National Discount Co Ltd>, Oversea-'
data: 'Chinese Banking Corp Ltd\n<OCBM.SI>, <Overseas Union Bank Ltd> and U'
data: 'nited Overseas Bank\nLtd <UOBM.SI>. They will underwrite the Monetar'
data: 'y Authority of\nSingapore (MAS) auctions, maintain market liquidity '
data: 'and channel\nopen-market operations, MAS said.\n    <Citicorp Invest'

data: 'edit Suisse First Boston Asia Ltd> will\nbe recognised as registered'
data: ' dealers. They will act as market\nmakers but will not bid directly '
data: 'at auctions.\n    MAS plans to launch trading by issuing taxable ins'

data: '38\nbillion dlrs of paper over the first five years.\n    Non-compet'
data: 'itive bids from primary dealers prepared to\naccept average yield wi'
data: 'll be allocated first, to a maximum\n500,000 dlrs for notes and bond'
data: 's and to an unlimited amount for\ntreasury bills.\n    The remaining'
data: ' amount will be awarded to competitive bidders\nfrom the lowest yiel'
data: 'd upwards.\n    In the secondary market, the standard lot traded bet'
data: 'ween\ndealers will be one mln dlrs worth of treasury bills and\n500,'

data: 'ill likely continue during 1986/87 since\ndomestic soyfood processor'

data: 'it said.\n    Area planted is expected to increase by 10 pct in both'
data: '\n1986/87 and 1987/88.\n    "Yield increases continue to be hampered'

data: 'sponse will be very negative," the senior\nofficial said.\n    Banki'
data: 'ng sources said some 80 pct of international creditor\nbanks involve'

end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Yuko Nakamikado, Reuters'

data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    TOKYO, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone is likely\nto leave office this sum'
data: 'mer amid opposition to his\ncontroversial tax-reform package, politi'
data: "cal analysts said.\n    They said Nakasone's reputation as a skilled"
data: ' politician has\nsuffered irreparable damage from his support of a f'
data: 'ive pct\nsales tax planned for January 1988.\n    "Nakasone is tryin'
data: 'g to carry out a drastic tax reform at the\nend of his administratio'
data: 'n, which is not only impossible but\nalso is very irresponsible as a'
data: ' politican," Rei Shiratori,\nprofessor of politics at Dokkyo Univers'
data: 'ity, told Reuters.\n    "Nakasone will almost certainly step down as'
data: ' soon as\nparliament approves the sales tax, probably in the summer,'
data: '"\nShiratori said.\n    Some ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) m'
data: 'embers of\nparliament have spoken against the tax, which Nakasone sa'
data: 'ys is\nneeded to balance planned cuts in income and corporate taxes.'
data: '\n    Nakasone today called for disciplinary action against LDP\nmem'
data: 'bers who oppose the tax. "There are some who are objecting\nbecause '
data: 'of their constituencies," he told a meeting of\ngovernment and party'
data: ' leaders. "If the party discipline is\nbroken, I would like to see p'
data: 'unishment considered."\n    "A proposed sales tax has become a polit'
data: 'ical issue, partly\nbecause Nakasone breached his election pledge ag'
data: 'ainst\nintroducing it," Shiratori said.\n    "Moreover, the tax is b'
data: 'eing introduced when the public feels\nuncertainty about the sluggis'
data: "h economy stemming from the yen's\nappreciation and about the future"
data: ' when the Japanese society is\nrapidly aging," he said.\n    Politic'
data: 'al analysts said the controversial tax could affect\nthe more than 2'
data: ',500 local elections scheduled for April,\ninvolving governors, mayo'
data: 'rs, town and village heads and\nassemblies at all levels.\n    But t'
data: 'he situation is complicated, since opposition parties\nexcluding the'
data: ' communists sometimes put up joint candidates with\nthe LDP, the pol'
data: 'itical analysts added.\n    Shiratori said, "In the worst case, impl'
data: 'ementation of the\nsales tax, now scheduled for next January, may be'
data: ' put off for\nsome time before the government makes a final decision'
data: '.\n    "Another alternative is to modify the planned five pct to\npe'
data: 'rhaps three pct.\n    "A third alternative for the government is to '
data: 'ram through\nthe bills only with the attendance of LDP MPs," he said'
data: '.\n    Seizaburo Sato, professor of politics at Tokyo University,\nt'
data: 'hought the last possibility most likely. "I think the LDP alone\nwil'
data: 'l take a vote on the tax bills," he said.\n    The LDP now holds 304'
data: ' seats in the 512-seat Lower House and\n143 in the 252-seat Upper Ho'
data: 'use.\n    To lure opposition parties back to parliament after the LD'
data: 'P\npushes through the tax bills, the Nakasone cabinet will have to\n'
data: 'resign, Sato said.\n    "Boycotting opposition members will be more '
data: 'willing to\nreturn to parliament if a new cabinet has been formed," '
data: 'he said.\n REUTER\n\x03'
