start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'ATPC MEMBERS FIND WAYS TO CURB TIN EXPORTS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Rajan Moses, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    KUALA LUMPUR, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Mine and industry officials from\nmost member states of the Associat'
data: 'ion of Tin Producing\nCountries (ATPC) say they have found ways to l'
data: 'imit group\nexports to 96,000 tonnes in the year started March 1, ac'
data: 'cording\nto views polled by Reuter correspondents.\n    The plan to '
data: 'curb exports, agreed in January, is aimed at\ncutting the world surp'
data: 'lus to 50,000 tonnes from 70,000 now and\nboosting prices to about 1'
data: '9 ringgit a kilo from just over 16.\n    Members of the seven-member'
data: " Kuala Lumpur-based ATPC account\nfor some 65 pct of the world's tin"
data: ' output.\n    Under the ATPC plan, Malaysia has been allocated an ex'
data: 'port\nquota of 28,526 tonnes, Indonesia 24,516, Thailand 19,000,\nBo'
data: 'livia 13,761, Zaire 1,736 and Nigeria 1,461.\n    Australia has said'
data: ' it is not setting any export quota.\nHowever, the tonnage allocated'
data: ' to it, 7,000 tonnes, is roughly\nequal to its expected output this '
data: 'year.\n    Comment from officials in Zaire was unavailable.\n    Min'
data: "e officials in Malaysia, the world's leading producer,\nsaid only 18"
data: '8 mines will be allowed to operate to ensure that\noutput is limited'
data: ' to around 31,500 tonnes in the year started\nMarch 1.\n    Chief In'
data: 'spector of Mines Redzuan Sumun told Reuters that\nexcess output of s'
data: 'ome 3,000 tonnes after exports of 28,500 in\nthe one-year quota peri'
data: 'od would be kept in the national stock.\n    Mine owners in Malaysia'
data: ' have welcomed the ATPC export curb\nand asked the government not to'
data: ' issue new mining licences. More\nthan 100 applications for licences'
data: ' are pending.\n    Redzuan said the Mines Department would approve n'
data: 'ew mining\nlicences only if a six-month review of production trends '
data: 'showed\nthat local mines were not overproducing.\n    ATPC chairman '
data: "and Indonesia's Mining and Energy Minister\nSubroto has pledged his "
data: "country's support for the export curb.\n    A spokesman for the stat"
data: 'e-owned tin mining company PT\nTambang Timah told Reuters it would b'
data: 'e easy for Indonesia to\nstick to an export quota of 24,516 tonnes b'
data: 'ecause this was\nclose to exports in calendar 1986 of 24,636.\n    I'
data: 'n Bangkok, Thai Industry Minister Pramual Sabhavasu said\nThailand w'
data: 'ould keep to its 19,000 tonne quota and added this\nwould not cause '
data: 'the local industry hardship at current prices.\n    To insure adhere'
data: 'nce, the industry ministry and sole tin\nexporter Thailand Smelting '
data: 'and Refining Co would encourage\nbigger stockpiles, and income tax e'
data: 'xemptions would be\npermitted, he said.\n    The Thai Mineral Resour'
data: 'ces Department is expected to\ndisallow new tin mines opening this y'
data: 'ear to prevent excessive\nproduction, industry sources said.\n    Bu'
data: 't Mining Industry Council President Dam Teutong told\nReuters that i'
data: 'f the tin price rose above 18 ringgit a kilo,\nThai miners would pre'
data: 'ss for the opening of more new mines.\n    Thailand exported 18,367 '
data: 'tonnes in 1986, up from 17,359 in\n1985, Pramual said.\n    Bolivia '
data: 'said it expects to export less tin this year than\nits allocated 13,'
data: '761 tonne quota.\n    Mining Minister Jaimie Villalobos told Reuters'
data: ' in La Paz\nthat Bolivia expected to export about 9,000 tonnes of ti'
data: 'n in\ncalendar 1987.\n    He said this was due to the sacking after '
data: 'the tin crisis of\nOctober 1985 of about 20,000 of the 28,000 worker'
data: 's at the state\nmining company Comibol, which produces more than 80 '
data: "pct of\nBolivia's total exports.\n    He said there were risks in th"
data: 'e ATPC plan to cut exports\nbut added he was confident the goals set'
data: ' by the plan would be\nachieved. He did not elaborate.\n    Mines, P'
data: 'ower and Steel Minister Bunu Sheriff Musa said in\nLagos that Nigeri'
data: 'a would have no difficulty keeping within its\nATPC quota of 1,461 t'
data: 'onnes because its metals output had\ndeclined due to poor demand and'
data: ' high production costs.\n    Industry sources told Reuters that Nige'
data: "ria's output was\nless than 1,000 tonnes last year.\n    ATPC offici"
data: "als said they would monitor member countries'\nexport figures every "
data: 'three months using customs documents and\nmake projections from such'
data: ' data to see if quotas were likely to\nbe breached within the year-l'
data: 'ong quota period.\n    The ATPC officials said members that appeared'
data: ' likely to\nbreach their quotas would be told to take remedial measu'
data: 'res.\n    They added that if member countries were unable to fulfil\n'
data: 'their quotas their extra tonnage would be reallocated to other\nmemb'
data: "ers at the ATPC's discretion.\n    The ATPC would have produced and "
data: 'exported an estimated\n106,000 tonnes of tin in 1987 without the pla'
data: 'n.\n    Non-members Brazil and China have pledged to cooperate with\n'
data: 'the ATPC and limit their exports to 21,000 and 7,000 tonnes\nrespect'
data: 'ively during the quota period.\n REUTER\n\x03'

data: ' would definitely sit on the SMC board despite the\nobjections of so'

data: 'a conflict of interest as such," he\nsaid.\n    "I was potentially c'

data: 'phere on the board. But Sy has\nassured (the government) that he doe'

data: 'ctorship. Its lawyer said in a letter to the PCGG that\na pending su'
data: "it seeking forfeiture of SMC's 500 mln peso deposit\nand major undis"
data: 'closed damages against the brewery represented a\nclear conflict.\n '
data: "   UCPB, however, sought board representation before Sy's\nappointme"

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'INDIAN BUDGET DEFICIT SEEN FUELING INFLATION'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Ajoy Sen, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    NEW DELHI, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's fiscal\n1987/88 budget has sparked spe"
data: "culation that a large deficit\nwill push up India's moderate inflati"
data: "on rate and that the\ncountry's stock markets will experience prolon"
data: 'ged uncertainty,\neconomists, politicians and stockbrokers told Reut'
data: 'ers.\n    The projected deficit for fiscal 1987/88, ending March, is'
data: '\n56.88 billion rupees, down from an upwardly revised estimate of\na'
data: ' record 82.85 billion in fiscal 1986/87.\n    The projected inflatio'
data: 'n rate for fiscal 1986/87, based on\nwholesale prices, is 6.5 pct ag'
data: 'ainst 3.8 pct in 1985/86.\n    Economists pointed out that the gover'
data: 'nment itself had\nexpressed concern about inflation in its most rece'
data: 'nt 1986/87\neconomic survey report published last week.\n    Present'
data: 'ing the budget to parliament on Saturday, Prime\nMinister Gandhi sai'
data: 'd a cabinet committee would be appointed to\ntrim large non-developm'
data: 'ent expenditures. The deficit for\n1987/88 will not be allowed to ex'
data: 'ceed the budgeted figure, he\nsaid.\n    But few analysts have taken'
data: " Gandhi's assurance seriously.\nThey say the deficit more than doubl"
data: 'ed in 1986/87 from an\ninitial estimate of 36.5 billion rupees.\n   '
data: ' Lal Krishna Advani, president of the opposition Bharatiya\nJanata p'
data: "arty, said Gandhi's failure to mention specific\nmeasures to cut non"
data: '-development expenses will push up prices.\n    Economists said incr'
data: 'eased liquidity in the economy, as\nreflected by expansion of the M3'
data: ' aggregate money supply, may\ncause prices to rise. The survey repor'
data: 't showed the M3 rose by\n15.7 pct or 185.78 billion rupees in the fi'
data: 'rst nine months of\n1986/87 against 13.37 pct or 136.42 billion in t'
data: 'he same 1985/86\nperiod.\n    Economists also said uncertain monsoon'
data: ' rain prospects,\nafter bad weather last year, may strain prices fur'
data: 'ther.\n    Economists said the deficit would also cause the governme'
data: 'nt\nto rely increasingly on internal borrowing. Market loans and\nbo'
data: 'nds were projected at 981.50 billion rupees for 1987/88, up\nfrom th'
data: 'e 1986/87 estimate of 852.13 billion.\n    No reduction has been pro'
data: 'posed in personal income taxes,\nwhich will discourage savings, econ'
data: 'omists said.\n    Avinash Purulkar, chief manager of the state-owned'
data: ' Union\nBank of India, said the annual inflation rate may double to\n'
data: 'around 15 pct in 1987/88 as the government prints more currency\nnot'
data: 'es to cover the deficit.\n    Brokers said stock market investors ha'
data: 've started selling\nlong-term portfolios to take advantage of a prop'
data: 'osal in the\nbudget that reduces the holding period required to clai'
data: 'm\nexemption from the capital gains tax to one year from three.\n   '
data: ' Delhi stockbroker B. D. Aggarwal said, "There is uncertainty\nin th'
data: 'e market. There is going to be growing selling pressure."\n    But B'
data: 'ombay broker Dinesh Walji said the present hectic\nselling of shares'
data: ' will slow when more buyers appear on the\nscene. "Just now there is'
data: ' acute nervousness in the market," he\nsaid.\n    Brokers said propo'
data: 'sals to set up a mutual fund to help\nsmall investors buy equity sha'
data: 'res and relaxations in the\ncapital gains tax will inject further bu'
data: 'oyancy into the market\non a long-term basis.\n    New equity and de'
data: 'benture issues, both convertible and\nnon-convertible, rose to an of'
data: 'ficially estimated 50.70 billion\nrupees in April/January 1986/87 fr'
data: 'om an estimated 36.95 billion\nin all 1985/86 and 20 billion in all '
data: '1984/85.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'JAPAN TO PROMOTE INTEREST RATE LIBERALISATION'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    TOKYO, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The Bank of Japan decided at a policy\nboard meeting to promote furt'
data: 'her interest rate liberalisation\nby lowering the minimum denominati'
data: 'on of regulation-free large\ndeposits and by raising the interest ra'
data: 'te ceiling on money\nmarket certificates (MMCs), a central bank offi'
data: 'cial said.\n    The new guideline will go into effect on April 6, th'
data: 'e bank\nsaid.\n    Under the guideline, the minimum denomination of\n'
data: 'regulation-free large deposits will be lowered to 100 mln yen\nfrom '
data: '300 mln.\n    The interest rate ceiling of MMCs with maturities of\n'
data: 'between one year and two years will be set at 0.5 percentage\npoint '
data: 'below the prevailing certificate of deposit rate, the\nbank said.\n '
data: '   But the ceiling on MMCs with maturities of one year or less\nwill'
data: ' remain the same, or 0.75 percentage point below the CD\nrates.\n   '
data: ' The minimum denomination of MMCs will be lowered to 10 mln\nyen fro'
data: 'm 30 mln.\n    The bank also said time deposit rates will be lowered'
data: ' by\n0.37 point, effective March 16, in line with the half-point cut'
data: '\nin the official discount rate on February 23.\n    New interest ra'
data: 'tes on two-year and one-year deposits at\nbanks, for example, will b'
data: 'e 3.64 pct and 3.39 pct per annum,\nrespectively.\n    Demand deposi'
data: 't rates, however, will remain the same.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'
end tag: </reuters>
data: '\n'

data: 'ution to the growth\nin Sterling M3 was contractionary by about 2.3 '
data: 'billion stg.\n    Within this, the Public Sector Borrowing Requireme'

data: 'EXCO BUYS U.S. GOVERNMENT SECURITIES BROKER'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    LONDON, Mar 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: '<Exco International Plc>, a subsidiary of\nBritish and Commonwealth '
data: 'Shipping Co Plc <BCOM.L>, said it had\nagreed in principle to buy an'
data: ' 80 pct stake in <RMJ Holdings\nCorp> for about 79 mln dlrs.\n    Ex'
data: 'co Chairman Richard Lacy told Reuters the acquisition was\nbeing mad'
data: 'e from Bank of New York Co Inc <BK.N>, which currently\nholds a 50.1'
data: ' pct, and from RMJ partners who hold the remainder.\n    Bank of New'
data: ' York and the partners will retain about 10 pct\neach and these stak'
data: 'es will be bought over the next six years.\n    RMJ is the holding c'
data: 'ompany of RMJ Securities, one of the\nlargest U.S. Government securi'
data: 'ties brokers.\n    It is also involved in broking notes, obligations'
data: ' and other\ninstruments sponsored by U.S. Federal agencies.\n    Lac'
data: 'y said Exco had been considering buying a U.S.\nGovernment securitie'
data: 's broker for the past four years and had\nmade an offer for RMJ when'
data: ' it was sold by Security Pacific Corp\n<SPC.N> in 1985. RMJ was then'
data: ' valued at about 50 mln dlrs.\n    B and C managing director Peter G'
data: 'oldie said RMJ would be\nbought at about the same multiple as Exco, '
data: "suggesting net\nincome of around 16 mln dlrs.\n    The company's ear"
data: 'nings had not been hit by the halving of\nbrokerage fees some 14 mon'
data: 'ths ago as volumes had since doubled.\n    Lacy said that RMJ employ'
data: 'ed some 300 people, with 200 in\nthe brokerage business and about 70'
data: ' in its <SMS> unit, which\nprovided computer software for the financ'
data: 'ial services\ncommunity.\n    RMJ Securities had offices in New York'
data: ', where total market\nturnover of U.S. Government securities was 110'
data: ' billion dlrs a\nday, and in London where it has 15 billion.\n    It'
data: ' was also given permission last week to open an office in\nTokyo whe'
data: 're total market turnover had lifted rapidly to about\nfive billion d'

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'ECONOMIC SPOTLIGHT - AUSTERITY MEASURES IN HUNGARY'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By David Lewis, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    BUDAPEST, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Hungary is to embark on a new series of\nausterity measures to tackl'
data: 'e a budget deficit which tripled\nlast year after quadrupling in 198'
data: '5.\n    The target deficit in the 1987 budget approved by\nParliamen'
data: 't last December was 43.8 billion forints.\n    But Zoltan Boesze, ch'
data: "ief of the Finance Ministry's budget\nfinancing division, told Reute"
data: 'rs the government now saw this as\ntoo high and had decided "quite s'
data: 'evere" measures were needed.\n    "All the organizations of economic'
data: ' management have been\ncharged with elaborating further (savings) me'
data: 'asures," he said.\n    Asked if these measures were being taken unde'
data: 'r pressure\nfrom the International Monetary Fund (IMF), Boesze said:'
data: ' "The\nFund suggested it would be good to improve monetary results,\n'
data: 'and of course the Fund would support these efforts."\n    IMF teams '
data: 'spent several weeks in Budapest late last year.\n    Boesze said pre'
data: "liminary figures showed that Hungary's state\nbudget deficit rose to"
data: ' a preliminary 47 billion forints last\nyear from 15.8 billion in 19'
data: '85 and 3.7 billion in 1984.\n    The economy overshot a target defic'
data: 'it of 23 billion forints\nbecause of poor performance by state firms'
data: ', which needed\nsubsidies and tax incentives to export and earn hard'
data: ' currency.\n    The exact extent and nature of savings are still und'
data: 'er\ndiscussion but subsidies to state enterprises -- the largest\nbu'
data: 'dget item -- must definitely fall, Boesze said.\n    Subsidies to st'
data: 'ate firms, including grants to maintain low\nconsumer prices, exceed'
data: 'ed the plan by nine billion to reach 164\nbillion forints in 1986, u'
data: 'p from 152.9 billion in 1985.\nParliament approved 1987 subsidies of'
data: ' 170 billion forints.\n    "I think that in 1987 it is quite impossi'
data: 'ble to keep up the\nformer situation and we will be obliged to reduc'
data: 'e subsidies,"\nBoesze said. "The central administration must be hard'
data: '. ... If we\nare not hard then we will not be successful."\n    Boes'
data: 'ze said the budget could also make savings from reserve\nprovisions '
data: 'of two billion forints for central expenditure and\n800 mln forints '
data: 'for transfers to local authorities. "I believe\nthese reserves shoul'
data: 'd not be used at all," he said.\n    Wage growth last year outstripp'
data: 'ed that of gross domestic\nproduct, which expanded one pct instead o'
data: 'f a planned 2.5 pct.\n    The authorities had already signalled a sm'
data: 'all fall in real\nwages for 1987, but Boesze said firms will suffer '
data: 'severe tax\npenalties if they award nominal rises of over one or two'
data: ' pct.\n    This would mean a severe cut in living standards, as reta'
data: 'il\nprice inflation is forecast at seven pct after 5.3 pct in 1986.\n'
data: '    A four-month basic wage freeze expires on April 1.\n    About 40'
data: ' pct of the 1986 subsidies to state enterprises and\n33 pct in 1985 '
data: 'were made to maintain low consumer prices.\n    Boesze said pure eco'
data: 'nomic policy would dictate significant\ncuts in price subsidies, but'
data: ' that social considerations made\nthis difficult.\n    But he added:'
data: ' "I think ultimately we will be able to make\ncurtailments in subsid'
data: 'ies in this area as well."\n    He said Hungary plans to introduce p'
data: 'rice reform at the\nbeginning of 1988 at the same time as personal t'
data: 'axation and\nvalue added tax. The IMF supports these aims.\n    Hung'
data: 'ary introduced a bankrupcty law last September in an\nattempt to sha'
data: 'ke out surplus labour from inefficient firms.\n    Between 100,000 a'
data: 'nd 150,000 workers are expected to be\nunemployed at least temporari'
data: 'ly by 1990. Labour discipline is\nbeing tightened and firms may fire'
data: ' workers more easily.\n    Boesze said the per capita employment tax'
data: ' paid to the state\nby firms was being raised this year to encourage'
data: ' enterprises to\nshed labour. He gave no exact figures.\n    Istvan '
data: 'Nagy, a senior Finance Ministry official responsible\nfor drafting t'
data: 'he bankrupcy law, told Reuters last year he hoped\nthe law would cut'
data: ' state subsidies to enterprises by 50 pct.\n    After subsidies to s'
data: 'tate enterprises, the largest single\nbudget items are social insura'
data: 'nce (153 billion forints approved\nfor 1987) and transfers to local '
data: 'councils (80 billion).\n    Interest payments on international debt '
data: 'are set to rise to\nmore than 10 billion forints in 1987 from betwee'
data: "n six and seven\nbillion in 1986, Boesze said.\n    Hungary's net ha"
data: 'rd currency debt leapt by 54 pct last year\nto 7.7 billion dlrs, acc'
data: 'ording to provisional figures, while\ntrade with Western countries p'
data: 'lunged into a deficit of more\nthan 400 mln dlrs from a 1.2 billion '
data: "dlr surplus just two years\nearlier.\n    Boesze said last year's bu"
data: 'dget deficit was financed 90 pct\nby credits from the National Bank,'
data: ' mostly from abroad, and 10\npct by the issue of domestic state bond'
data: 's.\n    Deputy Prime Minister Frigyes Berecz told Hungarian\neconomi'
data: 'sts in a speech this month that the country\'s economy\nwas in a "ve'
data: 'ry difficult" situation, but not in crisis.\n    There would have to'
data: ' be a turnround with tangible results\nthis year, however, and borro'
data: 'wing must be used more\neffectively.\n    "Any rise in our present l'
data: 'oans may prove to be dangerous,"\nBerecz said.\n REUTER\n\x03'

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'DIGITAL AUDIO TAPE PLAYERS GO ON SALE IN JAPAN'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Steven Brull, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    TOKYO, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Japanese consumers hesitated about buying\nthe controversial digital'
data: ' audio tape player (DAT) as it went on\nsale in Tokyo today, but sai'
data: "d the DAT player's near-perfect\nsound will make it a success once i"
data: 't becomes cheaper.\n    "The sound is great, but I\'ll wait until mo'
data: 're machines hit\nthe market and prices fall to about 100,000 yen bef'
data: 'ore buying\none," said Terumi Fujitsuka, 35, a steel firm employee.\n'
data: '    Aiwa, Sharp and Matsushita displayed their DAT players\ntoday al'
data: "though delivery will take about two weeks, retailers\nsaid. Aiwa's m"
data: 'achine, the cheapest, is listed at 188,000 yen.\n    Machines by Son'
data: 'y, Hitachi, Toshiba and others will appear\nas early as the end of M'
data: 'arch, industry sources said.\n    DAT players can play back and reco'
data: 'rd with fidelity superior\nto even a compact disc. They use a casset'
data: 'te half the size of\nthe standard audio cassette and unlike conventi'
data: 'onal analogue\nmachines, they can make copies an infinite number of '
data: 'times with\nalmost no loss of sound quality.\n    This aroused fears'
data: ' in the music industry of widespread tape\npiracy and loss of royalt'
data: "ies. In negotiations that delayed the\nDAT player's debut, the indus"
data: 'try demanded anti-piracy circuitry\nbe built into the machines.\n   '
data: ' Machines sold in Japan are fitted with a computer chip to\nprevent '
data: 'copying through a digital signal. But copies can still\nbe made if t'
data: 'he signal is routed through a regular amplifier.\n"Nobody can tell t'
data: 'he difference," one salesman said.\n    DAT players have been kept o'
data: 'ff Western markets and some\ncountries are considering banning them '
data: 'or imposing heavy duties\nunless tougher anti-piracy circuitry is ad'
data: 'ded. But Japanese\nhardware makers, hard pressed for profits in the '
data: 'era of the\nhigh yen and growing competition, are eager to carve out'
data: ' a\nprofitable niche.\n    Prices of DAT players will probably fall '
data: 'quickly, possibly\nto around 70,000 yen by next year as other makers'
data: ' put their\nproducts on the market, industry analysts said.\n    The'
data: 'y said by 1990, sales could reach six mln units per\nyear.\n    Phil'
data: 'ips of the Netherlands has said it will launch its DAT\nplayer on th'
data: 'e world market later this year.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'
end tag: </reuters>

data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'ECONOMIC SPOTLIGHT - ITALIAN BOOM'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Jane Leach, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    ROME, March 2  - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "Italy's strong economic revival has led\nsome observers to talk of m"
data: 'iracles and created euphoria in some\nquarters about future growth p'
data: 'rospects, but many Italian\nexperts warn that the current wave of op'
data: 'timism is excessive.\n    "I think all this foreign interest in the '
data: 'so-called Italian\nmiracle is really exaggerated...Foreign observers'
data: ' always\noscillate in the case of Italy between complete pessimism a'
data: 'nd\nunwarranted optimism," says Luigi Spaventa, one of Italy\'s\nlea'
data: 'ding economists and a professor at Rome University.\n    According t'
data: 'o Spaventa, these violent swings of mood have\nbeen occurring for th'
data: 'e last 15 years, with Italy one minute\nseen as the "bad boy of Euro'
data: 'pe" and unable to raise a dollar and\nthe next a worker of miracles '
data: 'and basking in admiration,\n    "I think there\'s a lot of exaggerat'
data: 'ion...Once it used to be\nthe underground economy and all the corres'
data: 'pondents of foreign\nnewspapers flocked to Italy to study this. That'
data: ' was another\nstory about nothing - like writing about a black cat i'
data: 'n a dark\nroom."\n    Spaventa, in tune with other economists and in'
data: "dustrialists\nhere, stress Italy's recent achievements, particularly"
data: ' the\ndramatic and solid recovery in the fortunes of industrial\nent'
data: 'erprises, but warns that the economy is still vulnerable.\n     Prof'
data: 'its of private sector firms such as Fiat S.P.A.,\n<FIAT.M> and <ING.'
data: ' C. Olivetti and C. S.P.A.> are booming, the\nmajor state industries'
data: ' are back in the black after years of\nlosses, inflation has nosediv'
data: 'ed and the trade and balance of\npayments deficits have been slashed'
data: '. Expectations by some\nexperts that Italy is poised to replace Brit'
data: "ain as the world's\nfifth largest economy have also boosted optimism"
data: '.\n    Italy itself has made it clear it is not happy with what it\n'
data: 'feels to be its second-rate status among the major\nindustrialised c'
data: 'ountries.\n    Only this week, it angrily demanded clarification of '
data: 'this\nstatus after being excluded from a meeting of finance minister'
data: 's\nfrom the Group of Five (G-5) - comprising the United States,\nJap'
data: 'an, West Germany, France and Britain.\n    Italy said its exclusion '
data: 'from the meeting violated an\nagreement reached in Tokyo last year t'
data: 'o let Italy and Canada\nattend meetings held by the five whenever di'
data: 'scussions concerned\nmanaging the international monetary system.\n  '
data: '  But Italy needs first to tackle some fundamental problems\nstill f'
data: 'acing its economy, economists and industrialists say.\n    "We must '
data: 'not forget that ours is still a vulnerable economy,"\nwarns Fiat man'
data: "aging director Cesare Romiti.\n    He says that while Italy's recent"
data: ' achievements are indeed\ncause for satisfaction and optimism, the f'
data: 'ocus now should be on\nthe problems still remaining rather than thos'
data: "e already solved.\n    The country's huge state sector deficit, high"
data: ' unemployment\nand a heavy dependence on imported oil are among the '
data: 'most\nworrying problems, experts say.\n    The size of the state spe'
data: 'nding deficit -- estimated at\n109,561 billion lire in 1986 and targ'
data: 'etted at 100,000 billion\nlire this year -- means there is a risk in'
data: 'flation could spiral\nagain, says Carlo Scognamiglio, head of the pr'
data: 'ivate Luiss\nuniversity in Rome.\n    Inflation fell into single dig'
data: 'its for the first time in a\ndecade in September 1984 and by January'
data: ' this year was running\nat 4.5 pct, but it is still not low enough t'
data: 'o guarantee\ninternational competiveness, economists and industriali'
data: 'sts say.\n    And unemployment was running at 11.6 pct nationally la'
data: 'st\nOctober according to the latest official data.\n    Recent offic'
data: 'ial data showed that of a total 2.77 million\npeople seeking work in'
data: ' October 1986, almost 73 pct were aged\nbetween 14 and 29. Unemploym'
data: 'ent in the south was running at\n17.7 pct, more than double that in '
data: 'the industrial north.\n    The Organisation for Economic Cooperation'
data: ' and Development\n(OECD) recently forecast that Italian gross domest'
data: 'ic product\n(GDP) would rise rise three pct in 1987 after expanding '
data: '2.5 pct\nin 1986. But it warned that growth was unlikely to be enoug'
data: "h to\ncheck rising unemployment.\n    Another problem is Italy's rel"
data: 'iance on imported raw\nmaterials. The country imports around 80 pct '
data: 'of its fuel needs.\n    This factor actually worked sharply in Italy'
data: "'s favour last\nyear, when lower energy costs helped slash the count"
data: "ry's trade\ndeficit to 3,717 billion lire  by year end from 23,085 b"
data: 'illion\nlire in 1985.\n    But economists say the improvement owes l'
data: 'ittle to any\nstructural change in the Italian economy and that any '
data: 'reversal\nof the trend in costs could have serious consequences.\n  '
data: "  If Italy truly wants to be counted among the world's top\nindustri"
data: 'alised nations, it also needs to tighten up stockmarket\noperating p'
data: 'rocedures and encourage firms to supply more quality\ninformation ab'
data: 'out their activities, economists say.\n    Italy has no controls on '
data: 'insider trading.\n    The country also needs to shed its rigid capit'
data: 'al movements\ncontrols -- a European Community directive calls for t'
data: 'hese to\nbe dismantled by 1992 -- but this too will require a less\n'
data: 'blinkered attitude and a change in traditional operating\nprocedures'
data: ', economists say.\n    "Even today, if I wanted to invest in the Tok'
data: "yo bourse, I\ndoubt I'd find the expertise in a brokerage firm or in"
data: ' banks\nwhich would allow me to do that," says Spaventa.\n REUTER\n\x03'

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'JAPAN, U.S. SET TO BEGIN HIGH-LEVEL TRADE TALKS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Rich Miller, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    TOKYO, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Japan and the U.S. Kick off top-level\ntrade talks tomorrow amid sig'
data: 'ns officials from both sides are\ngrowing increasingly irritated wit'
data: 'h each other.\n    The talks, held annually at sub-cabinet level to '
data: 'review the\nwhole gamut of U.S./Japan economic relations, will pave '
data: "the way\nfor American Secretary of State George Schultz's one day\ns"
data: 'top-over here at end-week on his way home from China.\n    Faced wit'
data: 'h growing Congressional protectionist pressure,\nthe U.S. Administra'
data: 'tion is pressing Japan for speedy action to\nreduce its still huge t'
data: 'rade surplus, U.S. Officials said.\n    "We appreciate their frustra'
data: 'tion," a senior Japanese\ngovernment official said. "But we are also'
data: ' frustrated."\n    The official said the 40 pct rise of the yen over'
data: ' the last\n18 months has hit Japan hard, forcing exporters to slash\n'
data: 'spending and lay off workers to make up for lost sales abroad.\nThat'
data: ' has not yet shown up in dollar-based statistics on trade,\nbut it w'
data: 'ill, he said.\n    He said the U.S. Administration was ignoring the '
data: 'progress\nthat has been made and instead emphasizing the problems th'
data: 'at\nremain when it talks with Congress.\n    "It would only take fiv'
data: 'e minutes to list their\naccomplishments," a senior U.S. Official re'
data: 'plied.\n    The talks begin tomorrow with high-level discussions on '
data: 'the\neconomic structures of both countries and how they affect the\n'
data: 'bilateral trade imbalance, which last year amounted to 51.48\nbillio'
data: "n dlrs in Japan's favour.\n    On the following two days, the topics"
data: ' will range from\nmultilateral trade talks under the auspices of the'
data: ' General\nAgreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) to such bilateral tr'
data: 'ade\nproblems as super computers.\n    The structural talks are inte'
data: 'nded to be free-wheeling\ndiscussions among senior officials. Tomorr'
data: "ow's topics include\nsavings and investment issues such as consumer "
data: 'credit and\nhousing, and the implications of government budget defic'
data: 'its.\n    These talks come at a particularly delicate time for the\n'
data: 'Japanese government, which is facing increasing domestic\npressure t'
data: 'o abandon its tight-fisted fiscal policy and\nstimulate the sagging '
data: 'economy by spending more.\n    Some U.S. Officials complained Japan '
data: 'has no intention of\nboosting domestic demand and imports, as Washin'
data: 'gton wants.\n    Japanese officials in turn pointed the finger at th'
data: 'e huge\nU.S. Budget deficit as one of the main culprits for the trad'
data: 'e\nimbalance. That budget deficit has meant that the U.S. Is\nbuying'
data: ' more imports.\n    Japan seems particularly peeved at being singled'
data: ' in a draft\ntrade bill before the Senate as a nation following adve'
data: 'rserial\ntrade practices. "It condemns Japan without due process," o'
data: 'ne\nJapanese official said.\n    That reference spoils what is other'
data: 'wise a well-thought-out\nbill introduced by Democratic Senator Lloyd'
data: ' Bentsen, he said.\n    Japan is also not totally happy with the adm'
data: "inistration's\ntrade bill, particularly its proposal to establish re"
data: 'ciprocal\naccess to foreign markets as one criteria for retaliatory '
data: 'trade\naction by the U.S., Officials said.\n    Nevertheless, Japane'
data: 'se officials said they remain in a weak\nbargaining position, especi'
data: 'ally with the threat of a trade bill\noverhanging them.\n    "We hav'
data: 'e no leverage," one official admitted.\n    As a result, Tokyo is st'
data: 'riving to meet U.S. Complaints\nabout its trade practices in a varie'
data: 'ty of fields, including\nsuper computers.\n    The U.S. Is pressing '
data: 'for greater access to the Japanese\nsuper computer market.\n    The '
data: 'Japanese government has sent a long questionnaire to\npublic institu'
data: 'tions like universities which buy the\nsophisticated machines in hop'
data: 'es of eventually setting up\ninformal bidding procedures easily unde'
data: 'rstood by all potential\nsellers, officials said.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

data: '<Qantas Airways Ltd> has placed a firm\norder with Boeing Co <BA> fo'
data: 'r four 747-400 aircraft at a cost\nof 250 mln Australian dlrs each, '
data: 'chairman Jim Leslie said.\n    The first is due for delivery in Apri'
data: 'l 1989 with the others\narriving in May, June and September of that '
data: 'year, he said in a\nstatement.\n    The 400 series is the latest mod'
data: 'el of the Boeing 747\nfamily, he said.\n    The purchase will take g'

data: 'y> and General Electric\nCo <GE>, a unit of United Technologies Corp'
data: " <UTX>, and\nBritain's <Rolls-Royce Ltd>.\n    He said the 747-400, "

data: 'eet high winglets and enhanced\nelectronics, should have its first f'
data: 'light next February. The\n400 series has a designed range of 12,500 '
data: "kms, 2,140 kms\nfurther than the current Qantas 747-300's, he said.\n"
data: '    The aircraft will be financed by foreign borrowings and\nforeign'
data: ' exchange earnings, and Qantas believes they will pay\nfor themselve'
data: 's in four to five years, Leslie said.\n    The 747-400 has a take-of'
data: 'f weight of 870,000 pounds, up\nfrom 833,000 for the 300 series, and'
data: ' offers an eight pct fuel\nsaving, he said.\n    The higher range an'
data: 'd payload means they will first be used\non the route to Britain and'
data: ' Europe via Asia.\n    They will also be used on non-stop flights be'
data: 'tween Sydney\nand Los Angeles.\n REUTER\n\x03'

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'EC OPENS ANTI-DUMPING ENQUIRY INTO SOVIET MERCURY'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    BRUSSELS, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The European Community Commission said\nit has opened an enquiry int'
data: 'o allegations that the Soviet Union\nis dumping mercury on the Europ'
data: 'ean market at below-cost prices.\n    The Commission said its decisi'
data: 'on follows a complaint from\nEC non-ferrous metals producers that th'
data: 'e sales of Soviet\nmercury were harming their business and threateni'
data: 'ng jobs in the\nEuropean industry.\n    According to the complaint, '
data: 'Soviet mercury sales in the EC\nhad risen from zero in recent years '
data: 'to 100 tonnes between\nAugust and October last year and threaten to '
data: 'capture 25 pct of\nthe EC market if they continue at the same pace.\n'
data: '    The industry said the mercury was being sold at more than\n40 pc'
data: 't below prices charged by EC producers, forcing them to\ncut their p'
data: 'rices to levels that no longer covered costs. The\nimports had cause'
data: 'd producers heavy financial losses, it said.\n    The Commission sai'
data: 'd the industry would probably be unable\nto hold prices at current l'
data: 'evels and that any increase would\nresult in loss of sales and jobs.'
data: '\n    The so-called anti-dumping procedure opened by the\nCommission'
data: ' will allow all interested parties to state their\ncases to the auth'
data: 'ority.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'
end tag: </reuters>

start tag: <body>
data: 'The Philippines will offer commercial\nbank creditors an innovative '
data: 'pricing plan that will make debt\npayments through certificates of i'
data: 'ndebtedness instead of cash,\nthe authoritative Business Day newspap'
data: 'er said.\n    Finance Secretary Jaime Ongpin told reporters Saturday'
data: ' that\nthe alternative proposal is designed to avoid an impasse when'
data: '\ndebt rescheduling talks reopen in New York on Tuesday.\n    He did'
data: ' not give details but said, "It is a very useful\nalternative and in'
data: ' the end will permit the banks to say that\nthey achieved their pric'
data: 'ing target and will likewise permit the\nPhilippines to say exactly '
data: 'the same thing."\n    Quoting negotiation documents to be presented '
data: "to the\ncountry's 12-bank advisory committee, Business Day said the\n"
data: 'debt certificates will carry maturities of five or six years.\n    I'
data: 't said the certificates will be classified as zero-coupon\nbonds or '
data: 'promissory notes with no interest but priced at a\nconsiderable disc'
data: 'ount from their redemption price.\n    It said the debt bonds will e'
data: 'ntitle holder banks to a\nguaranteed return on both interest and pri'
data: 'ncipal since no\npayment of any kind is made until the bond matures.'
data: '\n    It said a bank can sell the bonds on the secondary bond\nmarke'
data: 't for either dlrs or pesos depending on its requirement.\n    The pe'
data: 'so proceeds can be invested in selected industries\nunder the Philip'
data: "pines' debt/equity program. Ongpin said Manila\nis sticking to its d"
data: 'emand of a spread of 5/8 percentage points\nover London interbank of'
data: 'fered Rates (LIBOR) for restructuring\n3.6 billion dlrs of debt repa'
data: 'yments.\n    "(The proposal) will give the banks a choice of 5/8ths '
data: 'or\nthe alternative," Ongpin said. "Our representatives have gone\nt'
data: 'o Washington to the (International Monetary) Fund, the (World)\nBank'
data: ', the Fed (Federal Reserve Board) and the (U.S.) Treasury\nto brief '
data: 'them in advance on this alternative and it has\ngenerally been posit'

data: 'quick agreement.\n    Monsod told Reuters Finance Secretary Jaime On'

data: 'eriod.\n    Manila is seeking a spread of 5/8 percentage points over'
data: '\nthe London Interbank Offered Rates (LIBOR).\n    Monsod said,  "Ri'
data: "ght now we are saying to the banks, let's\nshare the financing burde"
data: 'n."\n    Ongpin said last month the country\'s consultative group of'

data: 'ity to bridge the funding gap.\n     He said the government and the '
data: 'consultative group would\nmeet annually to gauge financing needs for'
data: ' each year. The aid\ndonors and commercial bank creditors would then'
data: ' be asked to\nfinance any gap on a shared basis.\n    He told report'
data: 'ers on Saturday it would be unwise to try to\npin the banks down on '

data: 'te sector investment continued to be held\nback by the fear of a bal'

data: 'd fail to achieve its gross\nnational product (GNP) growth target of'

data: 'not good for the economy.\n    "It (Ongpin\'s stand) is going to mak'

data: 'team is going\nto press for there is absolutely no reason why they s'

data: 'Taiwan plans another round of deep tariff\ncuts this year to help na'
data: 'rrow its trade surplus with the U.S.,\nA senior economic planner sai'
data: 'd.\n    Wang Chao-Ming, vice-chairman of the council for economic\np'
data: 'lanning and development, told Reuters Taiwan would further\nreduce i'
data: 'mport tariffs on 1,700 products sometime in the second\nhalf of this'
data: ' year.\n    Cuts of up to 50 pct on those items were made last year '
data: 'and\nWang said further cuts would go much deeper.\n    "We have to s'
data: 'peed up liberalisation and cut import tariffs\nfaster and more subst'
data: 'antially," he said.\n    The United States, Taiwan\'s main trading p'
data: "artner, has said\nthe island's import tariffs, still ranging from a "
data: 'high of\nalmost 60 pct, were unacceptable. It has criticised the cut'
data: "s as\ntoo selective.\n     Taiwan's trade surplus with the United St"
data: 'ates hit 13.6\nbillion dlrs last year. The surplus has boosted forei'
data: 'gn\nexchange reserves to 50 billion dlrs, which Wang said made\nTaiw'
data: 'an a target for U.S. Protectionism.\n    Wang said the trade surplus'
data: " and the reserves weakened\nTaiwan's position in talks with Washingt"
data: 'on over export quotas,\nparticularly for shoes, textiles and machine'
data: " tools which are\namong the island's main export-earners.\n    A spe"
data: 'cial Taiwanese trade delegation leaves for Washington\ntomorrow to t'
data: 'ry to renegotiate an agreement signed last year\nlimiting exports of'
data: " Taiwan textiles.\n    Under the accord, Taiwan's textile export gro"
data: 'wth was\nlimited to 0.5 pct each year until 1988. Taipei has said it'
data: ' is\nlosing markets to South Korea and Hong Kong which were given\nm'
data: 'ore generous terms.\n REUTER...\n\x03'

data: '  A reading above 50 pct generally indicates that the economy\nis in'
data: ' an expanding phase. One below 50 pct implies a declining\neconomy.\n'

data: '250 U.S. industrial companies, also found that the growth\nrate in n'
data: 'ew orders and production slowed in February.\n    However, productio'
data: 'n remained vigorous as more than three\ntimes as many members report'
data: 'ed it better rather than worse.\n    Vendor deliveries improved slig'
data: 'htly last month, but members\nreported that steel supplies were tigh'
data: 't as U.S. Steel <X>\ngradually resumed production.\n    An equal num'
data: 'ber of members reported inventories were higher\nand lower. The NAPM'
data: ' said that had not happened since August\n1984.\n    For a sixth mon'
data: 'th, more purchasers reported paying higher\nrather than lower prices'
data: ', this time by a ratio of nine to one.\n    Robert Bretz, chairman o'
data: "f the NAPM's business survey\ncommittee and director of materials ma"

data: 'xpand in February,\nbut at a more subdued rate than in January. The '
data: 'slowing of new\norders should not be significant enough to dampen pr'
data: 'ospects for\na respectable first quarter."\n    The composite index '

start tag: <body>
data: 'Brazil would not have suspended\npayments on debt owed to foreign ba'
data: 'nks if it had received more\nand faster financing from official lend'

data: 'would not seek more money from the International\nMonetary Fund to w'
data: "hich Brazil paid 922 mln dlrs last year and\nsaid Brazil's problems "
data: 'could not be solved by IMF intervention.\n    "It\'s a question of w'
data: "hy the official lending agencies don't\nfinance a little bit more qu"
data: 'ickly and easily," Funaro told\nreporters at the Brazilian Embassy.\n'
data: '    Asked if Brazil would have continued making payments of\nmonthly'
data: ' interest to its foreign commercial bank lenders if\nofficial lendin'
data: 'g agencies had provided more funds, he replied,\n"Yes, because our c'
data: 'ountry did not receive financing from these\nagencies."\n    Asked h'
data: 'ow long the payment suspension would last, Funaro\nsaid "It all depe'
data: 'nds on what kind of financing we are going to\nreceive from the othe'
data: 'r side."\n    Brazil, with foreign debt totaling 108 billion dlrs,\n'
data: 'stunned the banking community last week by suspending payments\non s'
data: 'ome 68 billion dlrs owed to private banks.\n    Funaro said Brazil h'
data: 'ad paid 44 billion dollars to the World\nBank and other lending agen'
data: 'cies and commercial banks in the\npast four years and got only 11 bi'
data: 'llion dlrs in loans.\n    He said the net transfer was hurting the c'
data: 'ountry\'s\ncontinued growth and capacity to import goods.\n    "Some'
data: 'thing is wrong with the system. Some mechanism has to\nbe found to f'
data: 'inance a country like Brazil," Funaro said.\n    He did not specify '
data: 'what steps he had in mind but said he\nwould like to see "automatic"'
data: ' official lending when needed so\nthat Brazil would not have to dip '
data: 'into its dwindling reserves,\nnow reported to be below four billion '
data: "dlrs.\n    Funaro said Brazil had the world's third-largest trade\ns"
data: 'urplus and estimated the 1987 surplus would be at least eight\nbilli'
data: 'on dlrs.\n    But he said that without increased and faster lending '
data: 'from\nofficial institutions, the nation could not rely on its export'
data: '\nearnings to finance development and imports and also service\nits '
data: 'debt.\n    "We must find an equilibrium between foreign adjustment a'
data: 'nd\ninternal adjustment," Funaro said.\n    He complained that offic'
data: 'ial lending agencies had imposed\ntight control on credit over the p'
data: 'ast four years, leaving\ncommercial bank refinancing as the only cre'
data: 'dit available.\n    Funaro said U.S officials understand his positio'
data: 'n "but they\ndon\'t like it." Later he left Washington for a tour of'
data: ' Europe\nand debt discussions with officials in Britain, West German'
data: "y,\nFrance, Switzerland and Italy.\n    Brazil's central cank Presid"
data: 'ent Francisco Gros said he sent\na telex to creditor banks Friday to'
data: " clarify confusion over\nBrazil's request that banks expedite proced"
data: 'ures for renewal of\nshort-term interbank credit and trade credit li'

end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Patti Domm, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    NEW YORK, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'American Express Co, rumored to be\nconsidering a spinoff of part of'
data: ' Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc,\nsaid it is studying a range of optio'
data: "ns for its brokerage unit\nthat could improve Shearon's access to ca"
data: 'pital and help it meet\nbroadening international competition.\n    I'
data: 'n a joint statement, American Express and Shearson said\nthe actions'
data: " under consideration are an integral part of\nAmerican Express' worl"
data: 'dwide financial services strategy and\nthat the two companies have b'
data: 'een having both internal and\nexternal discussions on the matters.\n'
data: '    American Express said no decision has been reached on the\nstrat'
data: 'egic options and that it and Shearson could ultimately\ndecide to fo'
data: 'llow growth plans already in place.\n    Last week, rumors circulate'
data: 'd on Wall Street that the\nfinancial services giant was considering '
data: 'a spinoff of part of\nShearson and there was speculation it may be c'
data: 'onsidering\nselling a stake to a Japanese firm. Analysts said the\ns'
data: 'peculation also focused on American Express selling 20 pct of\nthe p'
data: 'rofitable brokerage firm to the public.\n    There was some speculat'
data: 'ion that American Express had also\nconsidered a total spinoff of Sh'
data: 'earson, but the plan was\nconsidered highly unlikely, analysts said.'
data: '\n     American Express said in the statement on Sunday that it\nwil'
data: 'l not comment on rumors and speculation and a spokesman\nwould not g'
data: 'o beyond the statement. The company also remained\nsilent last Thurs'
data: 'day and Friday, as rumors drove American\nExpress stock up a total o'
data: 'f 5-1/2 dlrs in two days to bring it\nto a Friday close at 74.\n    '
data: ' It said it issued the statement on Sunday because a\nsimilar statem'
data: 'ent was being circulated to employees.\n    Analysts have been divid'
data: 'ed on whether it makes sense for\nAmerican Express to give up a stak'
data: 'e in the wholly-owned\nbrokerage, which improved its after-tax earni'
data: 'ngs by about 50\npct in the last year.\n    Some analysts said Ameri'
data: 'can Express may consider spinning\noff part of Shearson because it i'
data: 's concerned that its stock\nprice does not fully reflect the value o'
data: 'f the brokerage firm.\n     Shearson contributed 316 mln dlrs of Ame'
data: "rican Express'\n1.25 billion dlr net in 1986.\n    American Express'"
data: ' ambitious plans for international growth\nmay be also enhanced by t'
data: 'he added cash that spinning out part\nof Shearson would bring. Analy'
data: 'sts speculated that all of\nShearson would have a market value of ab'
data: 'out 3.5 billion dlrs.\n    To some however, the need for added capit'
data: 'al is puzzling.\n"(American) Express is in a position where they can'
data: ' raise\ncapital if they need to," said Larry Eckenfelder of\nPrudent'

data: 'tacted on Sunday said the statement does\nlittle to clarify last wee'

data: 'l services firm, which\nunsuccessfully attempted to expand Shearson '

start tag: <dateline>

end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Switzerland recorded last year its first\noverall surplus in governm'
data: 'ent finances since 1974, ending with\na net gain worth 905 mln Swiss'
data: ' francs, the Finance Ministry\nsaid.\n    The surplus, including cas'
data: 'h transactions and long-term\ninvestments, contrasted with the 1985 '
data: 'shortfall of 1.06 billion\nfrancs and the 297 mln franc deficit prop'
data: 'osed in the 1986\nbudget.\n    All categories of revenues were highe'
data: 'r than forecast, and\nexpenditures were 433 mln francs under forecas'
data: 't.\n    The Finance Ministry said expenditures totalled 23.18\nbilli'
data: 'on francs against 22.88 billion in 1985 and the 23.61\nbillion propo'
data: 'sed in the original 1986 budget.\n    Tax receipts, at 25.11 billion'
data: ', were well above the 1985\nfigure of 22.19 billion and the forecast'
data: ' for 1986 of 23.71\nbillion. This left a surplus on cash transaction'
data: 's totalling\n1.94 billion francs against a forecast 102 mln and the '
data: '1985\ndeficit of 696 mln.\n    Income and wealth taxes ended 749 mln'
data: ' francs above\nforecast, 378 mln of which came from higher than expe'
data: 'cted\nreceipts on the stamp duty on financial market transactions.\n'
data: '    Taxes on comsumption brought in 638 mln francs more than\nplanne'
data: 'd and other taxes 16 mln francs more, the ministry said.\n    The mi'
data: 'nistry said the improvement in the overall account\nreflected years '
data: 'of efforts by the government and parliament to\nintroduce saving and'
data: ' the acceptance by people of necessary tax\nincreases. But economic '
data: 'factors, including the low rate of\ninflation, the weak dollar, fall'
data: 'ing interest rates and low oil\nprices were also important factors.\n'
data: '    A spokesman for the ministry said the government had used\nits i'
data: 'mproved cash position to retire about one billion francs\nof governm'
data: 'ent debt, which accounted for the difference between\nthe 1.94 billi'
data: 'on surplus on cash transactions and the 905 mln\nfranc overall surpl'

end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Dean Lokken'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Apple Computer Inc today will\nannounce the addition of two new mach'
data: 'ines to its profitable\nMacintosh line of personal computers, both a'
data: 'imed at the\nbusiness market.\n    The Macintosh was first introduce'
data: 'd in January 1984 and has\nbeen upgraded several times since then. B'
data: 'oth of the new\nmachines, the Macintosh SE and the Macintosh II, wil'
data: 'l be faster\nand more versatile, but considerably more expensive tha'
data: 'n\nearlier models.\n    The Mac SE (SE stands for "system expansion"'
data: '), which Apple\nsays will operate 15-20 pct faster than its current '
data: 'Mac Plus,\ngoes on sale today. It carries a suggested retail price r'
data: 'anging\nfrom 2,899 to 3,699 dlrs depending on its features.\n    The'
data: ' Mac II, designed to run about four times faster than\nthe Mac Plus,'
data: ' is to be ready for shipping in May and priced\nbetween 4,798 and 6,'
data: '998 dlrs.\n    Mac Plus, which went on the market one year ago, sell'
data: 's for\nabout 2,200 dlrs.\n    Both new computers are to be unveiled '
data: 'at the AppleWorld\nConference in Los Angeles.\n    Company officials'
data: ' expressed high hopes for both computers\nat a press briefing on Fri'
data: 'day, especially the high-performance\nMac II which is designed to gi'
data: 've Apple an entree to the\nexpanding market for science and engineer'
data: 'ing workstations.\n    John Sculley, Apple chairman and chief execut'
data: 'ive officer,\ndeclined to estimate anticipated sales, but he said th'
data: "e Mac SE\nshould contribute significantly to Apple's bottom line thi"
data: 's\nyear. He said it would appeal to the mainstream of PC users.\n   '
data: ' "I believe the Mac SE will be the product of choice for\nmost peopl'
data: 'e," he said. "My sense is that it will be a real\npower product for '
data: 'revenue."\n    Bruce Lupatkin, senior technology analyst with Hambre'
data: 'cht &\nQuist in San Francisco, said he had not seen the new computer'
data: 's\nbut expected the new products to do well.\n    "Apple has recogni'
data: 'zed the need for a convergence of\ncomputer functions into one gener'
data: 'al all-purpose workstation,"\nhe told Reuters. "The graphics interfa'
data: 'ce on the Mac products is\nsignificantly better than anything IBM ha'
data: 's to date."\n    International Business Machines is expected to anno'
data: 'unce\nupdated personal computers this spring.\n    The Mac II uses t'
data: 'he new Motorola 68020 microprocessor, an\n"open architecture" that a'
data: 'llows for the addition of numerous\nperipheral devices, a built-in h'
data: 'ard disk and one megabyte of\nmemory, expandable to eight megabytes.'
data: ' It can be equipped with\na 12-inch monochrome or a 13-inch color mo'
data: 'nitor.\n    In a demonstration of its speed and power, company\nexec'
data: 'utives said they thought the Mac II would push the\ndevelopment of s'
data: 'oftware for Apple computers in new directions\nthat could include so'
data: 'phisticated video editing, electronic mail\nsystems and sound reprod'
data: 'uction suitable for studio use.\n    The Mac II can be upgraded so t'
data: 'hat its monitor displays 256\ncolors or shades of gray.\n    The Mac'
data: ' SE is built around the 68000 microprocessor and\nwill be shipped wi'
data: 'th one megabyte RAM, expandable to four\nmegabytes, and a nine-inch '
data: 'monochrome screen.\n    Both new computers have two optional keyboar'
data: 'ds, a new\nfeature in the Apple line of products.          \n Reuter'

data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    HOUSTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'LL and E Royalty Trust said Louisiana\nLand and Exploration Co <LLX>'
data: ', the working interest owner for\nits oil and natural gas properties'
data: ', is entitled to start\nplacing all or part of the revenues that wou'
data: 'ld otherwise accrue\nto the trust.\n    LL and E said Louisiana Land'
data: ' has not yet escrowed any\namounts and will monitor the siutuation t'
data: 'o determine the\nnecessity of doing so.  The trust said "If the work'
data: 'ing interest\nowner does begin to escrow funds, the effect on the ro'
data: 'yalties\npaid to the trust would be significant."  Royalties from th'
data: "e\nproperties are the trust's only source of income.\n    The trust "
data: "said independent petroleum engineers' preliminary\nannual estimates "
data: 'of future net revenues and the discounted\npresent value of future n'
data: 'et revenues from proved oil and\nnatural gas reserves attributable t'
data: 'o properties in which the\ntrust has an interest are off 64 pct and '
data: '56 pct respectively\nfrom those estimated in 1986 due to the drop in'
data: ' oil and natural\ngas prices.\n    It said, however, that oil and na'
data: 'tural gas reserves have\nactually increased in physical amount.  The'
data: ' cost estimates\nreflect prices and costs only through September 30.'
data: '\n    The trust said using the September figures, the engineers\ndet'
data: 'ermined estimated future net revenues to the trust from\ntotal prove'
data: 'd reserves of about 57 mln dlrs.  Usingprices\nreceived in January 1'
data: '987, however, it said the estimate would\nhave been about 87 mln dlr'
data: 's.  LL and E noted that there has\nbeen some weakening in prices sin'
data: 'ce January.\n    The trust said the most significant portion of the '
data: 'drop in\nestimated future revenues cale from the Jay Field in Alabam'
data: 'a\nand Florida, a fall to seven mln dlrs from 92 mln dlrs in 1986,\n'
data: 'as prices recieved from Jay in September were near production\ncosts'
data: ' after expenses of nitrogen injection.\n Reuter\n\x03'

data: 'ther courier company.\n    Hutton LBO, a wholly owned subsidiary of '
data: 'E.F. Hutton Group\nInc, will be majority owner of the company.\n    '

data: " dlrs cash per share for 83 pct of Purolator's stock\nin a tender of"
data: 'fer to begin Thursday. The rest of the shares\nwill be purchased for'
data: ' securities and warrants to buy stock in a\nsubsidiary of PC Acquisi'
data: "tion, containing Purolator's U.S.\ncourier operations.\n    If all t"
data: 'he shares of Purolator are tendered, shareholders\nwould receive for'

data: 'urier operations.\n    Hutton said in the merger shareholders would '
data: 'get 46 mln\ndlrs aggregate amount of guaranteed debentures due 2002 '
data: 'of PC\nAcquisition and warrants to buy 15 pct of the common stock of'
data: '\nthe PC courier subsidiary. Hutton said the company has valued\nthe'
data: " warrants at two to three dlrs per share.\n    Purolator's stock pri"
data: 'ce closed at 35.125 dlrs on Friday.\nWhile some analysts estimated t'
data: 'he company was worth in the mid\n30s, at least one said it would be '
data: 'worth 38 to 42 dlrs.\n    This follows sales of two other Purolator '
data: 'units. It agreed\nrecently to sell its Canadian Courier unit to Onex'
data: ' Capital for\n170 mln dlrs, and previously sold its auto filters bus'
data: 'iness.\n    Purolator retains its Stant division, which makes closur'
data: 'e\ncaps for radiators and gas tanks. A Hutton spokesman said the\nfi'
data: "rm is reviewing its options on Stant.\n    Purolator's courier busin"
data: 'ess has been lagging that of its\nU.S. rivals because of the high pr'
data: 'ice it paid in the past\nseveral years to add air delivery to its gr'
data: 'ound fleet.\n    E.F. Hutton will provide 279 mln dlrs of its funds '
data: 'to\ncomplete the transaction. This so-called "bridge" financing\nwil'
data: 'l be replaced later with long-term debt most likely in the\nform of '
data: 'bank loans, Hutton said. Hutton LBO is committed to\nkeeping the cou'
data: 'rier business, its president Warren Idsal said.\n    "Purolator lost'
data: ' 120 mln dlrs over the last two years\nlargely due to U.S. courier o'
data: 'perations, which we believe the\nmanagement is turning around. We be'
data: 'live it will be a very\nserious competitor in the future," said Idsa'
data: 'l.\n    William Taggart, chief executive officer of U.S. Courier\ndi'
data: 'vision, will be chief executive officer of the new company.\n    The'

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'U.S. CORPORATE FINANCE - ASSET-BACK MARKET GROWS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By John Picinich, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    NEW YORK, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The U.S. asset-backed debt securities\nmarket, which grew explosivel'
data: 'y last year, is broadening and\ninvestment bankers say 1987 could se'
data: 'e a variety of issuers.\n    "It is interesting to note that the fir'
data: 'st two asset-backed\ndeals of the year were done by commercial banks'
data: '," said Anthony\nDub, who heads First Boston Corp\'s asset-backed gr'
data: "oup.\n    BankAmerica Corp's <BAC> Bank of America unit last week\ni"
data: 'ssued 400 mln dlrs of securities backed by credit card\nreceivables '
data: 'via sole manager First Boston. Dub said the\noffering sold out quick'
data: 'ly, mostly to institutional investors.\n    The Bank of America offe'
data: 'ring followed a January 16 issue of\n200 mln dlrs of similar debt by'
data: " RepublicBank Corp's <RPT>\nRepublicBank Delaware unit. Goldman, Sac"
data: 'hs and Co ran the books\non that deal, with First Boston acting as c'
data: 'o-manager.\n    However, Dub said the Bank of America securities wer'
data: 'e more\nclosely related to the so-called "cars deals" that raced to\n'
data: 'market last year than were the RepublicBank securities.\n    "The Re'
data: 'publicBank issue was secured by credit card\nreceivables. In contras'
data: 't, the Bank of America deal was the\nfirst public offering of credit'
data: ' card receivables because we\nused a grantor trust vehicle," he said'
data: '.\n    In a grantor trust, investors buy asset-backed certificates\n'
data: 'that represent a specified percentage of an undivided interest\nin t'
data: 'he trust, analysts explained.\n    The Bank of America certificates '
data: 'were issued by California\nCredit Card Trust A, which the bank estab'
data: 'lished for that single\npurpose, investment bankers pointed out.\n  '
data: '  The debt has an average life of 1.79 years and matures in\n1992. F'
data: 'irst Boston gave the issue a 6.90 pct coupon and priced\nit at 99.81'
data: '25 to yield 6.95 pct, or 65 basis points over\ncomparable Treasury s'
data: 'ecurities. Non-callable for life, the deal\nwas rated AAA by both Mo'
data: "ody's and Standard and Poor's.\n    Underwriters away from the syndi"
data: 'cate said they believed the\nBank of America deal was priced too agg'
data: 'ressively. "AAA-rated\nauto paper was trading about 75 basis points '
data: 'over Treasuries\nwhen First Boston priced the deal," one said.\n    '
data: 'However, Dub said the offering sold out quickly anyway.\n    The Fir'
data: "st Boston executive attributed this to the deal's\ntop-flight rating"
data: " by both agencies, unlike many of last year's\ncars deals, which wer"
data: 'e rated by S and P alone.\n    "Investors receive interest only paym'
data: 'ents for the first 18\nmonths and then interest and principal paymen'
data: 'ts for the\nremaining five to seven months," Dub detailed.\n    Inve'
data: 'stment bankers pointed out that because the Bank of\nAmerica deal di'
data: 'd not pay principal for a year and a half, the\nissue had a longer a'
data: 'verage life than some of the cars deals\nthat were brought to market'
data: ' late last year.\n    The collateral for the trust includes a pool o'
data: 'f VISA credit\ncard receivables, backed by a letter of credit. Bank '
data: 'of America\nhas about four billion dlrs of credit card receivables, '
data: 'making\nit one of the biggest in the U.S., analysts said.\n    Last '
data: "week's deal was Bank of America's second foray into\nthe young asset"
data: '-backed securities market, analysts noted.\n    In mid-December 1986'
data: ' Bank of America sold, via California\nCars Grantor Trust 1986-A, 51'
data: '4 mln dlrs of certificates backed\nby automobile receivables through'
data: ' Salomon Brothers Inc.\n    Upcoming asset-backed issues include 200'
data: ' mln dlrs of notes\nbacked by the car leases of Volvo 1986 Lease Fin'
data: 'ance Corp, a\nunit of Volvo Finance North America Inc, via First Bos'
data: 'ton, and\n450 mln dlrs of notes secured by sales contracts of Mack T'
data: 'rucks\nReceivables Corp, a unit of Mack Trucks Inc <MACK>, via\nShea'
data: 'rson Lehmand Brothers Inc.\n    The asset backed market, which began'
data: ' in March 1985, totals\nan estimated 11.9 billion dlrs.\n Reuter\n\x03'

start tag: <title>
data: 'REAGAN AND BAKER BEGIN TASK OF REBUILDING'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Peter Szekely'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'After a week that left his presidency\nshaken and his popularity at '
data: 'a new low, Ronald Reagan and his\nnew chief of staff today begin try'
data: 'ing to revive an\nadministration tattered by the Iran-contra arms sc'
data: 'andal.\n    Reagan and former Senate Republican leader Howard Baker,'
data: '\nwhose appointment as White House chief of staff won bipartisan\npr'
data: 'aise, will begin mapping strategy to deal with scathing\ncriticism b'
data: 'y a report on his failed bid to trade U.S. arms with\nIran for help '
data: 'in freeing Ameican hostages in Lebanon.\n    Among the chores facing'
data: " Reagan's new inner circle is\nassessing the damage the 300-page Tow"
data: 'er commission report has\ndone to the nomination of Robert Gates to '
data: 'succeed William Casey\nas the new head of the Central Intelligence A'
data: 'gency.\n    White House officials are checking to see how much suppo'
data: 'rt\nGates, a 43-year old career spy agency bureaucrat, would have\ni'
data: 'f his nomination is submitted to the full Senate for a vote,\nSenate'
data: ' Republican leader Robert Dole said.\n    Appearing on the NBC News '
data: 'program, "Meet the Press," the\nKansas senator said the Gates nomina'
data: 'tion "could be in some\ndifficulty."\n    Aides said that Gates\' fu'
data: 'ture would be given high priority\nby Baker.\n    Even though he was'
data: ' not deeply implicated in the arms sale\nscandal, lawmakers said Sen'
data: 'ate confirmation of the Gates\nnomination is not assured and, even i'
data: 'f won, would come only\nafter months of congressional probes into th'
data: 'e affair.\n    "He has the smell of Iran on him," said former Nevada'
data: ' Sen.\nand Reagan confidant Paul Laxalt. "He is a victim."\n    Laxa'
data: 'lt, appearing on the ABC News program, "This Week With\nDavid Brinkl'
data: 'ey," bluntly admitted "the Gates nomination is in\ntrouble." Senate '
data: 'Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn said\nthe odds are now sl'
data: 'ightly against confirmation of Gates.\n    When asked on the syndica'
data: 'ted television program, "John\nMcLaughlin: One on One," if he though'
data: 't Gates would be confirmed,\nthe Georgia Democrat shot back: "I woul'
data: 'dn\'t bet any money on it.\n    "I think this report hurts that," Nu'
data: 'nn said. "It indicates\nthat the National Security Council had polic'
data: "y-type influence\nover intelligence-type activities and we're going "
data: 'to go into\nthat with Mr. Gates.\n    Only a day after it was issued'
data: ' last week, the Tower report\nprompted the abrupt exit of Donald Reg'
data: 'an as White House chief\nof staff.\n    Regan, the former Wall Stree'
data: "t executive and Treasury\nsecretary who has been the president's top"
data: " aide for the past\ntwo years, was assigned the lion's share of the "
data: 'blame for the\nbotched handling of the Iran arms sale.\n    The repo'
data: 'rt blamed Regan for the "chaos that descended on the\nWhite House" s'
data: 'ince it was first revealed last November that\nprofits from the Iran'
data: ' arms sales had been diverted to contra\nrebels fighting the leftist'
data: ' Nicaraguan government.\n    The two other victims of the scandal ar'
data: 'e former National\nSecurity Adviser Vice Adm. John Poindexter who re'
data: 'signed and\nMarine Lt. Col. Oliver North who was fired after it was\n'
data: 'disclosed last November 23 that profits from the Iran arms sale\nwer'
data: 'e diverted to the contras. The two, pictured by the Tower\ncommissio'
data: 'n as the key operators of the Iran arms deal, have\nrefused to testi'
data: 'fy.\n    Reagan, who freely admits disliking details, is portrayed\n'
data: 'in the Tower report as a befuddled chief executive whose\ninattentio'
data: 'n let his aides run away with his foreign policy.\n    That percepti'
data: "on has wrecked Reagan's popularity and\nthreatened to condemn him to"
data: ' lame duck status until he leaves\noffice in January 1989. A recent '
data: 'Newsweek magazine poll found\nthat just 40 pct of Americans approved'
data: " of Reagan's leadership,\na record low, and a third believed he shou"
data: 'ld consider\nresignation.\n    After meeting with aides over the wee'
data: 'kend and poring over\nthe meaty report of the commission headed by f'
data: 'ormer Texas Sen.\nJohn Tower, Reagan is now preparing for a nationwi'
data: 'de television\naddress this week to respond to the criticisms of his'
data: '\npresidency.\n Reuter\n\x03'

data: 'is year after reporting better\nthan expected profits in 1986, chair'
data: 'man Li Ka-shing said.\n    He did not give a specific earnings proje'
data: 'ction but he told\nreporters the firm will pay total dividends of no'
data: 't less than 19\ncents a share this year after a one-for-four bonus i'
data: 'ssue and a\nfour-for-one stock split.\n    The company earlier decla'
data: 'red total dividends equal to 15\ncents a share for 1986, adjusting f'
data: "or the stock split and bonus\nissue.\n    Cheung Kong's earnings ros"
data: 'e to 1.28 billion H.K. Dlrs in\n1986, well above market expectations'
data: ' of 920 mln to one billion\ndlrs. They compared with profits of 551.'
data: '7 mln dlrs in 1985.\n    Cheung Kong also reported extraordinary gai'
data: "ns of 983.6 mln\ndlrs mainly from the firm's sale of the Hong Kong H"
data: 'ilton Hotel\nto Hongkong Electric Holdings Ltd <HKEH.HK> for one bil'
data: 'lion\ndlrs. It had gains of 81.3 mln dlrs in 1985.\n    Li attribute'
data: 'd the surge in 1986 earnings to a buoyant local\nproperty market and'
data: ' substantial increases in contributions from\nassociated companies.\n'
data: '    "Looking ahead, 1987 should be another year of stability for\nth'
data: 'e property market," Li said. "The growth in (Hong Kong\'s)\nexports '
data: 'is expected to stimulate the demand for industrial\nbuildings."\n   '
data: ' Cheung Kong is cash rich and is looking for new projects in\nthe Br'
data: 'itish colony, Li said, noting the firm is interested in a\nland recl'

end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The Writers Guild of America said its\nmembers have struck the news '
data: 'staffs of CBS Inc <CBS> and\nCapital Cities/ABC Inc <CCB> this morni'
data: 'ng after negotiations\nfor a new contract broke down.\n    The guild'
data: ' said there had been extensions prior to the\nstrike deadline this m'
data: 'orning, but said the strike was called\nafter the companies refused '
data: 'to negotiate.\n    The guild said the companies failed to put a fina'
data: 'l offer on\nthe table, made no money offer at all, and did not devia'
data: 'te\nsubstantially from their original proposals, which, the guild\ns'
data: 'aid, would have gutted the union contract.\n    The guild said the n'
data: 'etworks demanded the right to terminate\nemployees at will and lay t'
data: 'hem off without the  arbitration,\nand the hiring of temporary emplo'
data: 'yees to replace staffer\nemployees.\n    The guild represents newswr'
data: 'iters, editors, desk assistants,\nresearchers, production assistants'
data: ', promotion writers and\ngraphic artists.\n    The strike affects un'
data: 'ions in New York, Chicago, Washington\nand Los Angeles. Picketing wi'
data: 'll commence at corporate\nheadquarters in New York and other locatio'
data: 'ns, the guild said.\n Reuter\n\x03'

data: 'se discount houses wishing to use\nthem at 1430 GMT.\n    The Bank a'
data: 'lso said it provided the money market 456 mln stg\nassistance in the'
data: ' afternoon session bringing its total help so\nfar today to 493 mln '
data: 'stg. This compares with its forecast of a\nshortage in the system to'
data: 'day of around 700 mln stg.\n    The central bank purchased bank bill'
data: 's outright comprising\n41 mln stg in band one at 10-7/8 pct 361 mln '

data: 'ntly\nused the offer of borrowing facilities to signal that it does\n'
data: 'not want to see an early reduction in U.K. Base lending rates.\n    '
data: 'The Bank does this by lending to the discount houses at\nrates of in'
data: 'terest higher than its prevailing money market\ndealing rates.\n REU'

end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'BRAZIL CRITICISES ADVISORY COMMITTEE STRUCTURE'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Sandy Critchley, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    LONDON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Brazil is not happy with the existing\nstructure of the 14-bank advi'
data: 'sory committee which coordinates\nits commercial bank debt, Finance '
data: 'Minister Dilson Funaro said.\n    U.S. Banks have 50 pct representat'
data: "ion on the committee\nwhile holding only 35 pct of Brazil's debt to "
data: 'banks, he said,\nadding "This is not fair with the European and Japa'
data: 'nese banks."\nThe committee had played a useful role in 1982 and 198'
data: '3,\nhowever.\n    Noting the often different reactions of U.S., Japa'
data: 'nese and\nEuropean banks, Funaro told journalists that Brazil might '
data: 'adopt\nan approach involving separate discussions with the regions.\n'
data: "    Since debtor nations' problems were normally treated on a\ncase-"
data: 'by-case basis, "Perhaps the same principle should apply to\ncreditor'
data: 's," central bank president Francisco Gros said.\n    Brazil on Febru'
data: 'ary 20 suspended indefinitely interest\npayments on 68 billion dlrs '
data: 'owed to commercial banks, followed\nlast week by a freeze on bank an'
data: 'd trade credit lines deposited\nby foreign banks and institutions, w'
data: 'orth some 15 billion dlrs.\n    Funaro and Gros spent two days at th'
data: 'e end of last week in\nWashington talking to government officials an'
data: 'd international\nagencies and will this week visit Britain, France, '
data: 'West\nGermany, Switzerland and Italy for discussions with\ngovernmen'
data: 'ts.\n    Funaro and Gros are today meeting British Chancellor of the'
data: '\nExchequer Nigel Lawson, Foreign Secretary Geoffrey Howe and\nGover'
data: 'nor of the Bank of England Robin Leigh-Pemberton.\n    Bankers have '
data: 'estimated that Brazil owes U.K. Banks around\n8.5 billion dlrs in lo'
data: 'ng and medium term loans, giving the U.K.\nThe third largest exposur'
data: "e after the U.S. And Japan.\n    The crisis began when Brazil's trad"
data: 'e surplus, its chief\nmeans of servicing its foreign debt, started t'
data: 'o decline sharply\nand the problem was compounded by a renewed surge'
data: " in the\ncountry's\x7fate of inflation.  Reserves were reported to h"
data: 'ave\ndropped below four billion dlrs.\n    Funaro envisaged that any'
data: " eventual solution to problems\nwith Brazil's 108 billion dlr foreig"
data: 'n debt would involve only\npartial servicing of the debt.\n    "What'
data: ' we propose is to arrive at a mechanism of refinance\nfor part of th'
data: 'e service, because we cannot service all that," he\nsaid. "I really '
data: 'think we have to change the old rules."\n    Asked why Brazil was fi'
data: 'rst approaching governments, rather\nthan the commercial banks thems'
data: 'elves in its search for a\nsolution to the crisis, Funaro said "We m'
data: 'ust first talk to the\ngovernments and then we can talk to the banks'
data: ', because the\nbanks have some limits."\n    "It is a political disc'
data: 'ussion from our point of view," he\nsaid.\n    Funaro said he hoped '
data: 'next week to travel to talk to\nJapanese and Canadian government off'
data: 'icials. He would then talk\nto the commercial banks "If I\'ve got so'
data: "me solution from the\ngovernments. I can't take the burden only to t"
data: 'he banks." He was\nnot sure how long it would take to reach a soluti'
data: 'on.\n \x7f  In discussions with governments Brazil would review the\n'
data: 'mechanisms whereby finance was made available to nations in\nneed. F'
data: 'inance from official lending agencies had been virtually\nclosed sin'
data: 'ce 1982. "You must open these mechanisms," he said.\n    He said tha'
data: "t while the U.S. Officials had been disturbed by\nBrazil's suspensio"
data: 'n of interest payments, they understood\nBrazil had no other choice,'
data: ' as it had to protect its reserves.\n    Also the financing mechanis'
data: 'ms had to be discussed "because\nwe can\'t stay as we were the last '
data: 'few years."\n    "I\'m trying to put the problem on the table.... Al'
data: 'l of us\nwould like to have a kind of equilibrium." he said. Althoug'
data: 'h\nBrazil has rejected a substantive role for the International\nMon'
data: 'etary Fund (IMF) in managing its economy, Funaro paid a call\nin Was'
data: 'hington to IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus and to\nWorld Bank'
data: ' President Barber Conable.\n    Funaro noted that inflation in Febru'
data: 'ary had started to\ndecline again and he expected Brazil to achieve '
data: 'a minimum eight\nbillion dlr trade surplus in 1987.\n    Banking sou'
data: "rces noted that Brazil's monthly surplus had\ndeclined to some 150 m"
data: 'ln dlrs in the final three months of last\nyear, against a monthly o'
data: 'ne billion in the first nine months.\n    Brazil had the third large'
data: 'st trade surplus in the world,\nFunaro said, although its share of i'
data: 'nternational trade was only\none pct.  "The solution is linked with '
data: 'growth, not recession," he\nsaid, noting an IMF program would involv'
data: 'e promoting exports and\ninducing an internal recession in order to '
data: "service debt.\n    Banking sources said Brazil's debts to foreign go"
data: 'vernments,\nas opposed to commercial banks, now benefit from a sound'
data: "er\nstructure following last month's rescheduling by the Paris Club\n"
data: 'of creditor nations of 4.12 billion dlrs of official debt.\n REUTER\n'
data: '\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
