data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'U.S. NON-FARM PRODUCTIVITY FELL 2.2 PCT IN QTR'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, Mar 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Productivity in the non-farm business\nsector fell at a seasonally a'
data: 'djusted, revised annual rate of\n2.2 pct in the fourth quarter last '
data: 'year, the Labor department\nsaid.\n    Previously, the department sa'
data: 'id productivity fell 1.7 pct\nin the fourth quarter.\n    The declin'
data: 'e followed a 0.3 pct drop in the third quarter.\n    For all of 1986'
data: ', productivity increased 0.7 pct from 1985,\nreflecting rises of 4.3'
data: ' pct in the first quarter and 0.5 pct in\nthe second quarter.\n    N'
data: 'on-farm productivity in 1985 increased 0.5 pct, the\ndepartment said'
data: '.\n    For the fourth quarter, output rose 1.9 pct while hours of\na'
data: 'll persons increased 4.3 pct.\n    Hourly compensation rose 2.7 pct '
data: 'but effectively was zero\nwhen the increase in CPI-U is taken into a'
data: 'ccount. Unit labor\ncosts rose 5.1 pct.\n    The implicit price defl'
data: 'ator for non-farm business fell 0.4\npct following a 3.6 pct increas'
data: 'e in the third quarter.\n    Manufacturng productivity declined 0.1 '
data: 'pct after a 3.6 pct\nincrease in the third quarter.\n    Manufacturi'
data: 'ng output rose 3.3 pct in the fourth quarter and\nas hours gained 3.'
data: '4 pct and compensation per hour 2.1 pct, the\ndepartment said.\n    '
data: 'Real compensation per hour in manufacturing fell 0.6 pct in\nthe fou'
data: 'rth quarter when inflation was taken into account.\n    Business pro'
data: 'ductivity, including farms, fell 2.8 pct in the\nfourth quarter afte'
data: 'r a 0.4 pct third-quarter decline but was\n0.7 pct higher overall in'
data: ' 1986 than in 1985.\n    Hourly compensation increased three pct ove'
data: 'rall in 1986 in\nthe non-farm business sector, the smal.0 pct.e sinc'
data: 'e 1919.\n    In 1985, hourly compensation rose 4.0 pct.\n    The imp'
data: 'licit price deflator for non-farm business rose 2.2\npct in 1986 aft'
data: 'er a 3.3 pct rise a year earlier and was the\nsmallest increase sinc'

start tag: <body>
data: 'World animal health experts called for a\ncampaign to eradicate the '
data: 'lethal cattle disease Rinderpest in\nBangladesh, Bhutan, India, Nepa'
data: 'l and Pakistan, a statement from\na Food and Agriculture Organizatio'
data: 'n (FAO) meeting here said.\n    Some 230 mln dlrs is needed over two'

data: 'gladesh and Pakistan\nand high-risk areas of the other three countri'
data: 'es. In India some\n240 mln cattle are estimated to be at risk from t'
data: 'he disease.\n    The experts recommended the campaign be funded most'
data: 'ly by\nthe governments of the five nations, with help from the FAO.\n'
data: 'Similar campaigns are needed in Egypt, Yemen, Iraq and Iran.\n Reute'
data: 'r\n\x03'

data: 'rst approaching\ngovernments before talking to the commercial banks '

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'STUDY GROUP URGES INCREASED U.S. OIL RESERVES'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'A study group said the United States\nshould increase its strategic '
data: 'petroleum reserve to one mln\nbarrels as one way to deal with the pr'
data: 'esent and future impact\nof low oil prices on the domestic oil indus'
data: 'try.\n    U.S. policy now is to raise the strategic reserve to 750\n'
data: 'mln barrels, from its present 500 mln, to help protect the\neconomy '
data: 'from an overseas embargo or a sharp price rise.\n    The Aspen Insti'
data: 'tute for Humanistic Studies, a private\ngroup, also called for new r'
data: 'esearch for oil exploration and\ndevelopment techniques.\n    It pre'
data: 'dicted prices would remain at about 15-18 dlrs a\nbarrel for several'
data: ' years and then rise to the mid 20s, with\nimports at about 30 pct o'
data: 'f U.S. consumption.\n    It said instead that such moves as increasi'
data: 'ng oil reserves\nand more exploration and development research would'
data: ' help to\nguard against or mitigate the risks of increased imports.\n'
data: ' Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'STUDY GROUP URGES INCREASED U.S. OIL RESERVES'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'A study group said the United States\nshould increase its strategic '
data: 'petroleum reserve to one mln\nbarrels as one way to deal with the pr'
data: 'esent and future impact\nof low oil prices on the domestic oil indus'
data: 'try.\n    U.S. policy now is to raise the strategic reserve to 750\n'
data: 'mln barrels, from its present 500 mln, to help protect the\neconomy '
data: 'from an overseas embargo or a sharp price rise.\n    The Aspen Insti'
data: 'tute for Humanistic Studies, a private\ngroup, also called for new r'
data: 'esearch for oil exploration and\ndevelopment techniques.\n    It pre'
data: 'dicted prices would remain at about 15-18 dlrs a\nbarrel for several'
data: ' years and then rise to the mid 20s, with\nimports at about 30 pct o'
data: 'f U.S. consumption.\n    The study cited two basic policy paths for '
data: 'the nation: to\nprotect the U.S. industry through an import fee or o'
data: 'ther such\ndevice or to accept the full economic benefits of cheap o'
data: 'il.\n    But the group did not strongly back either option, saying\n'
data: 'there were benefits and drawbacks to both.\n    It said instead that'
data: ' such moves as increasing oil reserves\nand more exploration and dev'
data: 'elopment research would help to\nguard against or mitigate the risks'
data: ' of increased imports.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

data: 'bide had the attitude "that if\nwe couldn\'t do it ourselves, it was'

data: ' can link\nup profitably with someone who is already there."\n    He'
data: ' said Carbide has extended its catalyst business that way\nand is no'

data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'EC COMMISSION GIVEN PLAN TO SAVE STEEL INDUSTRY'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Gerrard Raven, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    BRUSSELS, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'European Community steelmakers\npresented the Executive Commission w'
data: 'ith a controversial plan\nfor the future of the industry which diplo'
data: 'mats say it may be\nforced reluctantly to accept.\n    Under the pla'
data: 'n steel output would remain subject to\nrestrictive quotas and impor'
data: 'ts would be firmly controlled for\nyears to come while steel firms u'
data: 'ndertook a massive\nslimming-down operation to adjust capacity to lo'
data: 'wer demand.\n    Industry Commissioner Karl-Heinz Narjes has propose'
data: 'd the\nending of the quota system by December 1988.\n    He has prop'
data: 'osed a return to the free market, which under EC\nlaw is supposed to'
data: ' exist except in times of "manifest crisis."\n    But diplomats said'
data: ' some ministers who meet to discuss this\nidea on March 19 will argu'
data: 'e that steel firms are in crisis in\ntheir countries, with orders fa'
data: 'lling as customers switch to\nalternative products and accounts firm'
data: "ly in the red.\n    Ministers from the EC's major steel producing co"
data: "untries are\nlikely to shy away from Narjes' proposals and could bac"
data: "k the\nindustry's own plan instead, in the hope of minimising the\np"
data: 'olitical impact of plant closures, they said.\n    Industry sources '
data: "said the plan presented to Narjes by the\nEC steelmakers' lobby grou"
data: 'p Eurofer would retain the quota\nproduction system at least until t'
data: 'he end of 1990.\n    Eurofer said in a statement consultants working'
data: ' for it\nidentified scope for closing plants on a "voluntary" basis '
data: 'to\nreduce capacity by 15.26 mln tonnes a year.\n    Cuts were still'
data: ' insufficient in one production area, that\nof hot rolled coils, and'
data: ' further talks were needed.\n    Eurofer added the industry would ne'
data: 'ed the support of the\nCommission and governments in carrying out a '
data: 'closure program,\nparticularly with social costs such as redundancy '
data: 'payments.\n    The EC steel industry has already shed 240,000 jobs t'
data: 'his\ndecade while reducing annual capacity by 31 mln tonnes.\n Reute'
data: 'r\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'

data: ' \n\x05\x05\x05C\n\x16\x16\x01f0167\x1freute\nd f BC-CME-PLANS-RULE-'
data: 'CHANGE   03-02 0085'
end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'CME PLANS RULE CHANGES TIGHTENING S/P TRADING'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Brad Schade, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    CHICAGO, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Directors of the Chicago Mercantile\nExchange will meet Wednesday to'
data: ' consider a membership petition\nasking the exchange to tighten rule'
data: 's covering trading\nactivities in the widely-popular Standard and Po'
data: "or's 500 Stock\nIndex futures pit, an exchange executive said.\n    "
data: 'The petition calls for elimination of dual trading, a legal\npractic'
data: 'e where traders execute customer orders as well as trade\nfor their '
data: 'own account.\n    But exchange officials noted this practice also pr'
data: 'ovides an\nopportunity for a trader to engage in what is called\n"fr'
data: 'ont-running", where traders enter orders for their own account\nbefo'
data: 're executing orders for their customers.\n    Leo Melamed, CME speci'
data: 'al counsel, said directors will rule\non the petition on Wednesday, '
data: 'but added that a special S and P\nAdvisory Committee has been studyi'
data: 'ng S and P 500 futures\ntrading conditions for the last six months a'
data: 'nd is expected to\nsubmit a complete list of recommendations within '
data: '30 days.\n    In addition to a recommendation on dual trading, Melam'
data: 'ed\nsaid the special committee will also make suggestions about a\np'
data: 'ossible automatic order entry and execution system for S and P\n500 '
data: 'futures and futures-options and rule changes that would\nalleviate c'
data: 'ongested conditions in the trading pit.\n    Melamed said directors '
data: 'are likely to approve the\nrecommendations of the special committee '
data: 'because "most actions\nof the board are in line with committee recom'
data: 'mendations."\n    CME senior vice president Gerald Beyer said if the'
data: " board\naccepts the member's petition this week, a rule change will "
data: 'be\nsubmitted to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for\nappro'
data: 'val.\n    If the board does nothing, or rejects the petition request'
data: ',\na rule change must then be submitted to the exchange membership\n'
data: 'for a vote within 15 days, Beyer said.\n    Melamed also added that '
data: 'if the petition must be ruled on\nbefore the recommendations from th'
data: 'e special committee are made\n"it will confuse the issue."\n    Not '
data: 'all traders agree on the need to eliminiate or restrict\ndual tradin'
data: 'g.\n    Although Jonathan Wolff, senior vice president at Donaldson\n'
data: 'Lufkin and Jenrette, noted dual trading is evident on most\nexchange'
data: 's.\n    "It\'s a question of the integrity of the person you do\nbus'
data: 'iness with," Wolff said.\n    Futures traders who act as brokers, ho'
data: 'wever, maintain that\ntrading for their own accounts is necessary in'
data: ' order to make up\nfor errors they inevitably make when filling cust'
data: 'omer orders in\nchaotic futures trading pits.\n    "To have an absol'
data: 'ute ban on dual trading makes it difficult\nfor a broker to function'
data: ' because of his errors," said John\nMichael, vice president at First'
data: ' Options of Chicago.\n    "What it comes down to is the ethics of th'
data: 'e people involved,"\nhe said.\n    Furthermore, the competitive natu'
data: "re of futures brokerage\nmakes front-running risky to a broker's liv"
data: 'elihood, he said.\n    "If I ever discovered a broker doing it (fron'
data: 't-running), or\neven suspected him of doing it, I would cut him off,'
data: '" Michael\nsaid.\n    An average broker in the Treasury bond futures'
data: ' pit, for\ninstance, will fill orders for 5,000 to 10,000 contracts '
data: 'a day\nat 1.25 dlrs per contract, floor sources said.  Even figuring'
data: '\nwhat is considered a typical 25 pct loss for errors such\nbrokerag'
data: 'e can be lucrative.\n    Front-running by brokers not only runs the '
data: 'market risk of\nan adverse price move, but also the risk of losing t'
data: 'he\nbrokerage business, Michael said.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'
end tag: </reuters>

start tag: <body>
data: 'WEDGE Group Inc, a Houston investment\nfirm with a 5.5 pct stake in '
data: 'American Medical International\nInc, said it has had talks with Pesc'
data: 'h and Co, which is seeking\ncontrol of the company.\n    In a filing'
data: ' with the Securities and Exchange Commission,\nWEDGE, which is owned'
data: ' by Issam Fares, a Lebanese citizen living\nin Switzerland, also sai'
data: 'd it discussed the possibility of\njoining with others in its own bi'
data: 'd to seek control of AMI.\n    WEDGE stressed that it has no current'
data: ' plans to seek control\nof AMI, but refused to rule out a takeover t'
data: 'ry in the future.\n    WEDGE said it has had discussions with AMI ma'
data: 'nagement,\nPesch, the closely held health care and investment concer'
data: 'n\ncontrolled by Chicago physician LeRoy Pesch, and other AMI\nshare'
data: 'holders.\n    It did not specify in its SEC filing which issues --\n'
data: 'selling its AMI stake or joining with others in a takeover try\n-- w'
data: 'ere discussed with which group. But it said the talks did\nnot produ'
data: 'ce any agreements or understandings.\n    WEDGE said it believes tha'
data: 't "some form of restructuring of\nAMI and its business would be high'
data: 'ly desirable and appropriate\nat this time."\n    WEDGE, which holds'
data: ' 4.8 mln shares of AMI common stock, said\nit plans to hold further '

data: 'The staff of the federal Securities\nand Exchange Commission (SEC) p'
data: 'lans to recommend that the\nWashington Public Power Supply System (W'
data: 'PPSS) be charged with\nsecurities fraud in connection with its July '
data: '1983 default on\n2.25 billion dlrs of bonds, a WPPSS official told R'
data: 'euters.\n    WPPSS attorney Ron English said the system was advised '
data: 'by\nSEC staff attorneys that the five SEC commissioners would be\nas'
data: 'ked to charge WPPSS in connection with its official\nstatements abou'
data: 't its plans to build its No. 3 and No. 4 nuclear\npower plants in th'
data: 'e Pacific Northwest at the time it was\nselling the bonds.\n    Engl'
data: 'ish, in a telephone interview, said the SEC staff\nplanned to allege'
data: ' that WPPSS had overstated the demand for\npower in the region and h'
data: 'ad understated the cost of the plants,\nwhich were to built with the'
data: " bonds' proceeds.\n    English denied the allegations. He said WPPSS"
data: ' had made no\npublic forecasts of power demand in connection with th'
data: 'e bond\nsale and had never understated the cost of the plants.\n    '
data: '"We at all times told the public everything we knew about\nthe costs'
data: '," he said.\n    English said WPPSS had no indication when the SEC m'
data: "ight\nmeet on the staff's recommendations.\n    The SEC, as a matter"
data: ' of policy, never comments on its\nenforcement activities.\n    The '
data: "SEC's WPPSS investigation began in late 1983 and the\nagency's slow "
data: 'pace on the probe has been publicly criticized on\nseveral occasions'
data: ' since then by Rep. John Dingell, the Michigan\nDemocrat who chairs '
data: "the House panel responsible for the SEC's\nbudget and operations.\n "
data: '   Of the five nuclear plants originally envisioned by WPPSS,\none h'
data: 'as been completed, two remain under construction, and two\nothers--t'
data: 'hose for which the defaulted bonds were sold-- have\nbeen terminated'

data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'AIBD, CEDEL, EUROCLEAR JOIN IN TRADE MATCH SYSTEM'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    LONDON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The Association of International Bond\nDealers, AIBD, said it will c'
data: 'ooperate with major clearing\nagencies Cedel and Euroclear on a euro'
data: 'bond trade confirmation\nand matching system to come into force by S'
data: 'eptember this year.\n    The system, designed to give market partici'
data: 'pants a fast and\nreliable way of checking whether transactions are '
data: 'matched, will\ninitially cover reporting of confirmed and mismatched'
data: ' trades.\n    It will include recording additional trade data, check'
data: 'ing,\ncomparison and matching any new elements but will only apply\n'
data: 'initially to delivery against payment transactions, AIBD said.\n    '
data: 'The AIBD said in a statement it would be responsible for\ndeveloping'
data: ' suitable rules to back up the two clearing systems\nwhen they intro'
data: 'duce their new matching matching facilities and\nconfirmation system'
data: 's by September this year.\n    Euroclear and Cedel intend to bring a'
data: ' "trade date-plus-one"\nmatching capacity, reporting on a given day '
data: 'on trades entered\nby 1000 London time, designed to work with a plan'
data: "ned AIBD rule\nrequiring the entry of previous day's trades by that "
data: 'time.\n    The confirmation system covering critical trade data is\n'
data: 'designed to aid the trader and the settlements department and\nalso '
data: 'reduce trading risks in volatile markets, AIBD said.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'
end tag: </reuters>

data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'AIBD, CEDEL, EUROCLEAR JOIN IN TRADE MATCH SYSTEM'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    LONDON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The Association of International Bond\nDealers, AIBD, said it will c'
data: 'ooperate with major clearing\nagencies Cedel and Euroclear on a euro'
data: 'bond trade confirmation\nand matching system to come into force by S'
data: 'eptember this year.\n    The system, designed to give market partici'
data: 'pants a fast and\nreliable way of checking whether transactions are '
data: 'matched, will\ninitially cover reporting of confirmed and mismatched'
data: ' trades.\n    It will include recording additional trade data, check'
data: 'ing,\ncomparison and matching any new elements but will only apply\n'
data: 'initially to delivery against payment transactions, AIBD said.\n    '
data: 'The AIBD said in a statement it would be responsible for\ndeveloping'
data: ' suitable rules to back up the two clearing systems\nwhen they intro'
data: 'duce their new matching matching facilities and\nconfirmation system'
data: 's by September this year.\n    Euroclear and Cedel intend to bring a'
data: ' "trade date-plus-one"\nmatching capacity, reporting on a given day '
data: 'on trades entered\nby 1000 London time, designed to work with a plan'
data: "ned AIBD rule\nrequiring the entry of previous day's trades by that "
data: 'time.\n    The confirmation system covering critical trade data is\n'
data: 'designed to aid the trader and the settlements department and\nalso '
data: 'reduce trading risks in volatile markets, AIBD said.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'OPEC PRESIDENT SAYS OIL MARKET BEING MANIPULATED'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    KINGSTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'OPEC president Rilwanu Lukman accused\n"oil market manipulators" of '
data: 'drawing down their own stocks and\nspreading rumours to give the imp'
data: 'ression OPEC was breaking its\n15.8 mln barrels per day output ceili'
data: 'ng, set last December.\n    Lukman told reporters the aim was to pul'
data: 'l prices below the\n18 dlrs per barrel reference level set by OPEC.\n'
data: '    "People are playing a waiting game to test the will of OPEC\nby '
data: 'drawing down more on their stock than normal, and this is\nhaving th'
data: 'e effect of giving an apparent excess supply on the\nmarket which we'
data: ' know is not real," Lukman said.\n    Lukman, Nigeria\'s oil ministe'
data: 'r, said that despite probable\n"minor deviations" by one or two memb'
data: 'er countries, "basically OPEC\nis producing around what it said it w'
data: 'ould produce."\n    After OPEC\'s price and production accord last D'
data: 'ecember, the\nmarket firmed steadily but spot prices fell in the las'
data: 't week to\naround 16 dlrs. Industry reports estimated the organizati'
data: 'on was\nproducing up to one mln bpd above its ceiling during Februar'
data: 'y.\n    But Lukman was confident OPEC would maintain its\ndiscipline'
data: ', in view of past experience. "We have the experience\nof what happe'
data: 'ned in 1986 behind us, when violations of\nagreements led to the col'
data: 'lapse of the market," he said.\n    Lukman was in Kingston as a gues'
data: 't of the state-owned\nPetroleum Corp of Jamaica.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Thousands of Spanish farmers battled\npolice in this northeastern ci'
data: 'ty during a march to demand a\nbetter deal from the EC, protest orga'
data: 'nisers said.\n    The farmers traded stones for tear gas and rubber '
data: 'pellets\nand occupied local government buildings in Saragossa.\n    '
data: 'In the southern city of Malaga, citrus growers dumped more\nthan 20 '
data: 'tonnes of lemons on the streets to protest against\nduties levied by'
data: ' the EC against their exports.\n    Spain joined the community in Ja'
data: 'nuary last year and farmers\nsay they have suffered competition from'
data: ' EC imports without\nsufficient compensation.\n Reuter\n\x03'

end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    GENEVA, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Chrysler Corp <C> will begin exporting\nvehicles before the end of t'
data: "his year to Europe, the world's\nsecond largest market, which it lef"
data: 't in 1978.\n    Robert Lutz, executive vice president, told a news\n'
data: 'briefing: "After a lapse of almost nine years, Chrysler is about\nto'
data: ' re-enter the European market. And we are here to stay."\n    Michae'
data: 'l Hammes, vice president of international operations,\nsaid Chrysler'
data: ' planned to market "a few hundred vehicles" by year\nend. "By the en'
data: 'd of 1988, we hope to reach 5,000." The first cars\nwould be sold in'
data: ' West Germany, Austria and Switzerland, he\nsaid.\n    The European '
data: 'base would be in West Germany, but no final\ndecision had been made '
data: 'on other sites.\n    The company will not set up its own dealer fran'
data: 'chises, but\nintends to work through distributors who will wholesale'
data: ' the\nvehicles to a franchised dealer organisation.\n    Lutz commen'
data: 'ted, "We prefer to export to Europe rather than\nmanufacture here be'
data: 'cause it will allow us to take full\ncompetitive advantage of the fa'
data: 'vourable exchange rates due to\nthe declining value of the dollar."\n'
data: "    The vehicles, on show at this week's Geneva motor show,\ninclude"
data: ' Chrysler LeBaron Turbo coupe and convertible, the Dodge\nLancer ES '
data: 'four-door hatchback, the Dodge Shadow ES compact, the\nPlymouth Voya'
data: 'ger miniwagon and the Dodge Daytona Shelby Z.\n    Chrysler is aimin'
data: 'g for the mainstream European buyer, who\nappreciates sporty cars wi'
data: 'th 2.2 litre engines, officials said.\n    Prior to negotiating a lo'
data: 'an guarantee program with the U.S.\nGovernment in 1978, Chrysler sol'
data: 'd its European operations to\nPeugeot SA <PEUP.P>. Chrysler now owns'
data: ' 24 pct of Mitsubishi\nMotors Corp <MIMT.T> and 15 pct of <Maserati>'
data: ', which may serve\nas European distribution channels in future, Hamm'
data: 'es said.\n Reuter\n\x03'

start tag: <body>
data: "Ford Motor Co's program to introduce\nair-bags in its compact cars i"
data: 's facing widespread resistance\nfrom both consumers and dealers, a t'
data: 'rade paper said.\n    As of February 20, Automotive News said Ford d'
data: 'ealers had\nsold only 455 1987-model Ford Tempos equipped with airba'
data: 'gs and\n294 similarly-equipped Mercury Topaz models compared with mo'
data: 're\nthan 100,000 of the standard-equipped compact models.\n    Ford '
data: 'has projected output of 12,000 Tempo and Topaz models\nequipped with'
data: ' airbags in the 1987 model year, but Automotive\nNews said the curre'
data: 'nt inventory of unsold cars represents a\ndisastrously high 1-1/2-ye'
data: "ar supply at current selling rates.\n    Most of Ford's sales of the"
data: ' compact cars equipped with air\nbags have been made to fleet buyers'
data: ' such as the U.S.\ngovernment, the paper said, with 11,000 having be'
data: 'en sold since\nthey were announced in late 1985.\n    Ford executive'
data: 's recently said their goal is to sell\nannually between 500,000 and '
data: 'one mln cars equipped with air\nbags by 1990 if the federal governme'
data: 'nt will relax certain\nregulatory standards as has been urged by som'
data: 'e traffic safety\nadministrative staff.\n   \n Reuter\n\x03'

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: "ZIMBABWE'S MAIZE MOUNTAIN POSES ECONOMIC PROBLEM"
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Peter Gregson, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    HARARE, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'More than two mln tonnes of surplus maize\ndotted across Zimbabwe in'
data: ' huge piles is posing an economic\nheadache for the country.\n    Th'
data: "e grain, Southern Africa's staple, has been bought by the\nGrain Mar"
data: 'keting Board (GMB) at prices guaranteed before it was\nplanted, and '
data: 'is costing the GMB about 27 mln dlrs a month in\nstorage and interes'
data: 't payments to make the purchases.\n    Accumulated over the past two'
data: ' years of bumper harvests, the\nsurplus represents about two years o'
data: 'f domestic consumption and\nis set to grow as further deliveries are'
data: ' due shortly.\n    Some deals have been made with aid donors, such a'
data: 's European\ncountries and Australia, to provide Zimbabwe with wheat '
data: 'in\nreturn for maize sent to neighbouring Mozambique, where the\nUni'
data: 'ted Nations has urged greater world efforts to feed the\nhungry.\n  '
data: '  But transport constraints keep those figures low and the\nonly sig'
data: 'nificant dent was a sale of 250,000 tonnes to South\nAfrica last yea'
data: 'r.\n    Because of the costs it has incurred, the GMB cannot afford\n'
data: 'to give the maize away and the standard 90 kg bags have been\naccumu'
data: 'lating, economists here said.\n    But failure to find buyers on glu'
data: 'tted world grain markets\nis damaging Zimbabwe, as it needs foreign '
data: 'exchange to finance\nimports for other areas of the economy, the eco'
data: 'nomists added.\n    "At present, it is a no-win situation. Let us ho'
data: 'pe some of\nthe extra aid (UN) Secretary General Javier Perez de Cue'
data: 'llar\ncalled for at the weekend will be spent here," a Western aid\n'
data: 'specialist said.\n    "At least this year\'s poor rains haven\'t exa'
data: 'cerbated the\nsituation too badly," he added. Rainfall during the cu'
data: 'rrent\nrainy season has been far below average, ravaging all but the'
data: '\nirrigated lands of large commercial farmers.\n    While this may c'
data: 'urb the amount of maize delivered this year\nto the GMB, the governm'
data: 'ent also acted late last year to slash\nmaize production and force d'
data: 'iversification.\n    Calling for a switch to other crops such as oil'
data: 'seeds,\nAgriculture Minister Moven Mahachi said an economically-viab'
data: 'le\nprice of 180 dlrs a tonne would be paid this year for only half\n'
data: 'the amount of maize bought by the GMB in 1986, and above that\ngrowe'
data: 'rs would be paid an unprofitable 100 dlrs.\n    The poor rains have '
data: 'also adversely affected other crops,\nsuch as sorghum, soybeans, gro'
data: 'undnuts, tobacco and cotton, the\nAgriculture Ministry reported at t'
data: 'he end of February.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

data: '-02 0084'
end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'TECHNOLOGY/CHIP INDUSTRY SEEKS CUSTOM DESIGNS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Catherine Arnst, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    NEW YORK, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'U.S. semiconductor manufacturers,\nstruggling to stem a river of red'
data: ' ink, are increasingly looking\ntoward customized designs rather tha'
data: 'n mass-market chips for\nfuture profits.\n    The market for customi'
data: 'zed chips - semiconductors designed\nfor a very specific application'
data: ' or product - is expected to\nexpand by 25 to 30 pct this year, comp'
data: 'ared with only about six\npct for the entire integrated circuit indu'
data: 'stry.\n     Market researcher Dataquest Inc estimates that sales of\n'
data: 'customized chips totaled about 4.5 billion dlrs worldwide last\nyear'
data: ', about 12 pct of the total chip market. By 1990, however,\ncustomiz'
data: 'ed chips are expected to represent a 12 billion to 15\nbillion dlr m'
data: 'arket, about 25 pct of total chip sales.\n    More important for the'
data: 'ir vendors, because they are not a\nstandard design customized chips'
data: " represent a sellers' market,\nand prices and profit margins can be "
data: 'set accordingly.\n    High volume memory chips have become "a perfec'
data: 't commodity\nmarket," Robert Brodersen, a professor of electrical\ne'
data: 'ngineering at the University of California at Berkeley, told\nan ind'
data: 'ustry forum.\n    "The product is interchangeable between one manufa'
data: 'cturer\nand another and customers base their buying decisions almost'
data: '\nentirely on price," Brodersen said. \n    He predicted that, in th'
data: "e next few years, only a handful of\nthe world's largest chip manufa"
data: 'cturers (most of them Japanese)\nwill produce memory chips, the stan'
data: 'dard electronic component\nfound in everything from digital watches '
data: 'to computers. "The\nrest of the industry just won\'t be involved."\n'
data: "    Last week's International Solid State Circuits Conference,\nthe "
data: "chip industry's annual forum for new developments, seemed\nto suppor"
data: "t Brodersen's prediction.\n     Of the 116 papers presented at the c"
data: 'onference, some 40 pct\nhad Japanese authors, the first time they ha'
data: 've outnumberd the\nUnited States. Most of the Japanese chip designs '
data: 'were in the\nmemory category, including Nippon Telephone and Telegra'
data: "ph Co's\nattention-grabbing 16 mln bit dynamic random access memory\n"
data: '(dram) chip, 16 times more powerful than anything now\navailable.\n '
data: '   The most advanced memory chip described by a U.S. company\nwas In'
data: "ternational Business Machine Corp's <IBM> four mln bit\nchip, and IB"
data: 'M only manufactures chips for its own internal use,\nnot for the ope'
data: 'n market.\n    The problem with memory chips is that they are all ba'
data: 'sed on\nthe same, well known design standards, so they are easy to c'
data: 'opy\nand inexpensive to manufacture. Because such large Japanese\nco'
data: 'nglomerates as Sony Corp <SNE>, NEC Corp, <NIPNY> Matushita\nand Mit'
data: 'sui have their own enormous consumer and electronics\nproduct lines,'
data: ' they also have a guaranteeed internal market for\ntheir chips, so t'
data: 'hey can produce huge amounts at a very low\ncost per unit.\n    Cust'
data: 'omized chips, however, are designed for a specific\ncustomer, manufa'
data: 'ctured in small quantities and expensive\nrelative to standard chips'
data: '. Computer markets are increasingly\nlooking to customized chips bec'
data: 'ause they are difficult to copy,\nthus making the final product hard'
data: 'er to clone as well.\n    Intel Corp <INTC>, the leading manufacture'
data: 'r of the\nmicroprocessors that form the brains of most computers, al'
data: 'erted\nthe industry to its intention to switch to customized chips\n'
data: 'last fall.\n    The company, which just reported a loss for 1986, sa'
data: 'id it\nwill spend 75 mln dlrs over the next three years to turn itse'
data: 'lf\ninto a leading manufacturer of custom and semi-custom chips.\n  '
data: '  Intel joins some 275 companies already competing for a\npiece of t'
data: 'he customized chip business but it has an advantage\nthat the others'
data: ' do not. IBM, which owns a 20 pct stake in\nIntel, has agreed to sha'
data: 're the designs for many of the 15,000\nchips it makes for its own us'
data: 'e. Intel will customize those\ndesigns and sell them to others.\n   '
data: " It will also get to use IBM's proprietary computer system\nfor desi"
data: 'gning chips, considered by experts to be one of the\nmost advanced i'
data: "n the world.\n    Intel's success is still not guaranteed, however. "
data: 'Industry\nanalysts noted that it is far different to design a mass m'
data: 'arket\nitem than a customized chip that requires a close working\nre'
data: 'lationship with the customer.\n    Intel spent five years and 100 ml'
data: 'n dlrs developing its\nnewest 30386 microprocessor. A much faster tu'
data: 'rnarouond time,\nand much lower development costs, will be required '
data: 'for\ncustomized chips if the firm is to succeed.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'
end tag: </reuters>

start tag: <title>
data: 'CONTINENTAL ILL <CIL> TO RECHARACTERIZE LOSS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Continental Illinois Corp settled an\nadministrative complaint by th'
data: 'e Securities and Exchange\nCommission by agreeing to recharacterize '
data: '425 mln dlrs\npreviously reported in the second quarter 1984 as a "l'
data: 'oss of\nsale on loans."\n    Under the settlement, which was announc'
data: "ed simultaneously\nwith the filing of the SEC's administrative actio"
data: 'n, Continental\nagreed to restate earlier financial reports to singl'
data: 'e out the\n425 mln dlrs as a separate loan loss item instead of lump'
data: 'ing it\ntogether with another item. The bank holding company said th'
data: 'e\nchange does not affect its operating results for 1984.\n    The S'
data: 'EC stressed in the complaint that it was not\nchallenging Continenta'
data: "l's reported net loss for the second\nquarter of 1984.\n    But it s"
data: 'aid it was misleading for the bank to split the 950\nmln dlr loan lo'
data: 'ss provision in half, attributing 425 mln dlrs\nof it to the event o'
data: 'f sale.\n    The 425 mln dlrs should have been part of a 950 mln dlr'
data: '\nbillion dlr loan loss provision required by the Office of the\nCom'
data: 'ptroller of the Currency, the SEC said.\n    Continental had origina'
data: 'lly listed 565 mln dlrs of the loan\nloss provision as a credit loss'
data: ' and another 425 mln dlrs as a\nloss on sale of loans, the SEC said.'
data: '\n    It was misleading for the bank to list the 425 mln dlrs as\nlo'
data: 'ss on sale, which implied the loss would not have occurred\nhad ther'
data: 'e not been a sale of distressed loans to the Federal\nDeposit Insura'
data: 'nce Corp, the SEC said.\n    The bank should have listed 990 mln dlr'
data: 's as a credit loss\ninstead of 565 mln dlrs and should not have char'
data: 'ecterized the\nother 425 mln dlrs as a provision for loss on sale of'
data: ' loans,\nthe SEC said.\n    Continental agreed to the settlement wit'
data: 'h the SEC without\nadmitting or denying any violations, the SEC said'
data: '.\n    But it agreed to restate its 1984 financial statements to\nac'
data: "commodate the SEC's objections and to report to its\nshareholders a "
data: "summarized version of the SEC's administrative\naction against it, t"
data: 'he agency said.\n    A Continental official stressed that the settle'
data: 'ment in no\nway will result in any change or restatement of the comp'
data: "any's\nearnings for that period.\n Reuter\n\x03"
end tag: </body>

start tag: <title>
data: 'SEARS <S> DEAN WITTER UNIT AGREES TO SEC CENSURE'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Federal regulators said Dean Witter\nReynolds Inc, the brokerage sub'
data: 'sidiary of Sears, Roebuck and\nCo, agreed to a censure to settle cha'
data: 'rges that it failed to\nfully report cash transactions.\n    In a co'
data: 'mplaint which was issued simultaneously with the\nsettlement, the Se'
data: 'curities and Exchange Commission charged Dean\nWitter, the fourth la'
data: 'rgest U.S. brokerage house, with failing\nto report more than one ml'
data: 'n dlrs of cash transactions.\n    In its administrative complaint, t'
data: 'he SEC stressed that was\nnot charging Dean Witter with taking part '
data: 'in a scheme to\nlaunder cash.\n    But it said it found 35 single lu'
data: 'mp sum cash deposits in\nexcess of 10,000 dlrs made with Dean Witter'
data: "'s branch offices\nand another three multiple cash deposits made by "
data: 'a customer on\na single day which totaled more than 10,000 dlrs. The'
data: ' total\nunreported cash was 1,062,234 dlrs, the agency said.\n    Fe'
data: 'deral law requires brokerage firms and banks to report to\nthe Treas'
data: 'ury Department all cash deposits greater than 10,000\ndlrs.\n    Aft'
data: "er examining seven pct of the Dean Witter's branch\noffices between "
data: 'July 1983 and April 1985, the SEC said it found\nthat the firm repor'
data: 'ted 1,880,376 dlrs in cash deposits, each of\nwhich had been greater'
data: ' than 10,000 dlrs, but failed to report\nanother 1,062,234 dlrs.\n  '
data: '  Besides agreeing to the censure, Dean Witter agreed to\ntighten it'
data: 's oversight of its branch offices.\n    Another major brokerage firm'
data: ', E.F. Hutton Group Inc,\nrecently disclosed in an SEC filing that a'
data: ' federal grand jury\nin Providence, R.I., was probing its compliance'
data: ' with cash\ndeposit reporting requirements at its Providence office.'
data: '\n Reuter\n\x03'

data: 'd last weekend by tin producing\ncountries to limit group exports to'
data: ' 96,000 tonnes in the year\nstarted March 1, a government official s'
data: 'aid.\n    The agreement by the seven-member Association of Tin\nProd'
data: 'ucing Countries (ATPC) aimed to cut the world surplus and\nboost pri'
data: 'ces. Following the accord, ATPC Chairman Subroto\nappealed to the Un'
data: 'ited States to restrict its tin releases from\nits strategic stockpi'
data: 'le.\n    "We don\'t think that (the U.S. government) has a large\nin'
data: 'fluence in the (tin) market at this stage of the game," said\nThomas'
data: " O'Donnell, Director of International Commodities at the\nState Depa"

data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'DOT REJECTS SMOKING BAN ON DOMESTIC FLIGHTS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The U.S. Department of Transportation\n(DOT) has concluded that a ba'
data: 'n on smoking on all domestic\nairline flights is not justified at th'
data: 'is time.\n    The department made known its conclusions in a report '
data: 'to\nCongress, made public today, on a recommendation by the\nNationa'
data: 'l Academy of Sciences that such a ban be adopted.\n    "We agree tha'
data: 't exposure to environmental tobacco smoke could\nbe viewed as a prob'
data: 'lem by some crew and passengers. However, we\nbelieve that further s'
data: 'tudy is needed before the department can\npropose a definitive respo'
data: 'nse to this recommendation," the DOT\nreport said.\n    The National'
data: ' Academy of Sciences (NAS) had studied the\nissue of smoking on airl'
data: 'ines under a DOT grant.\n    It recommended a ban in August after co'
data: "ncluding that\ntobacco smoke, when confined to an airliner's cabin, "
data: 'posed\npotential health hazards to cabin crew members, irritated \np'
data: 'assengers and crew, and created a risk of fires.\n    The DOT said m'
data: 'ore study was needed of the health effects of\nenvironmental tobacco'
data: ' smoke and of the concentration and\ndistribution of pollutants on v'
data: 'arious aircraft types.\n    It also called for more study of possibl'
data: 'e changes in\naircraft ventilation systems and said it wanted to spe'
data: 'nd more\ntime considering whether a ban should be extended to \ninte'
data: 'rnational as well as domestic flights.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'
end tag: </reuters>

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'AMC <AMO> SAYS STEPS TAKEN AFTER UAW TALKS FAIL'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Richard Walker, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    DETROIT, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'American Motors Corp said it will take\nsteps to build a proposed ne'
data: 'w jeep vehicle at an unspecified\n"alternative location" after the w'
data: 'eekend breakdown of talks\nwith the United Automobile Workers union '
data: "on a concessionary\ncontract covering workers at AMC's Wisconsin ope"
data: 'rations.\n    AMC spokesman Lloyd Northard told Reuters that the com'
data: 'pany\nwill not build its new Jeep ZJ sports utility vehicle at its\n'
data: "Kenosha, Wisc., assembly plant as a result of the talks'\nfailure.\n"
data: '    "We sincerely regret this outcome, but the responsibility\nfor i'
data: 't rests entirely with the local union bargaining\ncommittees," the c'
data: 'ompany said in a statement.\n    "We will, therefore, initiate the a'
data: 'ctions necessary to\nplace the new Jeep product in an alternative lo'
data: 'cation rather\nthan at Kenosha."\n    UAW officials said during the '
data: 'weekend they did not regard\nthe collapse of talks as final after th'
data: 'e company\'s "final"\nproposal on a new contract was unanimously rej'
data: "ected by union\nbargainers.\n    But AMC said the union's rejection "
data: 'of its concessions\npackage means that plants in Kenosha and Milwauk'
data: 'ee will lose\n6,500 jobs because the assembly complex in Kenosha "wi'
data: 'll not be\ngetting new work" as had been proposed with a new contrac'
data: 't.\n    "This unfortunate outcome demonstrates the difficulty of\nma'
data: 'intaining existing working and bringing new work to existing\nU.S. o'
data: 'perations," AMC said.\n    Asked if the company considered the decis'
data: 'ion to phase out\nthe Kenosa plant by 1989 as previously detailed to'
data: ' be final,\nNorthard said: "If the union came to us and said they wo'
data: 'uld\naccept our final proposal, that\'s another matter."\n    But th'
data: 'e company charged bargainers for UAW Locals 72 and 75\nhad reneged o'
data: 'n commitments for a new agreement with lower labor\nrates made in 19'
data: '85 when the union locals negotiated a\nconcessionary agreement cover'
data: "ing AMC's Wisconsin operations.\n    AMC, which last week reported i"
data: 'ts first profitable quarter\nin two years, said it wanted a contract'
data: ' for the plants with\nlabor rates and work rules comparable to agree'
data: 'ments between the\nUAW and Japanese automakers operating in the U.S.'
data: '\n    Wall Street investors reacted to the AMC-UAW impasse by\ndrivi'
data: "ng down AMC's stock price. In active trading, AMC was off\n3/8 to 3-"
data: "1/2, a 9.7 pct decline since Friday's close.\n   \n Reuter\n\x03"
end tag: </body>

data: 'ng their direct-dealing screens\navailable to many of those firms th'

data: 'll sell their\ndirect-dealing screens to only primary dealers in U.S'
data: '.\nGovernment securities or those that have applied to the Federal\n'
data: 'Reserve Bank of New york to become a primary dealer.\n    The U.S. J'
data: 'ustice department is looking into whether\nlimiting access to the sc'
data: 'reens to just a small group of dealers\nis a violation of U.S. Anti-'
data: 'trust laws.\n    Primary dealers, of which there are now 40, are an '
data: 'elite\ngroup of firms approved to buy Treasury securities directly\n'
data: 'from the Fed.\n    But Lacy said that any agreement to expand access'
data: " to the\nbrokers' direct-dealing screens is likely to be not as\nfar"
data: '-reaching as some would like. Instead of making screens\navailable t'
data: 'o any firm willing to pay for one, he said, it is\nmore likely that '
data: 'a "second tier" will be established.\n    He also said that RMJ is n'
data: 'ot willing to break away from the\ngroup of bond brokers and be the '
data: 'only firm to make its screens\nwidely available to any one who wants'
data: ' them.\n    Bond market sources had speculated that RMJ is better\np'
data: 'repared to offer its services nationwide than its three major\ncompe'
data: 'titors.\n    Lacy also said that he does not see any immediate press'
data: 'ure\nfor a further cut in commissions paid on bond transactions any\n'
data: 'time soon. In late 1985, transaction fees paid to brokers were\ncut '
data: 'in half to 39 dlrs per mln dlr transaction from 78 dlrs.\n    Some U'
data: '.S. primary bond dealers have been suggesting that\nwith further inc'
data: 'reases in transaction volume, fees can be cut\nwithout hurting the b'

data: 'ut by 9.5 pct over two years agreed in outline last\nDecember after '
data: 'virtually nine days of non-stop negotiations.\n    The accord, which'
data: ' is due to operate from the start of the\nnew milk marketing year on'
data: ' April 1, was hailed as the most\nsignificant step in an on-going ca'
data: 'mpaign to reform costly EC\nfarm policies and cut embarrassing food '
data: 'surpluses.\n    Diplomats say the December agreement itself is not\n'
data: 'threatened but that its effect could be considerably weakened\nif th'
data: 'e proposals are altered too radically.\n    West Germany and Ireland'
data: " are opposed to proposed limits on\na farmer's now automatic right t"
data: 'o sell surplus butter into\npublic stores when market prices and sto'
data: 'cks are high.\n    Faced with a butter "mountain" of a record 1.2 ml'
data: 'n tonnes\ncosting over two mln dlrs per day just to store, EC farm\n'

data: 't production to meet demand.\n    He is keen to reach an agreement o'
data: 'n the milk problem before\nthe ministers move on to consider this ye'

data: 'Sears, Roebuck and Co said it will\nrestructure its distribution ope'
data: 'rations, resulting in a 20 mln\ndlr after-tax charge against earning'
data: 's in its first quarter.\n    The retailer on April 30 will close its'
data: ' major Chicago\ndistribution center as the first part of the restruc'
data: 'turing. A\nspokesman said up to 1,800 workers will be affected, with'
data: ' many\nof them laid off. Some of the workers may be transferred to\n'
data: 'other Sears operations.\n    Sears said the restructuring and consol'
data: 'idation will save\nabout 150 mln dlrs by 1991.\n    Sears said it wi'
data: 'll set up a nationwide network of seven\nregions to handle all aspec'
data: 'ts of distribution of its products.\n    The closing of the Chicago '
data: 'plant will be followed by the\nshutdown of four other distribution u'
data: 'nits over the next several\nyears. Distribution centers will be clos'
data: 'ed in Boston, Atlanta,\nMemphis and Minneapolis, with the Boston shu'
data: 'tdown coming early\nnext year. No other closings are planned before '
data: '1989.\n    A spokesman said that, while there will be layoffs at tho'
data: 'se\nfacilities, the company does not yet know how many workers will\n'
data: "be let go.\n    Sears' distribution will be consolidated under regio"
data: 'nal\nmanagement in Columbus, Ohio, Dallas, Greensboro, N.C.,\nJackso'
data: 'nville, Fla., Kansas City, Mo., Los Angeles and\nPhiladelphia. Howev'
data: 'er, Sears said it will also evaluate the\nproductivity of the Los An'
data: 'geles and Philadelphia facilities "to\ndetermine whether they will b'
data: 'e modernized or relocated."\n    Responsibility for ordering distrib'
data: 'ution center inventory\nwill be centralized in Chicago.\n Reuter\n\x03'

start tag: <body>
data: 'B.F. Goodrich Co said it will phase\nout the production of aircraft '
data: 'tires, missile and marine\nproducts and molded rubber products in Ak'
data: 'ron, Ohio, by the end\nof 1987, laying off about 790 salaried, produ'
data: 'ction, maintenance\nand support services employees.\n    The company'
data: ' said layoffs will start within the next few\nweeks.\n    Goodrich s'
data: 'aid it will continue to make chemicals and\nadhesives in Akron, empl'
data: 'oying about 356.  Another 5000 salaried\nemployees in Akron work for'
data: ' Goodrich.\n    The company said it has not been able to operate the'
data: '\nbusinesses being discontinued in Akron profitably enough to\njusti'
data: 'fy the large investment that it has in them.\n    Goodrich said it w'
data: 'ill continue to make aircraft tires at\nNorwood, N.C., and sonar dom'
data: 'es at Jacksonville, Fla., and will\nrelocate its molded rubber produ'
data: 'cts business to a site not yet\nchosen.  It said it will stop making'
data: ' insulators for missiles.\n    Goodrich said it is prepared to discu'
data: 'ss with officials of\nthe United Rubber Workers Union severance bene'
data: 'fits for affected\nemployees and issues related to the continued ope'
data: 'ration in\nAkron of the chemical and adhesives businesses and to the'
data: '\nphaseout of the Akron aircraft tire, missile and marine and\nmolde'
data: 'd rubber products manufacturing.\n    A company spokesman said it do'
data: 'es not expect any adverse\nimpact on earnings from the move.\n Reute'

end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'NYMEX WILL EXPAND OFF-HOUR TRADING APRIL ONE'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '     By BERNICE NAPACH, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '     NEW YORK, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The New York Mercantile Exchange set\nApril one for the debut of a n'
data: 'ew procedure in the energy\ncomplex that will increase the use of en'
data: 'ergy futures worldwide.\n     On April one, NYMEX will allow oil tra'
data: 'ders that do not\nhold a futures position to initiate, after the exc'
data: 'hange closes,\na transaction that can subsequently be hedged in the '
data: 'futures\nmarket, according to an exchange spokeswoman.\n    "This wi'
data: 'll change the way oil is transacted in the real\nworld," said said T'
data: 'homas McKiernan, McKiernan and Co chairman.\n    Foreign traders wil'
data: 'l be able to hedge trades against NYMEX\nprices before the exchange '
data: 'opens and negotiate prices at a\ndifferential to NYMEX prices, McKie'
data: 'rnan explained.\n     The expanded program "will serve the industry '
data: 'because the\noil market does not close when NYMEX does," said Frank '
data: 'Capozza,\nsecretary of Century Resources Inc.\n     The rule change,'
data: ' which has already taken effect for\nplatinum futures on NYMEX, is e'
data: 'xpected to increase the open\ninterest and liquidity in U.S. energy '
data: 'futures, according to\ntraders and analysts.\n    Currently, at leas'
data: 't one trader in this transaction, called\nan exchange for physical o'
data: 'r EFP, must hold a futures position\nbefore entering into the transa'
data: 'ction.\n    Under the new arrangement, neither party has to hold a\n'
data: 'futures position before entering into an EFP and one or both\npartie'
data: 's can offset their cash transaction with a futures\ncontract the nex'
data: 't day, according to exchange officials.\n    When NYMEX announced it'
data: 's proposed rule change in December,\nNYMEX President Rosemary McFadd'
data: 'en, said, "Expansion of the EFP\nprovision will add to globalization'
data: ' of the energy markets by\nproviding for, in effect, 24-hour trading'
data: '."\n    The Commodity Futures Trading Commission approved the rule\n'
data: 'change in February, according to a CFTC spokeswoman.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'
end tag: </reuters>

end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: "HUGHES' U.S. RIG COUNT SLIPS TO 801 THIS WEEK"
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    HOUSTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'U.S. drilling activity continued to slow\nlast week as the number of'
data: ' active rotary rigs fell by 38 to a\ntotal of 801, against 1,248 wor'
data: 'king rigs one year ago, Hughes\nTool Co said.\n    Most of the decre'
data: 'ase came among rigs used for onshore\ndrilling, which dropped to a t'
data: "otal of 707 from last week's 744.\nA total of 77 rigs were active of"
data: 'fshore and 17 in inland waters\nduring the week, Hughes Tool said.\n'
data: '    Among individual states, Texas lost 24 working rigs,\nMichigan d'
data: 'ropped by six, and California, New mexico and Kansas\nwere each down'
data: ' by one. Colorado reported a gain of eight rigs\nand Louisiana was u'
data: 'p by four.\n    In Canada, the rig count was up 14 to 164, against 4'
data: '22 one\nyear ago.\n Reuter\n\x03'

start tag: <body>
data: 'A bidding war for Viacom International\nInc, one of the largest U.S.'
data: ' entertainment companies, pitted a\nmanagement group and other inves'
data: 'tors against National\nAmusements Inc, a closely held theater operat'
data: 'or.\n    Both sides raised their bids over the weekend. A source\ncl'
data: 'ose to the management side insisted that timing was on his\nside. He'
data: ' said if outside directors approve the management\nproposal, a merge'
data: 'r plan could be put to a vote of shareholders\nwith proxy material g'
data: 'oing out late this week. "It would take 20\ndays from the day we mai'
data: 'l," said the source.\n    The source predicted National Amusements, '
data: 'controlled by\ninvestor Sumner Redstone, would need "half a year" to'
data: ' complete\na tender offer because of the regulatory approvals that m'
data: "ust\naccompany any change in control of Viacom's broadcast licenses\n"
data: 'and cable television franchises.\n    Redstone was not available for'
data: " comment.\n    Some of Wall Street's arbitrage players said it was a"
data: ' rare\nsituation that could only be enjoyed - a true bidding war. On'
data: 'e\nsaid Redstone could begin a tender offer whenever he wanted and\n'
data: 'if enough people were convinced his proposal was superior to\nthe Vi'
data: 'acom management plan, he would have a chance to win.\n    The indepe'
data: 'ndent directors of Viacom were called into a\nmeeting today. Word on'
data: ' a decision was expected early tomorrow.\n    Viacom shares climbed '
data: '2-1/2 to 50-3/8 by midafternoon. One\nmajor Wall Street firm issued '
data: 'a sell recommendation. "We think\nwe\'re at the end now, in terms of'
data: ' bidding," said the firm\'s\narbitrageur, who spoke on condition he '
data: "not be identified.\n    Both Redstone's proposal and the management "
data: 'proposal would\ncreate a restructured company heavily leveraged with'
data: ' debt. The\nmanagement plan would result in a balance sheet with abo'
data: 'ut 2.5\nbillion dlrs in debt and nearly 500 mln dlrs in preferred\ns'
data: "tock, convertible into 45 pct of the common stock.\n    Redstone's n"
data: 'ewest proposal offers holders 42 dlrs in cash,\na fraction of a shar'
data: 'e of exchangeable preferred stock with a\nvalue of 7.50 dlrs, and on'
data: 'e-fifth of a share of common stock\nstock of Arsenal Holdings, repre'
data: 'senting 20 pct of the equity\ninterest in the restructured Viacom. O'
data: 'ne arbitrageur calculated\nthe equity in the Redstone plan was worth'
data: ' 2.50 dlrs making the\ntotal package worth 52 dlrs per share.\n    M'
data: 'anagement offered 38.50 dlrs in cash, exchangeable\npreferred stock '
data: 'worth 8.50 dlrs and a fractional share of\nconvertible preferred. Th'
data: 'e arbitrageur said the equity portion\nwas worth about 4.00 dlrs for'
data: " a total of 51 dlrs.\n    Redstone's newest plan raised the amount o"
data: 'f interest he\nwould pay on the cash portion of his offer for every '
data: 'day beyond\nApril 30 that a merger with Arsenal is not consummated. '
data: 'The\nplan calls for intest to be paid at an annual rate of nine pct\n'
data: 'during May and 12 pct thereafter. Previously Redstone offered\neight'
data: ' pct interest.\n    Other arbitrageurs said both Redstone and the ma'
data: 'nagement\ngroup, led by president and chief executive Terrence Elkes'
data: ',\nwere offering high prices. "Redstone really wants to own the\ncom'
data: 'pany," one said. Another said management seemed to have the\nedge on'
data: " the timing issue.\n    Redstone's company owns 19.6 pct ov Viacom's"
data: ' 35 mln shares.\n    A Wall Street analyst said it was hard to deter'
data: 'mine what\nthe equity in the newly leveraged company would be worth.'
data: ' He\nnoted as an example that new stock in FMC Corp <FMC>, which\nad'
data: 'opted a highly leveraged structure last year, inititally\ntraded at '
data: '12.50 dlrs per share, dipped to nine dlrs, and is now\njust over 30 '

data: 'er 1.25 mln shares at\n37.50 dlrs.\n    Chris Craft Industries <CCN>'
data: ', which owns a stake in Warner,\nrose 1-1/4 to 22-3/4.\n    Viacom w'

data: '\n'

start tag: <body>
data: "Canada's decision to raise the issue\nof a free trade pact with the "
data: 'U.S. was a sign of what many see\nas a new spirit of Canadian self-c'
data: 'onfidence, a public policy\nstudy group said \n    "It suggests the '
data: 'Canada of the immediate post-war period,\nwhen it was a major player'
data: ' in the process of building a postwar\nworld," the Washington-based '
data: 'Atlantic Council said.\n    U.S. and Canadian negotiators opened tal'
data: 'ks last summer\naimed at dismantling trade barriers between the two '
data: "countries,\nthe world's biggest trading partners with crossborder sh"
data: "ipments\nof about 150 billion dlrs annually.\n    The council's stud"
data: 'y said the trade talks, with a deadline\nof October for an agreement'
data: ', are the biggest issue in\nU.S.-Canadian relations.\n   The study s'
data: 'aid liberalized trade between the two countries\nwould improve the c'
data: 'ompetitiveness of their economies in world\nmarkets and lessen trade'
data: ' irritants which now mar their ties.\n    The council said "in the p'
data: 'ast most Canadians have shied away\nfrom the notion of a free-trade '
data: 'arrangement, fearing to be\noverwhelmed economically and politically'
data: ' by a closer\nassociation with a country 10 times their size in popu'
data: 'lation."\n    But at the same time, it added, Canadians realized the'
data: 'ir\ndomestic market was too small to permit the mass production and\n'
data: 'sales needed to raise productivity to the level demanded by an\nincr'
data: 'easingly competitive world.\n    The council said that in the talks,'
data: ' Canada is chiefly\ninterested in minimizing the imposing of U.S. du'
data: 'ties against \nallegedly subsidized exports.\n    A recent example w'
data: 'as the 15 per cent duty the U.S. imposed\non Canadian lumber exports'
data: ' on grounds the shipments were being\nsubsidized.\n    The council s'
data: 'aid the chief U.S. concerns included ending\ncurbs against U.S. bank'
data: 'ing, insurance, telecommunications, and\nthe so-called "cultural ind'
data: 'ustries" - publishing, broadcasting\nand films.\n    It said other m'
data: 'ajor U.S.-Canadian issues were defense\ncooperation, "acid rain" and'
data: ' the U.S. rejection of a Canadian\nassertion of sovereignty over wat'
data: 'ers of the Northwest Passage.\n Reuter\n\x03'

data: '\n'

start tag: <body>

data: 'ction to protect pensions of\nemployees and retirees of Kaiser Steel'

end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    NEW YORK, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Imperial Chemical Industries PLC, the\nlargest chemical company in t'
data: 'he United Kingdom, will expand its\nspecialty chemicals and drug bus'
data: 'inesses this year, and better\nits 1986 results, said chairman-elect'
data: ' Denys Henderson.\n    "We expect to shift our company toward higher'
data: ' value-added\nbusinesses and continue to broaden our base," Henderso'
data: 'n told\nreporters at an informal meeting here.\n    ICI today announ'
data: 'ced the formation of a new U.S.\ndrug company, ICI Pharma, which, wi'
data: 'th its Stuart\nPharmaceuticals unit, it said will double its current'
data: '\npharmaceutical sales to 1.1 billion dlrs by 1990.\n    Henderson s'
data: 'aid, "Our pharmaceutical business gets lost in\nthe way that Glaxo\''
data: 's (Glaxo Holdings PLC) does not."\n    ICI\'s pharmaceutical divisio'
data: 'n is the second largest drug\nmaker behind Glaxo in the U.K. Last ye'
data: 'ar U.S. drug sales were\nabout 40 pct of its worldwide drug sales of'
data: ' 1.5 billion dlrs,\nwhich in turn brought in 27 pct of its total pro'
data: "fits.\n    He estimated that by 1990, ICI's pharmaceutical division\n"
data: 'would account for about 30 pct of total company profits.\n    "The d'
data: 'rug division far and away brings in the highest rate\nof return," sa'
data: 'id A.W. Clements, finance director of ICI, who\nwas also at the meet'
data: 'ing.\n    Henderson said the new U.S. drug concern would basically\n'
data: 'act as a second sales force to double the exposure of its drugs\nto '
data: 'doctors. ICI will hire 145 new salespeople by October one.\n    Hend'
data: "erson said the major new products in the company's\npipeline, expect"
data: 'ed to each bring in sales of over 200 mln dlrs\nannually, were Stati'
data: 'l, a treatment for diabetic complications,\nZoladex, a treatment for'
data: ' advanced prostate cancer, and Carwin,\na treatment for mild to mode'
data: 'rate congestive heart failure.\n    Henderson said U.S. Food and Dru'

data: 'cted until\nabout 1989. ICI expects to file for permission to market'

data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'FUNARO REJECTS UK SUGGESTION OF IMF BRAZIL PLAN'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    LONDON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Brazilian Finance Minister Dilson Funaro\nflatly rejected a U.K. Sug'
data: 'gestion that his country seek\nInternational Monetary Fund help in o'
data: 'rder to facilitate debt\nnegotiations with commercial creditor banks'
data: '.\n    Talking to reporters, Funaro said this attitude would not\nhe'
data: 'lp resolve the crisis started when Brazil suspended\nindefenitely in'
data: 'terest payments on 68 billion dlrs in external\ndebt on February 20.'
data: '\n    Funaro was in Britain on the first leg of a tour of\nEuropean '
data: 'capitals to explain the motives of the Brazilian debt\nmoratorium an'
data: 'd to seek support for intiatives to improve\ncapital flows between d'
data: 'eveloped countries and third world\ndebtor nations.\n   Talking befo'
data: 're his departure for Paris, he said there could\nbe no question of B'
data: 'razil adopting another IMF austerity plan\nafter a similar package f'
data: 'our years ago "put Brazil in a very big\nrecession."\n    "We had an'
data: ' IMF program - it simply meant export more and\nimport less. We are '
data: 'not going to go the IMF," he said.\n    Funaro was reactnng to a Bri'
data: 'tish statement following his\ntalks with Chancellor of the Exchequer'
data: ' Nigel Lawson, saying the\nU.K. Government had no part to play in wh'
data: 'at it viewed as a\nproblem between Brazil and its commercial credito'
data: 'r banks.\n    Britain also believed an IMF program would help along\n'
data: 'negotiations between Brazil and the commercial banks, the\nstatement'
data: ', which banking sources interpreted as an outright\nrebuttal of all '
data: 'Brazilian demands, said.\n    "That was not my impression of the mee'
data: 'ting," Funaro said; "But\nif the (British) answer is more or less li'
data: 'ke this, then\nthat means nothing is helping to find a solution."\n '
data: '   Funaro stressed that his talks in Washington last week and\nin Eu'
data: 'rope this week were aimed at gaining official support to\nunblock le'
data: 'nding from official credit agencies, rather than to\ndeal with Brazi'
data: 'ls ties with commercial banks.\n    "Since 1982, all official agenci'
data: 'es have been closed to my\ncountry," he said.\n    He said Lawson ha'
data: "d made no commitments to support Brazil's\nefforts. Lawson would off"
data: 'icially state his position when the\ntwo meet again next month for t'
data: 'he IMF and World Bank spring\nmeetings in Washington, Funaro said.\n'
data: "    Stressing there was no binding time schedule for Brazil's\ndebt "
data: 'problem to be resolved, Funaro said Brazil had not come to\nEurope w'
data: 'ith specific proposals to overcome the present crisis.\n    "We didn'
data: '\'t come here to make a cash-flow programme," he said,\n"We will hav'
data: 'e meetings at the IMF next month - let\'s see what\nhappens."\n    N'
data: 'either did Brazil plan a major overhaul of current\ndomestic economi'
data: 'c policies, which Funaro said would likely lead\nto a five pct econo'
data: 'mic growth this year.\n    "Over the past five years we paid back 45'
data: ' billion dlrs and\nreceived 11 billion ... This is a very big effort'
data: '," he said.\n"What we have to offer is our cooperation."\n Reuter\n\x03'

start tag: <body>
data: 'All major grain producing countries\nmust do their part to help redu'
data: 'ce global surpluses and the\nrecent Australian farm policy proposals'
data: ' are flawed, two U.S.\nwheat organizations said.\n    The recent Aus'
data: 'tralian proposals were a good starting point\nfor discussions, "but '
data: 'we do not want the Australians to feel\nthey are alone in developing'
data: ' an agenda for discussions" on world\ngrain trade, the president of '
data: 'the National Association of Wheat\nGrowers, NAWG, and the chairman o'
data: 'f U.S. Wheat Associates said\nin a letter to U.S. Agriculture Secret'
data: 'ary Richard Lyng and U.S.\nTrade Representative Clayton Yeutter.\n  '
data: '  Future discussions on international wheat trade should\ninclude th'
data: 'ree topics -- a commitment to privatization of\ngovernment-run expor'
data: 't trading entities, a commitment to public\ndisclosure of sales and '
data: 'other terms if government entities are\ninvolved, and a recognition '
data: 'that supply reductions by the U.S.\nhave kept world prices higher th'
data: 'an they otherwise would be, the\ntwo organizations said \n    While '
data: 'the Australian proposals are welcome the two\norganizations said the'
data: 'y are not in total agreement with their\nassessments.\n    Australia'
data: '\'s proposals, which aim to reduce U.S. target\nprices and "quaranti'
data: 'ne" U.S. wheat stocks, would continue to\nplace the burden of supply'
data: ' adjustment and reform on U.S.\nfarmers, they said.\n      Other cou'
data: 'ntries, including Australia, have benefitted\nfrom the higher world '
data: 'prices that have resulted from past U.S.\nacreage and crop reduction'
data: ' programs, the organizations said.\n    "We will not continue to hur'
data: 't ourselves economically -- and\nsubsidize foreign wheat production '
data: '-- by unilaterally stocking\ngrain and changing programs which prote'
data: 'ct our growers," Jim\nMiller, president of NAWG said.\n    "We since'
data: "rely hope for some type of agreement among the\nworld's major grain "
data: 'producing nations to reduce stocks and\nrestore profitability to agr'

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'BRAZIL CRITICISES ADVISORY COMMITTEE STRUCTURE'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Sandy Critchley, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    LONDON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Brazil is not happy with the existing\nstructure of the 14-bank advi'
data: 'sory committee which coordinates\nits commercial bank debt, Finance '
data: 'Minister Dilson Funaro said.\n    U.S. Banks have 50 pct representat'
data: "ion on the committee\nwhile holding only 35 pct of Brazil's debt to "
data: 'banks, he said,\nadding "This is not fair with the European and Japa'
data: 'nese banks."\nThe committee had played a useful role in 1982 and 198'
data: '3,\nhowever.\n    Noting the often different reactions of U.S., Japa'
data: 'nese and\nEuropean banks, Funaro told journalists that Brazil might '
data: 'adopt\nan approach involving separate discussions with the regions.\n'
data: "    Since debtor nations' problems were normally treated on a\ncase-"
data: 'by-case basis, "Perhaps the same principle should apply to\ncreditor'
data: 's," central bank president Francisco Gros said.\n    Brazil on Febru'
data: 'ary 20 suspended indefinitely interest\npayments on 68 billion dlrs '
data: 'owed to commercial banks, followed\nlast week by a freeze on bank an'
data: 'd trade credit lines deposited\nby foreign banks and institutions, w'
data: 'orth some 15 billion dlrs.\n    Funaro and Gros spent two days at th'
data: 'e end of last week in\nWashington talking to government officials an'
data: 'd international\nagencies and will this week visit Britain, France, '
data: 'West\nGermany, Switzerland and Italy for discussions with\ngovernmen'
data: 'ts.\n    Funaro and Gros are today meeting British Chancellor of the'
data: '\nExchequer Nigel Lawson, Foreign Secretary Geoffrey Howe and\nGover'
data: 'nor of the Bank of England Robin Leigh-Pemberton.\n    Bankers have '
data: 'estimated that Brazil owes U.K. Banks around\n8.5 billion dlrs in lo'
data: 'ng and medium term loans, giving the U.K.\nThe third largest exposur'
data: "e after the U.S. And Japan.\n    The crisis began when Brazil's trad"
data: 'e surplus, its chief\nmeans of servicing its foreign debt, started t'
data: 'o decline sharply\nand the problem was compounded by a renewed surge'
data: " in the\ncountry'rate of inflation.  Reserves were reported to have\n"
data: 'dropped below four billion dlrs.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

data: '    WASHINGTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The Treasury Department said the\nUnited States and the Virgin Islan'
data: 'ds have signed a tax treaty\nto exchange tax information and provide'
data: ' mutual assistance in\ntax matters.\n    The agreement was needed to'
data: ' trigger provisions of the Tax\nReform Act of 1986 allowing the Virg'
data: 'in Islands to offer\ninvestment incentives by reducing Virgin Island'
data: 's taxes on\nnon-U.S. source income, the Treasury said.\n    The trea'
data: 'ty will be a model for similar agreements to be\nnegotiated with thr'
data: 'ee other U.S. possessions -- American Samoa,\nthe Mariana Islands an'
data: 'd Guam, the Treasury said.\n    The new agreement, which expands and'
data: ' replaces a prior\nagreement with the Virgin Islands, was signed on '
data: 'February 24,\nthe Treasury said.\n Reuter\n\x03'

data: 'ce, if three-month LIBOR rises to 15 pct during\nthe life of the flo'
data: 'ating-rate tranche and falls back below the\n11 pct cap, investors w'
data: 'ould be paid back, dollar for dollar,\nthe amount of interest they w'

data: 'Board of Governors of the\nexchange approved the contract last month'

data: 'ct will be  0.01 cent per gallon, or 4.20 dlrs a barrel,\naccording '
data: 'to the exchange.\n    The maximum daily price limit will be two cts '
data: 'a gallon on\nall contracts except spot. Trading will terminate on th'
data: 'e last\nbusiness day of the month preceding the delivery month.\n   '
data: " The exchange said delivery will be F.O.B from the seller's\npipelin"
data: 'e, storage, or fractionation facility in Mont Belvieu,\nTexas, which'
data: ' has a direct pipeline access to the Texas Eastern\nTransmission Pip'
data: 'eline (TET) in Mont Beliview.\n    Delivery method will be by in-lin'
data: 'e or in-well transfer,\ninter-facility transfer or pumpover, or book'
data: ' transfer and\ncannot be done earlier than the tenth calendar day of'
data: ' the\ndelivery month, according to the exchange. Deliveries must be\n'
data: 'completed no later than two business days prior to the end of\nthe d'
data: 'elivery month.\n    Buyers taking delivery of the propane must pay t'

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'FRANCE HAS LITTLE ROOM FOR MANOEUVRE, OECD SAYS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    PARIS, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'French industry is failing to produce the\ngoods its markets need an'
data: 'd its loss of competitiveness has left\nthe government little room f'
data: 'or manoeuvre to reflate the\neconomy, the Organisation for Economic '
data: 'Cooperation and\nDevelopment said.\n    With gross domestic product '
data: 'likely to grow only 2.1 pct\nthis year, the same rate as last year, '
data: 'unemployment could climb\nto 11.5 pct of the workforce by mid-1988, '
data: 'from its present 10.9\npct, it said in an annual review of the Frenc'
data: 'h economy.\n    The report said the French economy was "increasingly'
data: '\nill-adapted to demand" selling goods at "uncompetitive relative\np'
data: 'rices on both domestic and export markets."\n    "France\'s poor exp'
data: 'ort performance reflects a geographical\nbias in favour of markets l'
data: 'ess dynamic than the average...\nAnd...A substantial loss of market '
data: 'share...In the past 18\nmonths," it said.\n    Pointing to a likely '
data: 'widening of the French trade deficit\nto around 2.9 billion dlrs thi'
data: 's year from 2.4 billion in 1986,\nit warned that a further depreciat'
data: 'ion of the dollar against the\nfranc could lead to "a (renewed) loss'
data: ' of competitiveness\nrelative not only to the United States but also'
data: ' to the newly\nindustrialised countries."\n    This could result in '
data: 'further major losses of market share,\nparticularly in the non-OECD '
data: 'area, which accounts for almost a\nquarter of French exports, it sai'
data: 'd.\n    Until the competitive ability of industry improved, the\naut'
data: 'horities would have "little scope for macroeconomic\nmanoeuvre, even'
data: ' if the unemployment situation or the need to\nencourage a pickup in'
data: ' investment could require demand to grow\nmore briskly," it added.\n'
data: '    But rising unemployment could help to hold down wage\ndemands, c'
data: 'ontributing to a slowdown in inflation to around a\ntwo pct annual r'
data: 'ate this year and early next, the OECD said.\n    Written mainly in '
data: 'December last year, the report took no\naccount of a rise in oil pri'
data: 'ces early in 1987, and a 0.9 pct\nsurge in January consumer prices, '
data: "caused partly by the\ngovernment's deregulation of service sector ta"
data: 'riffs.\n    "We took a bet that the freeing of prices would not prov'
data: 'oke\nrunaway rises, and it is not absolutely certain that bet has\nb'
data: 'een lost," one OECD official commented.\n    OECD officials said the'
data: ' January data and a rise in oil\nprices above the 15 dlrs a barrel a'
data: 'verage assumed in the\nreport, indicated an upward revision in the i'
data: 'nflation forecast\nto around 2.5 or three pct.\n    The government l'
data: 'ast week revised its forecast up to between\n2.4 and 2.5 pct from tw'
data: "o pct, against last year's 2.1 pct.\n    But the OECD backed the gov"
data: "ernment's view that the\nunderlying trend for inflation remained dow"
data: 'nwards this year,\nwith a slowdown in domestic costs taking over fro'
data: "m last year's\nfall in oil and commodity prices as the chief cause o"
data: 'f\ndisinflation.\n    With French unit productivity costs now among '
data: 'the lowest in\nthe OECD area, the inflation differential between Fra'
data: 'nce and\nits main trading rival, West Germany, could fall to just on'
data: 'e\npct this year, it said.\n    On the other hand, the report noted,'
data: ' consumer prices for\nindustrial goods and private services have bee'
data: 'n rising steeply\nas companies built up their profits.\n    "For the'
data: ' disinflationary process to continue , and price\ncompetitiveness to'
data: ' become lastingly compatible with exchange\nrate stability, it is es'
data: 'sential that wage restraint continue,"\nit said.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

data: ' dlrs, up\nfrom 151.4 mln dlrs in 1985.\n    Hartford said results f'
data: 'or the year were aided by a gain of\n46.5 mln dlrs on the sale of it'
data: 's remaining 52 pct stake in\nAbbey Life Group PLC. For 1985, the com'
data: 'pany posted a gain of\n14.3 mln dlrs on the sale of 48 pct of Abbey '
data: 'Life.\n    Hartford said total property-casualty and life-health\nwr'
