data: 'SEC PROBES 1986 TRE <TRE> TAKEOVER ATTEMPT'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The federal Securities and Exchange\nCommission (SEC) is looking for'
data: ' possible securities laws\nviolations in connection with an unsucces'
data: 'sful 1986 bid by\nHollywood producer Burt Sugarman to take over TRE '
data: 'Corp,\nattorneys contacted by SEC investigators said.\n    During th'
data: "e takeeover attempt, a unit of Sugarman's Giant\nGroup Ltd at one po"
data: 'int held a 9.9 pct stake in TRE.\n    It had help in that effort fro'
data: 'm Jefferies Group Inc, a Los\nAngeles investment banking firm which '
data: 'sold it an option on a\nportion of the shares Sugarman eventually ac'
data: 'quired.\n    In addition, a company controlled by Sugarman raised 35'
data: ' mln\ndlrs in a debt offering underwritten by Drexel Burnham Lambert'
data: '\nInc with help from Jefferies, and used a portion of the\nproceeds '
data: 'to buy TRE stock.\n    Finally, Reliance Group Holdings Inc acquired'
data: ' nearly six\npct of TRE, according to an SEEC filing.\n    The attor'
data: 'neys, who asked not to be identified, said the SEC\nwas investigatin'
data: 'g whether Sugarman and other firms with TRE\nholdings were working t'
data: 'ogether without disclosing their\ncooperation, as would be required '
data: 'by the federal securities\nlaws.\n    One attorney said SEC probers '
data: 'also were examining whether\nSugarman and Drexel had made adequate d'
data: 'isclosures of its\nintended usage of the proceeds in the prospectus '
data: 'for the 35 mln\ndlr bond offering.\n    A TRE spokesman confirmed th'
data: 'at TRE, since December a unit\nof Aluminum Co of America, had been c'
data: 'ontacted by SEC\ninvestigators and was cooperating with the probe.\n'
data: '    The spokesman added that TRE Chairman Leopold Wyler had\nbeen in'
data: 'terviewed by the SEC probers.\n    A Jefferies spokesman said the SE'
data: 'C had asked for\ninformation a few months ago as part of an informal'
data: ' probe.\n    The spokesman said Jefferies had cooperated with the ag'
data: 'ency\nand had heard nothing more since that time.\n    "To the best '
data: 'of our knowledge, Jefferies is not the target\nof a formal SEC inves'
data: 'tigation" in connection with the TRE bid,\nhe said.\n    A Drexel sp'
data: 'okesman acknowledged that his firm had\nunderwritten the debt offeri'
data: 'ng for Sugarman but added:\n    "We had nothing to do with TRE."\n  '
data: '  As a matter of policy, the SEC routinely declines to\ncomment on i'
data: 'ts enforcement activities.\n Reuter\n\x03'

data: 'URE-MAKES   03-02 0083'
end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'REGAN DEPARTURE MAKES 3RD VOLCKER TERM LIKELY'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Peter Torday, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "Last week's White House shake-up has\nincreased the odds that Federa"
data: 'l Reserve Board chairman Paul\nVolcker, a symbol of strength in a go'
data: 'vernment reeling from the\narms-to-Iran scandal, will serve a third '
data: 'term, sources close to\nthe Fed say.\n    But they said that no deci'
data: 'sion on the appointment, which\nmust be filled this August, has been'
data: ' taken by the White House\nand Volcker too has not made up his mind.'
data: '\n    Former White House Chief of Staff Donald Regan, who\nresigned '
data: 'last week when ex-senator Howard Baker was named as\nhis replacement'
data: ', was implacably opposed to Volcker and tried\noften to undermine hi'
data: 'm.\n    It is an open secret in Washington that Regan tried to\nensu'
data: 're that Volcker, first appointed in 1979 by President\nCarter, will '
data: "not be offered a third term by President Reagan.\n    Only Volcker's"
data: ' key allies in the Reagan administration,\nVice-President George Bus'
data: "h and Treasury Secretary James Baker,\nkept Regan's recent maneuveri"
data: 'ng at bay, the sources said.\n    Sources close to the administratio'
data: 'n say Regan leaked a\nstory, quickly shot down by others in the admi'
data: 'nistration, that\nBeryl Sprinkel, chairman of the council of economi'
data: 'c advisers,\nhad been chosen to replace Volcker.\n    But as the adm'
data: "inistration's credibility was increasingly\nunder fire, it became cl"
data: "ear that Regan's power to bring about\nsuch changes was on the wane."
data: '\n    The sources said New White House Chief of Staff Howard\nBaker '
data: 'has a very good relationship with his namesake at the\nTreasury Depa'
data: 'rtment and is likely to respect his views on the\nFed chairmanship.\n'
data: '    As a moderate Republican, Baker is also unlikely to share\nthe r'
data: 'ight-wing\'s opposition to Volcker.\n    "This new White House is go'
data: 'ing to need all the strength it\ncan get," said one source when aske'
data: "d about the possibility of\nVolcker's reappointment.\n    Paul Volck"
data: 'er is deeply respected in financial markets both\nin the United Stat'
data: 'es and around the world. At a time when the\nstability of the dollar'
data: ' and the viability of major debtor\nnations are in question, Volcker'
data: "'s departure would definitely\nundermine U.S. leadership, foreign ex"
data: 'change analysts say.\n    U.S. officials say Volcker works very clos'
data: 'ely with Treasury\nSecretary Baker on issues like international debt'
data: ' and global\neconomic cooperation.\n    The two men seem only to dif'
data: 'fer on how far to deregulate\nthe banking industry, but recent state'
data: 'ments by Volcker, in\nwhich he adopted a more liberal attitude on de'
data: 'regulation,\nsignalled the politically-independent central bank is c'
data: 'oming\naround at least partially to the Treasury position.\n    And '
data: 'a recent statement by a Reagan administration official\nthat the two'
data: ' men saw "exactly eye-to-eye" on the dollar was seen\nas an indicati'
data: "on of Baker's support for the Fed chairman.\n    Baker is understood"
data: " to have played a key role in Volcker's\nreappointment to the Fed in"
data: ' mid-1983.\n    The sources said Baker respects Volcker and when app'
data: 'ointed\nTreasury Secretary in February 1985, he decided to ensure a\n'
data: 'good working relationship, in part because he believed the two\nkey '
data: 'government economic institutions have to work closely.\n    Regan, T'
data: "reasury Secretary during President Reagan's first\nterm, was formerl"
data: "y head of Wall Street's largest brokerage firm\nMerrill Lynch and ca"
data: "me to Washington determined to be America's\npre-eminent economic sp"
data: 'okesman.\n    He developed a deep antipathy for Volcker, whose polit'
data: 'ical\nskills undermined that ambition, and who financial markets too'
data: 'k\nmuch more seriously.\n    But the sources said Volcker would have'
data: ' to be invited to\nstay. "Is the president going to ask him? he woul'
data: 'dn\'t stay\notherwise," said one. "He\'d have to be asked," said Ste'
data: 'phen\nAxilrod, formerly staff director of monetary policy at the Fed'
data: '\nand now vice-chairman of Nikko Securities Co. International.\n    '
data: 'Otherwise, the list of potential candidates is not\nawe-inspiring. A'
data: 'nd if Volcker left this Augsut, he would leave\nbehind one of the mo'
data: 'st inexperienced Fed Boards in years.\n    Many analysts believe thi'
data: 's lack of collective experience --\nthe four sitting members were al'
data: 'l appointed within the last\nthree years -- is dangerous, coming at '
data: 'a time when the global\neconomy is threatened by instability.\n    A'
data: 'n experienced successor, therefore, would seem a\nnecessity. One wid'
data: 'ely mentioned possibility is Secretary of\nState George Shultz, whos'
data: 'e experience as Treasury Secretary\nunder Preesident Nixon and backg'
data: 'round as a trained economist\nwould make him ideal.\n    But Shultz '
data: 'too may have been damaged by the arms-to-Iran\nscandal, while vice-c'
data: 'hairman Manuel Johnson is regarded at 37\nyears old as too young for'
data: ' the job.\n    Other potential candidates include economist Alan\nGr'
data: 'eenspan, frequently an informal presidential economic\nadviser, New '
data: 'York Fed President E. Gerald Corrigan, Federal\nDeposit Insurance Co'
data: 'rp chairman William Seidman, and Sprinkel.\n    Long a Regan protege'
data: ", Sprinkel's chances may be damaged by\nhis patron's departure from "
data: 'the White House.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

data: 'February volume at the Chicago Board of\nTrade, CBT, declined 14 pct'
data: ' from the year-ago month to\n8,191,266 contracts, the exchange said.'
data: '\n    A relatively steady interest rate climate reduced volume in\nt'
data: 'he most active contract, Treasury bond futures, by 17.5 pct\nfrom a '
data: 'year ago to 4,307,645 contracts.\n    However, trading in most agric'
data: 'ultural futures contracts\nincreased last month, led by oats and cor'
data: 'n futures.\n    Oats volume tripled to 27,662 contracts, and corn vo'
data: 'lume\nincreased 35 pct to 580,204 contracts. Wheat and soybean oil\n'
data: 'futures activity also rose from a year ago, while soybean and\nsoybe'
data: 'an oil volume slipped, the exchange said.\n    Major Market Index fu'
data: 'tures increased activity 37 pct during\nthe month with 194,697 contr'
data: 'acts changing hands.\n Reuter\n\x03'

start tag: <body>
data: 'Grain trade representatives continued\nto speculate that the Reagan '
data: 'administration will offer\nsubsidized wheat to the Soviet Union, whi'
data: 'le U.S. Agriculture\nDepartment officials said there was no substanc'
data: 'e to the\nreports.\n    "It\'s pure fiction," said one senior offici'
data: "al at USDA's\nForeign Agricultural Service, referring to the rumor t"
data: 'hat the\nadministration would make an export enhancement offer to Mo'
data: 'scow\nin the next two to three weeks.\n    An aide to Agriculture Se'
data: 'cretary Richard Lyng who asked not\nto be identified said there was '
data: 'nothing to substantiate the\nspeculation, which he said was started '
data: 'by "somebody fanning the\n(wheat) market." Wheat futures strengthene'
data: 'd today, partly on the\nbasis of the speculation.\n    One lobbyist '
data: 'with close connections to the Reagan\nadministration said a Soviet t'
data: 'rade team told private grain\ntrade officials in New York last week '
data: 'that Moscow would buy as\nmuch as four mln tonnes of U.S. wheat, muc'
data: 'h of it before\nmid-year, if it was "competitively priced."\n    Ale'
data: 'xander Ivlev, an official with Amtorg, a Soviet trading\norganizatio'
data: 'n, told Reuters he had no information to\nsubstantiate the rumors of'
data: ' an imminent wheat subsidy offer, but\nsaid that Moscow "would consi'
data: 'der" buying U.S. wheat if it was\ncompetitively priced.\n    "We don'
data: "'t care if it is EEP, what we (the Soviets) are\nlooking for is comp"
data: 'etitive prices," Ivlev said. "If they (the\nadministration) are inte'
data: 'rested in selling it (wheat), they\nshould find ways to do it."\n Re'
data: 'uter\n\x03'

data: 't talks broke off in\nJanuary and a conciliator has been appointed t'
data: 'o try to help\nsettle the dispute. The current contract expires at t'
data: "he end of\nMarch.\n    The seafarers' employers are also asking for "

start tag: <title>
data: 'REUTERS <RTRSY> IN REAL ESTATE MARKET VENTURE'

data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    NEW YORK, March 2 - '
end tag: </dateline>

data: 'European Community (EC) farm ministers\nwere fighting hard early tod'

data: 'ish city of Saragossa thousands of\nSpanish farmers battled with pol'

data: 'farmers traded stones for tear gas and rubber pellets\nand occupied '
data: 'local government buildings while in the southern\ncity of Malaga, ci'

data: 's form part of an on-going campaign to reform\nsurplus-creating farm'
data: ' policies that have become a political\nembarrassment at home and co'
data: 'mmercial flash-point abroad and\nthreatened to leave the Community w'
data: "ith no cash for other areas.\n    Andriessen's latest package comes "
data: 'only months after a\ndecision to cut dairy production by 9.5 pct ove'
data: 'r two years and\nto slash beef prices by around 10 pct.\n    That de'
data: 'cision, agreed in outline last December after\nvirtually nine days o'

data: 'JAPAN UNEMPLOYMNENT RISES TO RECORD IN JANUARY'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    TOKYO, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "Japan's seasonally adjusted unemployment\nrate rose to a record 3.0 "
data: 'pct in January, the worst since the\nGovernment started compiling un'
data: 'employment statistics under its\ncurrent system in 1953, up from the'
data: " previous record 2.9 pct in\nDecember, the government's Management a"
data: 'nd Coordination Agency\nsaid.\n    Unemployment was up from 2.8 pct '
data: 'a year earlier.\n    Unadjusted January unemployment totalled 1.82 m'
data: 'ln people,\nup from 1.61 mln in December and 1.65 mln a year earlier'
data: '.\n    Male unemployment in January remained at 2.9 pct, equal to\nt'
data: 'he second-worst level set last December. Record male\nunemployement '
data: 'of 3.1 pct was set in July 1986.\n    Female unemployment in January'
data: ' remained at 3.0 pct, equal\nto the record level marked in April, Au'
data: "gust, September and\nDecember last year.\n    January's record 3.0 p"
data: 'ct unemployment rate mainly stemmed\nfrom loss of jobs in manufactur'
data: 'ing industries, particularly in\nexport-related firms, due to the ye'
data: "n's continuing appreciation\nagainst the dollar, officials said.\n  "
data: '  Employment in manufacturing industries fell 380,000 from a\nyear e'
data: 'arlier to 14.30 mln including 1.83 mln employed in the\ntextile indu'
data: 'stry, down 190,000 from a year earlier, and 1.06\nmln in transport i'
data: 'ndustries such as carmakers and shipbuilders,\ndown 170,000.\n REUTE'
data: 'R\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'COFFEE TRADERS EXPECT SELLOFF AFTER ICO TALKS FAIL'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Lisa Vaughan, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    LONDON, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The failure of the International Coffee\nOrganization (ICO) to reach'
data: ' agreement on coffee export quotas\ncould trigger a massive selloff '
data: 'in London coffee futures of at\nleast 100 stg per tonne today, coffe'
data: 'e trade sources said.\n    Prices could easily drop to as low as 1.0'
data: '0 dlr or even 80\ncents a lb this year from around 1.25 dlrs now, th'
data: 'ey said.\n    A special meeting between importing and exporting coun'
data: 'tries\nended in a deadlock late yesterday after eight days of talks\n'
data: 'over how to set the quotas. No further meeting to discuss\nquotas wa'
data: 's set, delegates said.\n    Quotas, the major device used to stabili'
data: 'ze prices under the\nInternational Coffee Agreement, were suspended '
data: 'a year ago after\nprices soared following a damaging drought in Braz'
data: 'il.\n    With no propects for quotas in sight, heavy producer\nselli'
data: 'ng initially and a price war among commercial coffee\nroasting compa'
data: 'nies will ensue, the trade sources predicted.\n    Lower prices are '
data: 'sure to trickle down to the supermarket\nshelf this spring, coffee d'
data: 'ealers said.\n    The U.S. And Brazil, the largest coffee importer a'
data: 'nd\nexporter respectively, each laid the blame on the other for the\n'
data: 'breakdown of the talks.\n    Jon Rosenbaum, U.S. Assistant trade rep'
data: 'resentative and\ndelegate to the talks, said in a statement after th'
data: 'e council\nadjourned, "A majority of producers, led by Brazil, were '
data: 'not\nprepared to negotiate a new distribution based on objective\ncr'
data: 'iteria.\n    "We want to insure that countries receive export quotas'
data: '\nbased on their ability to supply the market, instead of their\npol'
data: 'itical influence in the ICO."\n    Brazilian Coffee Institute (IBC) '
data: 'President Jorio Dauster\ncountered, "Negotiations failed because con'
data: 'sumers tried to\ndictate quotas, not negotiate them."\n    Previousl'
data: 'y, quotas were determined by historical amounts\nexported, which gav'
data: 'e Brazil a 30 pct share of a global market\nof about 58 mln 60-kilo '
data: 'bags. A majority of producers wanted\nquotas to continue under this '
data: 'basic scheme.\n    But most consumers and a maverick group of eight '
data: 'producers\nproposed carving up the export market on the basis of\nex'
data: "portable production and stocks, which would reduce Brazil's\nshare t"
data: 'o 28.8 pct.\n    Consumer delegates said this method would reflect c'
data: "hanges\nin many countries' export capabilities and make coffee more\n"
data: 'readily available to consumers when they need it.\n    A last-minute'
data: ' attempt by Colombia, the second largest\nexporter, to rescue the ta'
data: 'lks with a compromise interim\nproposal could not bring the two side'
data: "s together.\n    Delegates speculated Brazil's financial problems,\n"
data: 'illustrated by its recent suspension of interest payments on\nbank d'
data: 'ebt, have increased political pressure on the country to\nprotect it'
data: 's coffee export earnings.\n    Developing coffee-producing countries'
data: ' that depend heavily\non coffee earnings, particularly some African '
data: "nations and\nColombia, are likely to be hurt the most by the ICO's f"
data: 'ailure\nto agree quotas, analysts said.\n    The expected drop in pr'
data: 'ices could result in losses of as\nmuch as three billion dlrs in a y'
data: 'ear, producer delegates\nforecast.\n    The ICO executive board will'
data: ' meet March 31, but the full\ncouncil is not due to meet again until'
data: ' September, delegates\nsaid.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

data: 'aimed at saving an agreement on\ncutting excessive milk production a'
data: 'fter making no progress in\nover 12 hours of negotiations.\n    The '
data: 'ministers will resume talks at 10.00 local time in a\nbid to clear t'
data: 'he way for a full-scale review of proposed\nreforms for other surplu'
data: 's sectors.\n    Diplomats said member states were unable to settle\n'
data: "differences over new rules limiting farmers' automatic right to\nsel"

data: 'ld continue for one to\nseveral weeks, declining in frequency and ma'

data: 'ert yen into sterling through\ndollars for British securities purcha'
data: 'ses, appear to be buying\nin London rather than in Tokyo, a bond man'

data: 'e was about 240.34/44 today, up from\n234.50 at the start of the cal'
data: 'endar year and a narrow range of\n230 to 234 late last year.\n    Ma'
data: 'ny bond traders in Tokyo are doubtful that sterling will\nfurther ap'
data: 'preciate steeply. However, gilts may benefit from\nfurther declines '
data: 'in U.K. Interest rates, they said.\n    "The U.K. Government is in n'
data: 'o hurry to issue more bonds,\nsuggesting further market improvement '
data: 'and continuing demand\nfrom brokers here," said Laurie Milbank and C'
data: 'o assistant manager\nMachiko Suzuki.\n    She said she expected the '
data: 'yield on the actively traded\n11-3/4 pct gilt due March 2007 to dip '
data: "below 9.5 pct, against\n9.581 pct at yesterday's close in London.\n "

start tag: <title>
data: "JAPAN'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE SEEN RISING TO 3.5 PCT"
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Jeff Stearns, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    TOKYO, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "Japan's unemployment rate is expected to\ncontinue to climb to about"
data: " 3.5 pct within the next year from\nJanuary's three pct record, seni"
data: 'or economists, including Susumu\nTaketomi of Industrial Bank of Japa'
data: "n, said.\n    December's 2.9 pct was the previous worst level since "
data: "the\ngovernment's Management and Coordination Agency began compiling"
data: '\nstatistics under its current system in 1953.\n    "There is a gene'
data: 'ral fear that we will become a country with\nhigh unemployment," sai'
data: 'd Takashi Kiuchi, senior economist for\nthe Long-Term Credit Bank of'
data: ' Japan Ltd.\n    The government, which published the January unemplo'
data: 'yment\nfigures today, did not make any predictions.\n    "At present'
data: ' we do not have a forecast for the unemployment\nrate this year, but'
data: ' it is difficult to foresee the situation\nimproving," a Labour Mini'
data: 'stry official said.\n    Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said the g'
data: 'overnment had\nexpected the increase and had set aside money to help'
data: ' 300,000\npeople find jobs in fiscal 1987 beginning in April.\n    P'
data: 'rime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone told a press conference\nthe record '
data: 'rate underlines the need to pass the 1987 budget\nwhich has been hel'
data: "d up by opposition to proposed tax reforms.\n    The yen's surge has"
data: ' caused layoffs in the mainstay steel\nand shipbuilding industries. '
data: 'Other export-dependent industries,\nsuch as cars and textiles, have '
data: 'laid off part-time employees\nand ceased hiring, economists said.\n '
data: '   Although the growing service industry sector has absorbed a\ngrea'
data: 't number of workers the trend is starting to slow down,\nsaid Koichi'
data: " Tsukihara, Deputy General Manager of Sumitomo Bank\nLtd's economics"
data: ' department.\n    However, other economists disagreed, saying the se'
data: 'rvice\nsector would be able to hire workers no longer needed by the\n'
data: 'manufacturing sector over the next five years.\n    The economists s'
data: 'aid the service sector should grow as the\ngovernment stimulates dom'
data: 'estic demand under its program to\ntransform the economy away from e'
data: 'xports.\n    Although Japanese unemployment rates appear lower than\n'
data: 'those of other industrialised nations, methods for calculating\nstat'
data: 'istics make them difficult to compare, economists warned.\n    "The '
data: 'three pct figure  could translate into a relatively\nhigh figure if '
data: 'European methods were used," one economist said.\nMore than half of '
data: "January's 170,000 increase in jobless from a\nyear earlier were thos"
data: "e aged between 15 and 24, Sumitomo's\nTsukihara said.\n REUTER\n\x03"

start tag: <title>
data: 'JAPAN MOVES TO TIGHTEN CHIP-EXPORT CURBS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    TOKYO, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The Ministry of International Trade and\nIndustry (MITI) acted to ti'
data: 'ghten restrictions on microchip\nexports to countries other than the'
data: ' U.S. To preserve a\nU.S.-Japan pact on semiconductor trade, but maj'
data: 'or Japanese\nchipmakers doubt its usefulness.\n    A MITI spokesman '
data: 'said his ministry had asked chipmakers to\nissue certificates to spe'
data: 'cified trading houses stating they are\nauthorised exporters.\n    T'
data: 'rading houses applying for a MITI export licence will be\nrequired t'
data: 'o show such a certificate, but those without it will\nnot automatica'
data: 'lly be denied licences, he said.\n    But some industry officials pr'
data: 'edicted any government\nmeasures were likely to have limited effect '
data: 'as long as the\nworld semiconductor market remained weak.\n    U.S. '
data: 'Government and industry officials have complained\nrepeatedly that J'
data: 'apanese chipmakers continue to sell at below\ncost to third countrie'
data: 's despite the July agreement.\n    Japanese firms and officials in t'
data: 'urn argue the flow of\ncheap chips to third countries is due to grey'
data: '-market sales by\nthird-party brokers, who seek to profit from the g'
data: 'ap between\nlow prices in Japan and higher prices based on productio'
data: 'n costs\nand set for Japanese makers under the agreement.\n    The M'
data: 'ITI spokesman said, "If the percentage of grey market\nis increasing'
data: ' for one specific company, it suggests they are\ndistributing their '
data: 'products through their sales network knowing\nthey will be exported '
data: 'by some means. In that case we will ask\nthem what they are doing to'
data: ' reduce the figure."\n    MITI earlier asked makers to cut output of'
data: ' certain chips by\n10 pct in first-quarter 1987, spokesmen for the f'
data: 'irms said.\n    But they doubt the usefulness of the latest move. "A'
data: 's long\nas there is a gap between prices set under the pact and mark'
data: 'et\nprices, there will be people who want to exploit the gap to\nmak'
data: 'e money," a Hitachi Ltd <HIT.T> spokesman said.\n REUTER\n\x03'

data: 'Finnish unemployment was 6.7 pct in\nDecember last year compared wit'
data: 'h 6.8 pct in November and 6.1\npct in December 1985, the Central Sta'

data: ' said with real growth at an estimated 1.9 pct in\ncalendar 1986, in'
data: 'dicating signs of recovery from the 1.7 pct\nshrinkage in 1985, the '
data: 'government was likely to hold its course\nand wait for measures intr'
data: "oduced in last year's budget to work.\n    Last March Hu cut corpora"
data: 'tion tax to 33 pct from 40 pct,\nand income tax was reduced by the s'
data: 'ame margin.\n    Last year the government also reduced wage costs by'
data: '\nintroducing a wage freeze and cutting employer contributions to\nt'
data: 'he mandatory state savings scheme, the Central Provident Fund\n(CPF)'
data: ', to 15 pct of salaries from 25 pct.\n    "I don\'t foresee any new '
data: 'or additional stimulus because the\neconomy is now improving," said '
data: 'Clemente Escano, vice president\nof the Union Bank of Switzerland.\n'
data: "    The government's economic report for calendar 1986, issued\nlast"
data: ' week, said the CPF reduction and other cost-cutting\nmeasures only '
data: 'started to bite in the third quarter of 1986.\n    But the report sa'
data: 'id over half the economy -- especially the\ncommerce, financial, and'
data: ' business services sectors -- continued\nto be depressed by weakness'
data: ' in the surrounding regional\neconomies and an excess of domestic pr'
data: 'operty.\n    The sources said the fragility of the economic recovery'
data: '\nsuggested the government would not introduce much of its\nplanned '
data: "consumption tax in the coming financial year.\n    In last year's bu"
data: 'dget Hu said he planned to set up\ncollecting machinery for the tax.'
data: ' Economists said a campaign\nagainst smoking this year might be the '
data: 'opportunity for him to\nlevy the tax on tobacco as a first step towa'
data: 'rds its wider use.\n    The sources said the government does not loo'
data: "k likely to\nraise more revenue in this year's budget.\n    Last yea"
data: "r's budget projected a 3.22 billion dlr budget\ndeficit for fiscal 1"
data: '986/87, but the economic report projected\nan overall calendar 1986 '
data: 'surplus of three billion.\n    Lower tax revenue was balanced by ris'
data: 'ing investment income\nand stringent controls on government operatin'

data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'PHILIPPINE PLANNING CHIEF URGES PESO DEVALUATION'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Chaitanya Kalbag, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    MANILA, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The Philippines must devalue the peso if\nit wants its exports to re'
data: 'main competitive, Economic Planning\nSecretary Solita Monsod told Re'
data: 'uters.\n    "The peso/dollar rate has to be undercut to make our exp'
data: 'orts\nmore competitive," Monsod said an interview. "No question abou'
data: "t\nit. I'm saying you cannot argue with success. Taiwan, South\nKore"
data: 'a, West Germany, Japan, all those miracle economies\ndeliberately un'
data: 'dervalued their currencies."\n    The peso has been free-floating si'
data: 'nce June 1984. It is\ncurrently at about 20.50 to the U.S. Dollar.\n'
data: '    Finance Secretary Jaime Ongpin has said the government does\nnot'
data: ' intend to devalue the peso and wants it to be flexible and\nable to'
data: ' continue to respond to market conditions.\n    Monsod said Ongpin w'
data: 'as looking at the exchange rate from\nthe point of view of finance. '
data: '"If the dollar rate goes higher,\nour debt service in terms of pesos'
data: ' gets higher, so the\nfinancing is very difficult," she said. "But I'
data: ' am looking at it\nin terms of the economy."\n    She said she was n'
data: 'ot trying to oppose official policy.\n    "I\'m just saying, keep it'
data: ' competitive. I do not want it to\nbecome uncompetitive because then'
data: ' we are dead."\n    Monsod said, "The ideal movement in the peso/dol'
data: 'lar rate is\na movement that will reflect differences in inflation ('
data: "rates)\nof the Philippines versus the other country. It's an arithme"
data: 'tic\nthing."\n    Official figures show Philippine inflation average'
data: 'd 0.8 pct\nin calendar 1986. Ongpin told reporters on Saturday it wa'
data: 's\nexpected to touch five pct this year.\n    He said the government'
data: ' and the International Monetary Fund\nhad set the peso/dollar 1987 t'
data: 'arget rate at 20.80.\n    The peso lost 22.2 pct in value to slump t'
data: 'o 18.002 to the\ndollar when it was floated in 1984.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>
data: '\n'
end tag: </reuters>

data: ' from March 1 in line with\nan Association of Tin Producing Countrie'
data: 's (ATPC) plan to curb\nexports, the ATPC said.\n    ATPC Executive D'
data: 'irector Victor Siaahan told Reuters he\nreceived a telex from Zaire '
data: 'indicating its willingess to take\npart in the plan to limit total A'
data: 'TPC exports to 96,000 tonnes\nfor a year from March 1.\n    Siaahan '
data: 'said Zaire is expected to produce 1,900 tonnes of\ntin in calendar 1'
data: '987, and that in 1986 its output and exports\nwere about 1,200 tonne'
data: 's.\n    The ATPC hopes to cut the 70,000-tonne world surplus by\n20,'
data: '000 tonnes and boost prices.\n    All ATPC members except Zaire and '
data: 'Australia recently agreed\nto adhere to the export quotas allocated '
data: 'them under the plan.\nAustralia said its quota of 7,000 tonnes was r'
data: 'oughly equal to\nits expected output this year.\n    The ATPC consis'
data: 'ts of Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand,\nBolivia, Australia, Nigeria an'
data: 'd Zaire.\n    China and Bolivia, important producers of tin, are not'

start tag: <title>
data: 'JAPANESE FINANCIAL FUTURES PLAN REVEALED'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    TOKYO, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "The Federation of Bankers' Associations of\nJapan released its propo"
data: 'sal for early creation of a\ncomprehensive financial futures market '
data: 'in Tokyo.\n    The market should include a comprehensive range of fu'
data: 'tures\nand options trading so Tokyo can develop into a real global\n'
data: 'money centre where a variety of risk-hedging instruments is\navailab'
data: 'le, the proposal said.\n    It should provide currency and interest '
data: 'rate futures, and\nincorporate the existing yen bond futures and pla'
data: 'nned stock\nindex futures contracts.\n    The proposal said transact'
data: 'ions in all these contracts must\nbe conducted on the same market so'
data: ' participants can readily\nengage in arbitrage between various finan'
data: 'cial instruments.\n    To make this possible, the proposal calls for'
data: ' new\nlegislation which would administer all related futures and\nop'
data: 'tions transactions under the same legal framework.\n    Banking sour'
data: 'ces said they expect that initially the\ncurrency futures would be d'
data: 'ollar-yen and interest futures would\ninclude Japanese domestic yen '
data: 'certificates of deposit,\nthree-month Eurodollar deposits and 20-yea'
data: 'r U.S. Treasury\nbonds.\n    Banking sources quoted federation chair'
data: 'man Yoshiro Araki as\nsaying he hoped the market would be created as'
data: ' soon as possible\nbecause it would help promote the liberalisation '
data: "of Japan's\nfinancial markets.\n    Araki said he had no intention o"
data: 'f limiting prospective\nmarket participants to banks but was willing'
data: ' to accept those\nfrom wider business circles, the sources said.\n  '
data: "  Japan's only current financial futures market, in yen\nbonds, bega"
data: 'n on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in October 1985.\n    But the Osaka St'
data: 'ock Exchange plans to start futures trading\nin a basket of leading '
data: 'stocks in April.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

data: 'O-LET-U   03-03 0108'
end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'JAPAN LIKELY TO LET U.S. BANKS DEAL SECURITIES'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Tsukasa Maekawa, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    TOKYO, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'Japan looks likely to allow U.S. Banks to\nconduct securities busine'
data: 'ss here, a move that will probably\ncause the barriers separating Ja'
data: 'panese commercial banks from\nbrokerage houses to break down, financ'
data: 'ial analysts said.\n    But the timing of the approval remains uncer'
data: 'tain, due to\nconflicting domestic interests.\n    J.P.Morgan and Co'
data: ' <JPM>, Bankers Trust New York Corp <BT>,\nManufacturers Hanover Cor'
data: 'p <MHC> and Chemical Bank New York\nCorp <CHL> are expected to win a'
data: 'pproval to conduct securities\nbusiness in Japan, U.S. Bank official'
data: 's said.\n    "There is no reason for extended delay of approval," on'
data: 'e\nofficial at a U.S. Bank said. The four U.S. Banks have been\nseek'
data: 'ing finance ministry approval for months.\n    To date, Japan has al'
data: 'lowed European banks to do securities\nbusiness here through 50-pct '
data: 'owned subsidiaries. As Japanese\nbanks can conduct securities busine'
data: 'ss in European countries,\nthis was seen as a reciprocal move and di'
data: 'd not pave the way for\nJapanese banks to enter the domestic securit'
data: 'ies market.\n    But if U.S. Banks win approval, Japanese banks will'
data: ' press\nhard for similiar status, since they are not allowed to cond'
data: 'uct\nsecurities business in the U.S.\n    Many U.S. Bank officials e'
data: 'xpect their applications to be\napproved before June. But Japanese b'
data: 'anking sources said the\ndecision will be delayed until next year. A'
data: ' spokesman for the\nfinance ministry declined comment.\n    U.S. Ban'
data: 'kers will meet with ministry officials for talks on\nfinancial marke'
data: 't deregulation sometime in the next few months.\nMinistry sources sa'
data: 'id the talks are likely to be held in April\nor June.\n    At the la'
data: 'st round of financial negotiations in September,\nU.S. Officials sai'
data: "d Japan's commitment to deregulation was\nflagging.\n    Analysts sa"
data: 'id the finance ministry has been seriously\nconsidering the U.S. Req'
data: 'uest since the U.S. Federal Reserve\nBank of New York approved five '
data: 'new primary government\nsecurities dealers, including two Japanese b'
data: 'rokerages, last\nDecember.\n    They said the ministry will have to '
data: 'approve the U.S.\nRequest soon to head off criticism its markets are'
data: ' not as open\nto foreigners as those of the U.S.\n    Analysts said '
data: 'Japan has proceeded rapidly with financial\nderegulation since 1984,'
data: ' but has not touched upon the clear\ndivision between the securities'
data: ' and banking businesses.\n    Japanese banks and securities houses h'
data: 'ave fought hard to\nprotect their interests, but analysts said the b'
data: 'anks are\nfinding it increasingly difficult to earn money in traditi'
data: 'onal\nfields.\n    Officials of major Japanese banks said they will '
data: "pay\nspecial attention to the ministry's reaction to U.S. Bank\nrequ"
data: 'ests because approval would accelerate market\nliberalization in Jap'
data: 'an.\n    The Japanese bankers hope approval will pave the way for\nt'
data: 'heir own entry into the domestic securities market.\n REUTER\n\x03'

end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    ME}LBOURNE, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'CRA Ltd <CRAA.S> said it expected to\npay a final 1986 dividend of n'
data: 'ot less than 10 cents a share\nafter July 1, making 13 cents for\x7f'
data: 'the year against 15 in 1985.\n    The mining and smelting group earl'
data: 'ier reported 1986 net\nearnings rose to 138.2 mln dlrs from 87.8 mln'
data: " in 1985, against\nanalysts' forecasts yesterday of 125 mln to\x7f16"
data: '0 mln.\n    CRA said it was deferring consideration of a dividend un'
data: 'til\nlater this year to provide the benefit of dividend imputation\n'
data: 'to its shareholders. After July 1, dividends will be tax-free\nto sh'
data: 'areholders provided they come out of earnings on which the\nfull 49 '
data: 'pct company tax rate has been p\x7fid.\n    The company operates on '
data: 'a substituted tax year, not the\nfiscal year ending June 30, and as '
data: 'a result has incurred tax at\nthe 49 pct rate on 1986 earnings, CRA '
data: 'said in a statement.\n    Consequently, it has funds available for d'
data: 'istribution with\ndividend imputed but is waiting to see the imputat'
data: 'ion\nlegislation before determining the final payout, it said.\n    '
data: 'Despite the higher net earnings, CRA said 1986 was a poor\nyear for '
data: 'the minerals industry, with the notable exception of\ngold producers'
data: '.\n    Prices for major metals expressed in real U.S. Dollars\ndecli'
data: 'ned to the lowest levels in about 50 years, it said.\n    Fluctuatin'
data: 'g exchange and interest rates added volatility\nand uncertainty, whi'
data: 'le the revaluation of the yen is leading to\nsubstantial restructuri'
data: 'ng of Japanese industry, CRA said.\n    World demand for metals is g'
data: 'rowing slowly. Inventories have\nsteadily declined, with supply and '
data: 'demand in better balance,\nbut overcapacity continues, CRA said.\n  '
data: '  Turning to contributions to its earnings, CRA said\nBougainville C'
data: 'opper Ltd <BUVA.S> contributed 31.3 mln dlrs\nwhile its share of Com'
data: "alco Ltd's <CMAC.S> net was 37.8 mln.\n    Net earnings from iron-or"
data: 'e operations were 111.8 mln dlrs\nagainst 149.2 mln in 1985, it said'
data: '.\n    Lead, zinc and silver mining and smelting operations\nincurre'
data: 'd a net loss of 66.8 mln dlrs against a 38.1 mln loss in\n1985, CRA '
data: 'said.\n    Coal activities resulted in a net profit of 36.7 mln dlrs'
data: '\nagainst 34.1 mln, while salt raised its contribution to 4.7 mln\nf'
data: "rom 2.8 mln.\n    CRA's share of earnings from the Argyle diamond pr"
data: 'oject\namounted to 12.0 mln dlrs against nine mln in 1985.\n    CRA '
data: 'said the main item in its 250.28 mln dlr extraordinary\nloss was a 1'
data: '72.9 mln writeoff of unrealised foreign exchange\nlosses on borrowin'
data: 'gs as required by a new accounting standard.\n    Other extraordinar'
data: 'y items were 63.3 mln dlrs provided for\nclosures and writedown of a'
data: 'ssets and a 14.1 mln increase in\nfuture tax provisions, CRA said.\n'
data: '    Cash flow continued at a high level, being 950.6 mln dlrs\nbefor'
data: 'e capital expenditure against 1.02 billion in 1985. The\nstrong cash'
data: ' flow, coupled with the proceeds of the 1986 rights\nissue and the u'
data: 'se of existing cash balances, enabled group debt\nto be reduced by n'
data: 'early 500 mln dlrs.\n    CRA said it held forward contracts at year-'
data: 'end to buy 985\nmln U.S. Dlrs to hedge part of its foreign debt. Thi'
data: 's cost 47.0\nmln dlrs after tax, included in the net interest cost.\n'

data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'CHINA CALLS FOR BETTER TRADE DEAL WITH U.S.'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: "    By Mark O'Neill, Reuters"
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    PEKING, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'China called on the United States to\nremove curbs on its exports, t'
data: 'o give it favourable trading\nstatus and ease restrictions on export'
data: 's of high technology.\n    But the U.S. Embassy replied that Chinese'
data: ' figures showing\n13 years of trade deficits with the U.S. Out of th'
data: 'e last 15 are\ninaccurate and said Peking itself would have to persu'
data: 'ade\nCongress to change laws which limit its exports.\n     The offi'
data: "cial International Business newspaper today\npublished China's deman"
data: 'ds in a  editorial to coincide with the\nvisit of U.S. Secretary of '
data: 'State George Shultz.\n     "It is extremely important that the U.S. '
data: 'Market reduce its\nrestrictions on Chinese imports, provide the need'
data: 'ed facilities\nfor them and businessmen from both sides help to expa'
data: 'nd Chinese\nexports," the editorial said.\n     "The U.S. Should qui'
data: 'ckly discard its prejudice against\nfavourable tariff treatment for '
data: 'Chinese goods and admit China\ninto the Generalised System of Prefer'
data: 'ence (GSP).\n     "Despite easing of curbs on U.S. Technology export'
data: 's in\nrecent years, control of them is still extremely strict and\ni'
data: 'nfluences normal trade between the two countries," it added\n     Th'
data: "e paper also printed an article by China's commercial\ncounsellor in"
data: ' its Washington embassy, Chen Shibiao, who said\nthat "all kinds of '
data: 'difficulties and restrictions" were preventing\nbilateral trade fulf'
data: 'illing its full potential.\n     He named them as U.S. Protectionist'
data: ' behaviour, curbs on\ntechnology transfer and out-of-date trade legi'
data: 'slation.\n     The paper also printed a table showing that, since\nb'
data: 'ilateral trade began in 1972, China has had a deficit every\nyear ex'
data: 'cept 1972 and 1977. It shows the 1986 and 1985 deficits\nat 2.09 bil'
data: 'lion and 1.722 billion dlrs.\n     A U.S. Embassy official said the '
data: "U.S. Did not accept\nPeking's trade figures at all, mainly because t"
data: 'hey exclude\ngoods shipped to Hong Kong and then trans-shipped to U.'
data: 'S. While\nU.S. Figures are based on country of origin.\n     He said'
data: ' that, if China wants to obtain GSP status, it will\nhave to lobby C'
data: 'ongress itself to persaude it to amend several\nlaws which currently'
data: ' prevent Peking getting such status.\n     The U.S. Trade Act of 197'
data: '4 says that to qualify for GSP,\nChina must be a member of the Gener'
data: 'al Agreement of Tariffs and\nTrade (GATT), for which it applied in J'
data: 'uly 1986, and "not be\ndominated or controlled by international Comm'
data: 'unism."\n     The official said China was well aware of the laws, so'
data: "me\nof which date to the anti-Communist early 1950's, but that\nther"
data: 'e is not sufficient political will in the U.S. To change\nthem.\n   '
data: '  China has been the subject of about a dozen cases\ninvolving anti-'
data: 'dumping in the U.S. Within the last two years,\nwhich the U.S. Side '
data: 'won, he said.\n     But, for the first time, China signed last week '
data: 'an\nagreement which it itself initiated to voluntarily restrain\nexp'
data: 'orts of at least two categories of steel goods, which may\nlead the '
data: 'U.S. Side to withdraw the anti-dumping case, he added.\n     Another'
data: ' diplomat said willingness to provide such\nvoluntary export restrai'
data: 'nts would be an important issue in\nbilateral trade issues and in Pe'
data: 'king\'s application to GATT.\n     "China has the potential to disru'
data: 'pt world markets,\nespecially in textiles. Other GATT countries will'
data: ' be nervous\nabout China in this respect. But there is a precedent f'
data: 'or other\ncentralled planned economies in GATT," the diplomat said.\n'
data: '     Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Romania are members of\nGAT'
data: "T but none has China's massive market potential for imports\nor its "
data: 'vast labour pool to produce cheap exports.\n     In a speech today i'
data: 'n the northeast city of Dalian, U.S.\nSecretary of State George Shul'
data: "tz said his country welcomed\nChina's interest in participating in G"
data: 'ATT.\n     "The process of Chinese accession will not be accomplishe'
data: 'd\novernight -- the GATT rules were not designed for a large\neconom'
data: 'y of the Chinese type," Shultz said.\n     "China can play an import'
data: 'ant role by actively joining GATT\ndiscussions seeking to expand gen'
data: 'eral trading opportunities and\nenhance market access for exports wo'
data: 'rldwide. China can further\ndevelop its foreign trade system so as t'
data: 'o gain the maximum\nbenefit from its GATT participation," he said.\n'
data: '     The problems facing U.S.-China trade and GATT membership\nare s'
data: 'imilar -- a pricing system which many foreign businessmen\nregard as'
data: ' arbitrary and not related to actual costs, especially\nfor exports,'
data: ' and a de facto dual currency system.\n     In a memorandum backing '
data: 'its application presented to GATT\nlast month, China said it was gra'
data: 'dually reforming its economic\nsystem and replacing mandatory instru'
data: 'ction with "guidance\nplanning" and economic levers.\n     The diplo'
data: 'mat said that, to join GATT, China had much to\ndo.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

end tag: </reuters>

data: 'reasury said.\n    The underlying trend, which is a guide to Bank of'
data: ' England\noperations to support the pound on foreign exchanges, is n'
data: 'et of\nborrowings and repayments.\n    This was above market expecta'
data: 'tions for a 100 mln dlrs rise.\n    The Treasury said the Bank of En'
data: 'gland used the opportunity\nof strong demand to rebuild reserves aft'

data: 'vely modest.\n    Actual reserves rose by 305 mln dlrs in February t'
data: 'o 22.26\nbillion dlrs, after rising 29 mln in January to 21.95 billi'
data: 'on.\n    Accruals of borrowings under the exchange cover scheme were'
data: '\n36 mln dlrs last month, after 163 mln in January, while\nrepayment'
data: 's were 16 mln dlrs after the previous 151 mln, a\nTreasury spokesman'
data: ' said.\n    Capital repayments totalled two mln dlrs. In January,\nc'
data: 'apital repayments totalled 14 mln dlrs, with a valuation\nchange tha'
data: 't resulted in a fall of 41 mln dlrs due to the\nquarterly rollover f'
data: 'rom the European Monetary Cooperation Fund\nswap.\n    The Treasury '
data: "would not comment on the Bank of England's\nmarket operations, but c"
data: 'urrency traders reported moderate Bank\nof England intervention to c'
data: 'urb upward pressure on the pound\ntoday.\n    A Treasury spokesman, '
data: 'commenting on the reserves figures,\nsaid that the government does n'
data: 'ot want sterling either to rise\ntoo far or to fall substantially fr'
data: 'om current levels.\n    He noted that the Chancellor of the Excheque'
data: 'r Nigel Lawson\nstressed this after the recent Paris currencies meet'

data: 'HONG KONG M3 RISES 2.2 PCT IN JANUARY'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    HONG KONG, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "Hong Kong's broadly defined M3 money\nsupply rose 2.2 pct to 607.17 "
data: 'billion H.K. Dlrs in January,\nafter a 3.1 pct rise in December, for'
data: ' a year-on-year rise of\n23.3 pct, the government said in a statemen'
data: 't.\n    Local currency M3 rose 3.6 pct to 280.36 billion dlrs from\n'
data: 'December when it was up 3.4 pct from November, for a rise of\n16.3 p'
data: 'ct on the year.\n    Total M2 rose 3.3 pct to 535.26 billion dlrs in'
data: ' January\nfrom December when it rose 3.5 pct on the previous month. '
data: 'Local\nM2 rose 4.7 pct to 249.03 billion dlrs in January from Decemb'
data: 'er\nwhen it climbed 4.2 pct.\n    Total M2 and local M2 rose 32.5 pc'
data: 't and 23.9 pct on the\nyear-ago month, respectively.\n    Total M1 r'
data: 'ose 12 pct to 62.84 billion dlrs in January after\na 5.0 pct rise th'
data: 'e previous month. Local M1 rose 12.3 pct to\n57.97 billion dlrs afte'
data: 'r a 6.2 pct rise. Total M1 and local M1\nyear-on-year growth was 32.'
data: '5 and 32.6 pct, respectively.\n    Total loans and advances rose 3.3'
data: ' pct to 517.19 billion\ndlrs from December when they rose 1.2 pct.\n'
data: "    Loans for financing Hong Kong's visible trade rose 3.4 pct\nto 3"
data: '6.72 billion dlrs after a 1.8 pct rise in December.\n REUTER\n\x03'
end tag: </body>
end tag: </text>

data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'NO BUNDESBANK POLICY CHANGES EXPECTED THURSDAY'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    FRANKFURT, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The Bundesbank is unlikely to change\nits credit policies at its cen'
data: 'tral bank council meeting on\nThursday, as exchange rates and short-'
data: 'term interest rates have\nstabilized over the past few weeks, money '
data: 'market dealers said.\n    Attention in the money market is focused o'
data: "n tomorrow's\ntender for a securities repurchase pact, from which fu"
data: 'nds will\nbe credited on Thursday, when an earlier pact expires, dra'
data: 'ining\n16 billion marks from the system.\n    The tender was announc'
data: 'ed last Friday, because carnival\nfestivities closed banks in Duesse'
data: 'ldorf yesterday, and will\nclose banks here this afternoon.\n    Bec'
data: 'ause of the disruption to business from carnival,\nminimum reserve f'
data: 'igures for the start of the month are\nunrealistic, making it diffic'
data: 'ult for banks to assess their\nneeds at the tender.\n    Dealers sai'
data: 'd the Bundesbank would want to inject enough\nliquidity in this week'
data: "'s pact to keep short-term rates down.\n    But because of uncertain"
data: "ty about banks' current holdings,\nthe Bundesbank may well allocate "
data: 'less than 16 billion marks\nthis week, and top it up if necessary at'
data: ' next week\'s tender.\n    "I would not be surprised if the Bundesba'
data: 'nk cuts the amount\na little, to say 14 or 15 billion marks," one de'
data: 'aler said.\n    "They would then stock it up at the next tender when'
data: ' the\nneed is clearer," he added.\n    An earlier pact expires next '
data: 'week, draining 8.5 billion\nmarks from the system. Banks also face a'
data: ' heavy but temporary\ndrain this month from a major tax deadline for'
data: ' customers.\n    Banks held 52.0 billion marks on February 27 at the'
data: '\nBundesbank, averaging 51.0 billion over the whole month, just\ncle'
data: 'ar of the 50.5 billion February reserve requirement.\n    Call money'
data: ' traded today at 3.85/95 pct, up from 3.80/90\nyesterday.\n REUTER\n'

data: 'EEK-GRE   03-03 0110'
end tag: </unknown>
data: '\n'
start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'GERMAN BANKS SEEK GREATER BRAZIL LINK WITH IMF'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Anthony Williams, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    BONN, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'West German banks would like Brazil to work\nmore closely with the I'
data: 'nternational Monetary Fund (IMF) with a\nview to seeking a solution '
data: "to the country's debt problems,\nsenior West German banking sources "
data: 'said.\n    The sources, speaking ahead of a meeting later today\nbet'
data: 'ween Brazilian Finance Minister Dilson Funaro and his West\ngerman c'
data: 'ounterpart Gerhard Stoltenberg, also believed Brazil\nshould come up'
data: ' with a convincing economic recovery program.\n    Their comments ec'
data: 'hoed those of British Chancellor of the\nExchequer Nigel Lawson, who'
data: ' met Funaro yesterday.\n    Funaro is currently on a European trip s'
data: 'eeking to involve\ngovernments in negotiations with commercial banks'
data: " on\nrescheduling part of Brazil's foreign debt, which totals some\n"
data: '109 billion dlrs. But Lawson told Funaro Brazil had to solve\nits pr'
data: 'oblems with the banks rather than governments.\n    Diplomatic sourc'
data: 'es in Bonn said Funaro would leave early\ntomorrow morning for Zuric'
data: 'h after meeting Stoltenberg this\nevening.\n    Funaro has rejected '
data: 'suggestions for negotiations with the\nIMF and said there is no ques'
data: 'tion of Brazil agreeing to an\nausterity program with the Fund.\n   '
data: ' However, the West German banking sources said institutions\nhere fe'
data: 'lt it was particularly important that Brazil presented a\ncredible r'
data: 'ecovery program and that there be a "rapprochement"\nwith the IMF.\n'
data: '    "Consultations are the least that can be expected," said one\nba'
data: "nker.\n    Funaro's trip follows the decision by Brazil 10 days ago "

data: '. It has also frozen bank and credit lines deposited by\nforeign ban'
data: 'ks and institutions worth about 15 billion dlrs.\n    One senior ban'

data: 'd support for a call from Funaro\nfor a change in the structure of t'
data: 'he advisory committee of\nbanks which has coordinated Brazilian debt'
data: ' since 1982.\n    Funaro said yesterday that U.S. Banks, holding 35 '
data: 'pct of\nBrazilian debt, were over-represented on the 14-bank advisor'
data: 'y\ncommittee with 50 pct of the committee seats. He said Brazil\nmig'
data: 'ht adopt a different approach to its creditor banks,\ninvolving sepa'
data: 'rate discussions with the regions.\n    Such a move would be in Braz'
data: "il's interest, since European\nbanks have been more supportive than "
data: 'U.S. Banks of alternative\ndebt solutions, such as interest capitali'
data: 'sation.\n    The senior banker was strongly opposed to a purely regi'
data: 'onal\napproach, saying: "There must be one committee and one solutio'
data: 'n."\nBut he added: "There must be an understanding that special\nreq'
data: 'uests from special regions be taken into account."\n    German banks'
data: ' had objected to the fact that the idea of\ninterest capitalisation '
data: 'had been rejected in the committee. It\nwas imperative that alternat'
data: 'ive options be considered. "The menu\nmust become richer," the banke'
data: 'r said.\n    Banking sources said commercial banks would not be invo'
data: "lved\nin today's talks with Funaro. A spokesman for the Bundesbank i"
data: 'n\nFrankfurt said the central bank would also not be represented.\n '

start tag: <text>
data: '\x02\n'
start tag: <title>
data: 'REGAN DEPARTURE MAKES 3RD VOLCKER TERM LIKELY'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <author>
data: '    By Peter Torday, Reuters'
end tag: </author>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "Last week's White House shake-up has\nincreased the odds that Federa"
data: 'l Reserve Board chairman Paul\nVolcker, a symbol of strength in a go'
data: 'vernment reeling from the\narms-to-Iran scandal, will serve a third '
data: 'term, sources close to\nthe Fed say.\n    But they said that no deci'
data: 'sion on the appointment, which\nmust be filled this August, has been'
data: ' taken by the White House\nand Volcker too has not made up his mind.'
data: '\n    Former White House Chief of Staff Donald Regan, who\nresigned '
data: 'last week when ex-senator Howard Baker was named as\nhis replacement'
data: ', was implacably opposed to Volcker and tried\noften to undermine hi'
data: 'm.\n    It is an open secret in Washington that Regan tried to\nensu'
data: 're that Volcker, first appointed in 1979 by President\nCarter, will '
data: "not be offered a third term by President Reagan.\n    Only Volcker's"
data: ' key allies in the Reagan administration,\nVice-President George Bus'
data: "h and Treasury Secretary James Baker,\nkept Regan's recent maneuveri"
data: 'ng at bay, the sources said.\n    Sources close to the administratio'
data: 'n say Regan leaked a\nstory, quickly shot down by others in the admi'
data: 'nistration, that\nBeryl Sprinkel, chairman of the council of economi'
data: 'c advisers,\nhad been chosen to replace Volcker.\n    But as the adm'
data: "inistration's credibility was increasingly\nunder fire, it became cl"
data: "ear that Regan's power to bring about\nsuch changes was on the wane."
data: '\n    The sources said New White House Chief of Staff Howard\nBaker '
data: 'has a very good relationship with his namesake at the\nTreasury Depa'
data: 'rtment and is likely to respect his views on the\nFed chairmanship.\n'
data: '    As a moderate Republican, Baker is also unlikely to share\nthe r'
data: 'ight-wing\'s opposition to Volcker.\n    "This new White House is go'
data: 'ing to need all the strength it\ncan get," said one source when aske'
data: "d about the possibility of\nVolcker's reappointment.\n    Paul Volck"
data: 'er is deeply respected in financial markets both\nin the United Stat'
data: 'es and around the world. At a time when the\nstability of the dollar'
data: ' and the viability of major debtor\nnations are in question, Volcker'
data: "'s departure would definitely\nundermine U.S. leadership, foreign ex"
data: 'change analysts say.\n    U.S. officials say Volcker works very clos'
data: 'ely with Treasury\nSecretary Baker on issues like international debt'
data: ' and global\neconomic cooperation.\n    The two men seem only to dif'
data: 'fer on how far to deregulate\nthe banking industry, but recent state'
data: 'ments by Volcker, in\nwhich he adopted a more liberal attitude on de'
data: 'regulation,\nsignalled the politically-independent central bank is c'
data: 'oming\naround at least partially to the Treasury position.\n    And '
data: 'a recent statement by a Reagan administration official\nthat the two'
data: ' men saw "exactly eye-to-eye" on the dollar was seen\nas an indicati'
data: "on of Baker's support for the Fed chairman.\n    Baker is understood"
data: " to have played a key role in Volcker's\nreappointment to the Fed in"
data: ' mid-1983.\n    The sources said Baker respects Volcker and when app'
data: 'ointed\nTreasury Secretary in February 1985, he decided to ensure a\n'
data: 'good working relationship, in part because he believed the two\nkey '
data: 'government economic institutions have to work closely.\n    Regan, T'
data: "reasury Secretary during President Reagan's first\nterm, was formerl"
data: "y head of Wall Street's largest brokerage firm\nMerrill Lynch and ca"
data: "me to Washington determined to be America's\npre-eminent economic sp"
data: 'okesman.\n    He developed a deep antipathy for Volcker, whose polit'
data: 'ical\nskills undermined that ambition, and who financial markets too'
data: 'k\nmuch more seriously.\n    But the sources said Volcker would have'
data: ' to be invited to\nstay. "Is the president going to ask him? he woul'
data: 'dn\'t stay\notherwise," said one. "He\'d have to be asked," said Ste'
data: 'phen\nAxilrod, formerly staff director of monetary policy at the Fed'
data: '\nand now vice-chairman of Nikko Securities Co. International.\n    '
data: 'Otherwise, the list of potential candidates is not\nawe-inspiring. A'
data: 'nd if Volcker left this Augsut, he would leave\nbehind one of the mo'
data: 'st inexperienced Fed Boards in years.\n    Many analysts believe thi'
data: 's lack of collective experience --\nthe four sitting members were al'
data: 'l appointed within the last\nthree years -- is dangerous, coming at '
data: 'a time when the global\neconomy is threatened by instability.\n    A'
data: 'n experienced successor, therefore, would seem a\nnecessity. One wid'
data: 'ely mentioned possibility is Secretary of\nState George Shultz, whos'
data: 'e experience as Treasury Secretary\nunder Preesident Nixon and backg'
data: 'round as a trained economist\nwould make him ideal.\n    But Shultz '
data: 'too may have been damaged by the arms-to-Iran\nscandal, while vice-c'
data: 'hairman Manuel Johnson is regarded at 37\nyears old as too young for'
data: ' the job.\n    Other potential candidates include economist Alan\nGr'
data: 'eenspan, frequently an informal presidential economic\nadviser, New '
data: 'York Fed President E. Gerald Corrigan, Federal\nDeposit Insurance Co'
data: 'rp chairman William Seidman, and Sprinkel.\n    Long a Regan protege'
data: ", Sprinkel's chances may be damaged by\nhis patron's departure from "
data: 'the White House.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

start tag: <dateline>
data: '    DETROIT, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'General Motors Corp has changed its\nmethod of disbursing merit rais'
data: 'es for salaried employees and is\nreducing the size of the merit rai'
data: 'se pool to 3.5 pct of the\ntotal amount available for salaries from '
data: '5.5 pct last year, a\ncompany spokesman said.\n    He said GM will n'
data: 'o longer include merit raises in the\ncalculation of base pay but wi'
data: 'll make them simply lump-sum\npayments.  As a result, the merit rais'
data: 'es will not be included\nin the calculation of pensions and other be'
data: 'nefits.  The change\naffects about 109,000 salaried workers in the U'
data: '.S. and Canada.\n                                       \n    GM las'
data: 't year eliminated cost of living increases for\nsalaried workers, ma'
data: 'king pay increases based on merit alone. As\na result of the new act'
data: 'ion, GM has effectively frozen the base\npay rates of salaried emplo'
data: 'yees.\n    The spokesman said GM is making the change to remain\ncos'
data: 't-competitive with other U.S. automakers.\n    GM is currently in th'
data: 'je midst of a program to cut\nemployment of salaried workers by 25 p'
data: 'ct.\n Reuter\n\x03'

start tag: <title>
data: 'U.S. LEADING INDEX FELL 1.0 PCT IN JANUARY'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    WASHINGTON, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: 'The U.S. index of leading indicators\nfell a seasonally adjusted 1.0'
data: ' pct in January after a revised\n2.3 pct December gain, the Commerce'
data: ' Department said.\n    The department previously said the index rose'
data: ' 2.1 pct in\nDecember.\n    The decline in January was the biggest f'
data: 'or any month since\nJuly, 1984, when the index fell 1.7 pct.\n    Th'
data: 'e January decrease left the index at 183.8 over its 1967\nbase of 10'
data: '0, and was led by a fall in contracts and orders for\nplant and equi'
data: 'pment.\n    A total of six of 10 indicators available for January\nc'
data: 'ontributed to the decline.\n    Besides contracts and orders for pla'
data: "nt and equipment, they\nwere building permits, manufacturers' new or"
data: 'ders for consumer\ngoods, a change in sensitive materials prices, sl'
data: 'ower\ndeliveries from vendors and higher average weekly claims for\n'
data: 'state unemployment insurance.\n    Four of 10 indicators were positi'
data: 've, including stock\nprices, new business formation, average work we'
data: 'ek and money\nsupply.\n    The main factor for the December upward r'
data: 'evision was new\nbusiness formation.\n    There was no revision in t'
data: 'he 0.9 pct increase in the\nleading indicators index for November.\n'
data: '    The index of coincident indicators, which measures the\ncurrent '
data: 'economy, fell 0.1 pct in January after increases of 0.7\npct in Dece'
data: 'mber and 0.2 pct in November.\n    The index of lagging indicators, '
data: 'which measures past\neconomic activity, rose 0.5 pct in January afte'
data: 'r a decrease of\n0.5 pct in December and an increase of 0.2 pct in N'
data: 'ovember.\n Reuter\n\x03'
end tag: </body>

data: 'COFFEE PRICE FALL SHORT TERM - DUTCH ROASTERS'
end tag: </title>
data: '\n'
start tag: <dateline>
data: '    ROTTERDAM, March 3 - '
end tag: </dateline>
start tag: <body>
data: "This morning's sharp decline in coffee\nprices, following the breakd"
data: 'own late last night of negotiations\nin London to reintroduce Intern'
data: 'ational Coffee Organization,\nICO, quotas, will be short-lived, Dutc'
data: 'h roasters said.\n    "The fall is a technical and emotional reactio'
data: 'n to the\nfailure to agree on reintroduction of ICO export quotas, b'
data: 'ut it\nwill not be long before reality reasserts itself and prices\n'
data: 'rise again," a spokesman for one of the major Dutch roasters\nsaid.\n'
data: '    "The fact is that while there are ample supplies of coffee\navai'
data: 'lable at present, there is a shortage of quality," he said.\n    "Av'
data: 'erage prices fell to around 110 cents a lb following the\nnews of th'
data: 'e breakdown but we expect them to move back again to\naround 120 cen'
data: 'ts within a few weeks," the roaster added.\n    Dutch Coffee Roaster'
data: "s' Association secretary Jan de Vries\nsaid although the roasters we"
data: 're disappointed at the failure of\nconsumer and producer ICO represe'
data: 'ntatives to agree on quota\nreintroduction, it was equally important'
data: ' that quotas be\nreallocated on a more equitable basis.\n    "There '
data: 'is no absolute need for quotas at this moment because\nthe market is'
data: ' well balanced and we must not lose this\nopportunity to renegotiate'
data: ' the coffee agreement," he said.\n    "There is still a lot of work '
data: 'to be done on a number of\nclauses of the International Coffee Agree'
data: 'ment and we would not\nwelcome quota reintroduction until we have a '
data: 'complete\nrenegotiation," de Vries added.\n    With this in mind, an'
data: 'd with Dutch roasters claiming to have\nfairly good forward cover, t'
data: 'he buying strategy for the\nforeseeable future would probably be to '
data: 'buy coffee on a\nhand-to-mouth basis and on a sliding scale when mar'
data: 'ket prices\nwere below 120 cents a lb, roasters said.\n Reuter\n\x03'
